HEADLINE: Texas Frees 12 on Bond After Drug Sweep Inquiry 

BYLINE:  By MONICA DAVEY 

DATELINE: TULIA, Tex., June 16 

 BODY:
In the same warm third-floor courtroom where she was convicted three years ago, Kizzie White was told this afternoon to go home. She searched the packed room for her son, Cashawn, 6, who had lived with relatives since she went to prison and who, for the rest of the afternoon, kept one small hand touching her -- her hand, her ear, her neck. 
 Joe Moore, 60, clutched a crumpled shopping bag. In it were gifts he had asked his lawyers to deliver like bubble bath, a toothbrush, cocoa butter and hair conditioner. Mr. Moore, a hog farmer, had been craving a long hot bath for the four years that he spent in a prison in Abilene, he said. 
 A third man left the courthouse and went home as fast as possible.
"I've got to get to my kids," he called out as he pushed to the exit.
They were among 12 inmates released on bond, most of the remaining people behind bars stemming from a drug sweep in 1999 that led to convictions against 38 people, most of them black. Lawyers and advocates have pointed to the case as an example of racism in law enforcement, and the narcotics agent who organized and carried out the sweep has been criticized for his tactics, racial comments and history.
Still, as the former prisoners and their families celebrated this evening with barbecued ribs and hot links in the basement of the Swisher County Memorial building, their lawyers warned that their legal troubles were not ended. 
Ron Chapman, a retired judge who has presided over hearings in the case, ordered the prisoners released after Gov. Rick Perry signed a special bill this month to allow that unusual step. The State Court of Criminal Appeals and the Board of Pardons and Paroles are reviewing the case. Those outcomes will decide whether any convictions stand and whether the 12 people might return to prison.
"It's a significant day, but it's not the end at all," said Vanita Gupta, a lawyer with the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund Inc. "Our clients are walking out under the cloud of conviction." 
In fact, some defendants struggled before they went to prison. Some were unemployed, their lawyers said, and others had criminal records. At the hearing, Judge Chapman urged them to avoid trouble. 
"There are a great number of people who have a great deal of time, effort and faith in each of you invested," he said. "Your friends and loved ones are counting on you."
As they left the courthouse, some former inmates outlined plans -- for engineering school, for road trips, for a big first meal on the outside.
"I just want to go on with my life," said Mr. Moore, adding that he was not certain what that might mean. 
Since he was sentenced to a 90-year term for the delivery of cocaine, he said, he did not know what had happened to the 350 hogs that he cared for on 30 acres. 
"I don't know," he said. "I've been locked up. I want to go home, look at TV and stay out of trouble." 
Some of the lawyers said they planned to deliver a blunt message for their clients when they met with them privately, leave Tulia.
"It's going to be impossible to stay here," said JeffBlackburn, a lawyer from Amarillo. 
The prisoners will encounter the jurors who convicted them, Mr. Blackburn said, adding:
"These folks will have virtually no chance if they stay here. They will be arrested for spitting. They will be pursued to the ends of the earth."
If the prisoners had harsh feelings about Tulia, a dusty town of 5,000 between Amarillo and Lubbock, they were not saying so tonight.
"There's no doubt about it, we have great people here in Tulia," said Freddie Brookins Jr., who was serving a 20-year sentence for the delivery of cocaine. 
As lawyers, reporters and relatives gathered at the courthouse, far fewer white residents showed up. The cases have stirred deep racial tensions, and the reactions of the white majority were all but silent. Almost no one, not even officials, would offer opinions about race relations here. 
"It's a great community with great people," Sheriff Larry Stewart said. "That's it. That's all I'll say."
On nearby streets and in nearby stores, some white residents, all refusing to be quoted by name, questioned whether the defendants were not guilty of drug crimes and faulted the news media for unfairly portraying an entire town as racist by pinning the work of one troubled officer on an entire community.
Thomas Coleman, the former undercover narcotics agent who carried out the 18-month investigation as part of the Panhandle Regional Narcotics Task Force, was named the state's Lawman of the Year shortly after the arrests. But his credibility -- and the case itself -- have unraveled. In April, he was charged with lying under oath about his background at a hearing related to the drug cases. 
Mr. Coleman has an unlisted telephone number. His lawyer, Cindy Ermatinger of Waxahachie, did not return a call.
Early on July 23, 1999, as television cameras captured their images, the 46 people whom Mr. Coleman said he had bought drugs from were arrested. Thirty-nine were black. No drugs, weapons or large quantities of cash were seized.
At least two of the 38 people who were convicted remained behind bars this evening because of legal complications.
Mr. Coleman's methods raised questions. He did not record his purchases, and he worked alone. His notes sometimes consisted of his jotting down broad information about sales on his leg.
The cases had inconsistencies, too. Tonya White's lawyers proved that she withdrew $8 from a bank in Oklahoma on the day she was reportedly selling drugs here. 
"I knew something would come up to prove I was innocent," Ms. White said. But three siblings, including Kareem and Kizzie, went to prison. Both emerged today. 
In a crush of television cameras, Kizzie White, 26, stood with her son and a daughter, Roneisha, 9. Ms. White looked down shyly at the reporters and the constant questions. She said she had missed her children bitterly. 
"I wanted to be there for them," she said. She saw her children eight times in prison, she said. She was allowed to call them for a few moments every 90 days, and she wrote to them three times a week to remind them that she loved them, she said. Their names are tattooed in fancy script on her shoulder and neck. 
For now, Ms. White said, she will stay in Tulia. But she said she was thinking about moving to Houston, perhaps to attend nursing school. 
Sometime, she said, she will explain all that happened. 
"What I want to do now is to be the best mother I can," she said.
Roneisha turned to her mother, who was talking with a reporter, and asked, "After this, can we go now?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: Kizzie White with a friend, Tamika Ray, 11, left, and her daughter Roneisha, 9, after being released from prison yesterday in Tulia, Tex. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: THE PRESIDENT; 
In Speech, Bush Reiterates Threat Hussein Posed, but Makes No Mention of Weapons Search

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: ELIZABETH, N.J., June 16 

 BODY:
President Bush today swept aside criticism that the United States overstated the threat posed by Iraq as the work of "revisionist historians" and said there was no doubt that Saddam Hussein had been "a threat to the United States" for the past dozen years.
 But in a speech to small-business owners and employees that dwelt largely on the benefits of the recently passed tax cuts, Mr. Bush made no mention of the so-far fruitless search for Mr. Hussein's chemical, nuclear or biological weapons, which he almost never failed to mention in similar speeches when building the case for an invasion of the country earlier this year. 
 "This nation acted to a threat from the dictator of Iraq," Mr. Bush said in a hotel ballroom here. "Now there are some who would like to rewrite history -- revisionist historians is what I like to call them," he said.
He drew applause from a largely Republican, sympathetic crowd when he declared that "Saddam Hussein was a threat to America and the free world in '91, in '98, in 2003."
He cited Mr. Hussein's refusal to abide by the demands "of the free world" and added, "This is for certain: Saddam Hussein is no longer a threat to the United States and our friends and allies."
His decision not to delve into the question of unconventional weapons was notable, because only 11 days ago, addressing American troops in Doha, Qatar, Mr. Bush insisted that his concern about Mr. Hussein's weapons were justified, even while he trimmed back his assertions about what kind of weaponry Mr. Hussein had on hand. At that time, he argued that mobile laboratory trucks found in Iraq showed that the deposed government was "capable of producing biological agents." He did not go that far today.
Mr. Bush's aides insist that he is not backing away from the administration's assertions before the war about the weapons capacity of Mr. Hussein's government, statements that added urgency to his calls for military action. Now, the failure to find such weapons, at least so far, has led to several Congressional inquiries, and sent administration officials to the airwaves to argue that they did not exaggerate the threat.
At the same time, administration officials who said a month ago that they believed that Mr. Hussein was dead are beginning to revise their view, and say now that he may well be alive. In a television interview over the weekend, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Richard B. Myers, said he was leaning toward that view.
Mr. Bush's speech today was a taste of his approach to the early days of his re-election campaign, which begins this week with a series of fund-raising events. At the core of the speech is his contention that he has acted to protect America -- first by toppling the Taliban in Afghanistan, then by toppling Mr. Hussein's government -- and that he is acting simultaneously to protect the economy from a downturn that has so far defied government prescriptions.
Before speaking to the small-business owners today, Mr. Bush visited workers at Andrea Foods in Orange, N.J., watching them stuff pasta for frozen Italian meals. Mr. Bush used his visit to the ravioli production line to promote what he contends will be the job-creating effects of the tax cut he signed into law recently. Among other provisions, it allows businesses to write off $100,000 in new equipment purchases on an accelerated basis.
"We have had one of the shallowest recessions in our nation's history as a result of the tax relief plan," he argued.

HEADLINE: Neighbors Join Critics Of Burmese 

BYLINE:  By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Tuesday, June 17 

 BODY:
Myanmar's Southeast Asian neighbors broke with precedent on Monday to chastise it publicly for its crackdown on dissent and its detention of the pro-democracy leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi.
 Their criticism, at a regional forum here in the Cambodian capital, added to the growing condemnation around the world. 
 Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi has been held in what the government calls protective custody since May 30, when military-backed thugs attacked her convoy as she traveled in northern Myanmar. Scores of people were killed and injured. 
Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, who is leading an American campaign against the crackdown, is scheduled to meet in Phnom Penh on Wednesday with the foreign ministers of the 10 members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, which includes Myanmar, the former Burma.
Emerging from a closed meeting of the ministers on Monday, several participants said the group, known as Asean, had jointly told the Myanmar foreign minister of its concerns. In a further rebuke, they said reference to the issue would be included in a joint statement to be issued today.
The association has in the past held back from criticizing Myanmar, as part of its long-standing policy of noninterference in the affairs of member states. But analysts said the group's silence now, as the world rallies against Myanmar, risked making it appear ineffectual.
"We in Asean are now sharing in accountability to the world about the slow progress of the transition to democracy in Myanmar," said the Philippine foreign secretary, Blas Ople.
S. Jayakumar, the foreign minister of Singapore, said the point was made to the Myanmar foreign minister, U Win Aung, "that the recent developments were a setback not just for Myanmar but also for Asean."
He added: "The ministers urged the Myanmar foreign minister to stay on the course for national reconciliation." That would mean a return to long-stalled talks between the government and Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi and an easing of the current crackdown.
On Sunday, Mr. Win Aung repeated the government's assertion that Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi would be freed but declined to say when.
"Let us not call it detention," he said. "What we would like to say is that for the time being we protect her from personal harm."
He said the government was holding her because of rumors that assassins might try to kill her.
Mr. Powell, who will arrive in Phnom Penh along with senior officials of a dozen nations in the Asean Regional Forum, an Asia-Pacific security group, is expected to lobby for stronger action against Myanmar, which is already the target of economic penalties from a number of nations.
In Washington, Congress is preparing to toughen current American sanctions to add a ban on all imports from Myanmar. The European Union took a similar step on Monday, strengthening its current measures.
Myanmar was one of the last nations to be admitted to Asean, a loose political and economic grouping whose other members are Brunei, Cambodia, Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand and Vietnam. 
Since Myanmar was admitted in 1997, its fellow members have said they could modify its behavior in what they said was a tactful, Asian way, through a policy they called constructive engagement.
For the past three years, a Malaysian diplomat, Razali Ismail, acting as a United Nations envoy, has gently brokered confidence-building talks between the junta and Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi.
In May 2002, she was released from 19 months of house arrest, and the junta promised to begin talking substantively about national issues. Those talks never materialized.
The attack last month and a wave of arrests signaled a return to the tough policies that were in place before Mr. Razali began his visits.
M. C. Abad, the spokesman for the Asean secretariat, said the grouping might have to reassess its policy of noninterference.
"What we would like to happen is a discussion of broadening the interpretation and application of that principle," he said.

HEADLINE: Opening Skies Over the Atlantic 

 BODY:
It may take some time, but air travel across the North Atlantic is likely to improve dramatically -- with more competitive fares and scheduling -- as a result of changes in the way the European Union regulates aviation. The European Court of Justice has rightly decided that it makes little sense for Europe's single economy to retain an airline system that dates from an age when airlines were owned by governments and treated like national symbols.
 The court struck down the old bilateral treaties between the United States and various European nations. The hope now is for an ambitious open-skies treaty that allows airlines to fly wherever and whenever they want, which could bring to trans-Atlantic travelers the same benefits deregulation has conferred on both sides of the Atlantic. 
 Unlike the old treaties that would only apply, say, to KLM from the Netherlands or Lufthansa out of Germany, an arrangement with the European Union could unleash competition. Air France would be allowed to fly between New York and Madrid -- which it cannot do now -- while Alitalia could fly to Los Angeles from Charles de Gaulle. 
America's outdated foreign ownership restrictions will likely remain one of the biggest obstacles to this needed deregulation of trans-Atlantic air travel. Currently, foreign shareholders can control only up to 25 percent of an airline's voting stock. Labor unions have long defended this senseless protectionism, a stance that has gone from being self-interested to self-defeating at a time when the nation's battered airline industry could use an infusion of overseas investment capital.
The Bush administration is rightly pressing Congress to raise the foreign ownership cap to 49 percent of voting shares, bringing our limits more in line with those of other countries. Doing so would strengthen the health of America's transportation infrastructure, and it would help smooth the way toward a desirable air deal with Europe.

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE; 
2 Towers Rise in Chicago Despite Weak Market

BYLINE:  By ROBERT SHAROFF 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, June 17 

 BODY:
Rents are falling, vacancies are rising and the economy remains in the doldrums. Normally, this would not be looked on as the most opportune moment to commence construction of millions of square feet of new downtown office space.
 But that has not deterred two major Chicago developers from starting two high-profile office buildings totaling more than 2.8 million square feet of space. 
 The buildings are the Hyatt Center and 111 South Wacker. The first is being developed by a partnership consisting of the Pritzker family and Higgins Development Partners while the second is being constructed by the John Buck Company. Both buildings broke ground in the last six months with the Hyatt Center expected to be finished in late 2004 and 111 South Wacker in mid-2005. 
In addition, a third developer, Hines Interests of Houston, has announced a tentative starting date later this year for a third high-rise.
Why build now? Why add 2.8 million square feet of space -- 3.6 million if the Hines building is included in the calculations -- to the more than 20 million square feet currently sitting vacant?
"If they were driven by economics," says Stephen Smith, managing director of Jones Lang LaSalle, a large real estate investment and services firm with headquarters here, "none of these buildings would be happening." 
Indeed, the fundamentals of the downtown office market are not very encouraging. The overall vacancy rate -- including space available for sublease -- stands at about 16 percent. Two years ago, the rate was about 10 percent. In addition, the rate is expected to increase to about 18 percent over the next year.
The crucial real estate measure called absorption -- the net of space that has become vacant and space that has been leased in a given period -- is also lagging. "We've had negative absorption for five straight quarters," said John O'Donnell, vice chairman and chief financial officer of John Buck.
And Mr. Smith of Jones Lang LaSalle said, "No one has been able to identify the next tech trend that is going to drive growth." 
A result is that rents are dropping after a run-up in the late 90's when they briefly peaked at just over $30 a square foot a year for Class A space, the most modern in the best locations. 
"Right now, landlords are doing whatever they need to do to lease space," said John Goodman, executive vice president and regional manager for Julien J. Studley Inc., a national tenant representative firm with offices here. 
He added that for Class A space, the current net effective rental rate is $17 to $22 a square foot. "That's where deals are being done," he said. 
The problem is a lack of tenants, at any price. "We've had almost no real growth -- except for bankruptcy firms and law firms -- among typical users," said John F. McKinney, president of JF McKinney & Associates, a large leasing firm that is handling leasing at Hyatt Center.
Paul Beitler, co-developer of Dearborn Center, a new 1.8-million-square- foot building at the corner of Dearborn and Adams Streets, said, "We haven't signed a lease in two years." The building, which was finished earlier this year, is 30 percent vacant, Mr. Beitler said. "Essentially, ever since 9/11, there has been no leasing."
The attacks on the World Trade Center and fears of future terrorism are also having a negative impact on the city's ultimate trophy building, the 110-story Sears Tower, the tallest in the United States. 
"Before 9/11, we had gotten to a point where we were commanding some really strong rates for a Class A building," said Stephen Budorick, senior vice president of New York-based Trizec Properties Inc., which has a controlling interest in the 3.4-million-square-foot building. "Afterwards, we were 25 percent off that."
The building has had several high- profile defectors in recent months, the most notable being Goldman, Sachs & Company. Goldman, which occupies 245,000 square feet on a long-term lease that does not expire until 2011, is leaving for smaller -- about 200,000 square feet -- space at the new Hyatt Center. 
According to Andrea Raphael, a Goldman vice president and spokeswoman, the reasons for the move are strategic. "We wanted to consolidate and get an amount of space that was more efficient for us," she said. 
Trizec Properties -- and much of the local real estate community here -- has a different interpretation. "The factor that put them in the market," Mr. Budorick said, "is 9/11."
Whatever the reason, Goldman's decision reflects the leasing strategy of the new buildings, which is to entice existing downtown companies to leave their current space with promises of being in new, technologically up-to-date buildings on one of Chicago's premier business streets. Wacker Drive, home to the Hyatt Center and 111 South Wacker, as well as the Sears Tower, is a broad boulevard that parallels the Chicago River on the north and west sides of the Loop business district. 
Over the last decade, as development has spread west, Wacker has challenged LaSalle Street as the city's financial center of gravity.
"This project was driven by the tenants," said Penny Pritzker, chief executive of the Pritzker Realty Group, a family-owned company. "It wasn't driven by us saying we want to go out and build a building today."
Mr. O'Donnell of the John Buck Company, the developer of 111 South Wacker, said, "We're 42.5 percent leased and are currently talking to three other tenants that will take it to 75 percent." 
Hyatt Center's anchor tenants are the Pritzker-owned Hyatt Corporation; Goldman Sachs; and the law firm of Mayer, Brown, Rowe & Maw. The three will occupy two-thirds of the building's 1.8 million square feet. 
The 1.1-million-square-foot 111 South Wacker will be anchored by the accounting firm of Deloitte & Touche, which is taking 425,000 square feet.
Both developers say they are asking for, and receiving, rents in the mid to upper $20's. "The size of our floors and the technological advantages we have to offer are enough to offset the rental differentiation," Mr. McKinney said.
Another factor developers are capitalizing on is the shortage of large blocks of space in the downtown market. "We use a lot of space," said Debora de Hoyos, managing partner of Mayer, Brown, Rowe & Maw, which is now in a 1980s-vintage high-rise on LaSalle Street. "And when you get close to 500,000 square feet, there's very few blocks of space to choose from."
Both projects promise to be striking additions to the local skyline. After a long trend toward retro-styled stone-and-concrete buildings, Chicago is returning to its modernist roots. Hyatt Center, designed by the New York-based architecture firm of Pei Cobb Freed at a cost of $425 million, is a dramatic ellipse-shaped steel-and-glass structure. As for 111 South Wacker, it has a lower price tag -- in excess of $260 million -- and is a more traditional glass box. The building's architect is Lohan Caprile Goettsch, a local firm.
In addition, a third new building, 1 South Dearborn, by Hines Interests of Houston, appears likely. That building, a 40-story, 825,000-square-foot tower designed by the Chicago-based DeStefano Keating Partners Ltd., has a tentative starting date of Dec. 1. 
"Somewhere between 50 and 60 percent leased is where you need to get to start building," said Greg Van Schaack, vice president of Hines Interests. "We're close" 
The good news so far is that interest rates remain low enough that developers are able to carry buildings with significant vacancy levels for longer periods of time without the threat of foreclosure from lenders. 
Real estate executives are also careful to draw a distinction between the current downturn and the one that occurred a decade ago. "In the early 90's," said Sam Zell, chairman of Equity Office Properties, a publicly owned real estate investment trust in Chicago, "you had five or six empty buildings just standing there. That's a lot different than starting buildings today in hopes of filling them two or three years from now."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Aforecaster lowers his projection for 2003 ad spending, but says it will break a record, barely.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
TURNS out the bowl of cherries that greeted analysts and reporters as they gathered yesterday to hear a revised prediction of advertising spending from the dean of Madison Avenue forecasters was not a leading indicator.
 Instead, the forecaster, Robert J. Coen, who has been tracking ad trends since the Truman administration, revised downward his prediction for American ad spending this year at a presentation in Midtown Manhattan. The change, attributed partly to sluggish interest from local advertisers in certain media outlets, including newspapers, was the second time in six months that Mr. Coen, senior vice president and forecasting director at Universal McCann in New York, had reduced his estimate for 2003. 
 Mr. Coen's predictions are closely watched because of his involvement in forecasting since 1948. He issues his predictions twice a year, in June or July and in December. 
Mr. Coen's new forecast for 2003 is for a gain of 4.6 percent from the $236.9 billion that is his final figure for ad spending last year. That compares with the 5 percent increase Mr. Coen predicted at a presentation in December. In July 2002, when he offered his first look at 2003, Mr. Coen forecast a gain of 5.5 percent from 2002.
The 2002 result represented a slim 2.4 percent increase from 2001, coming in slightly below an earlier estimate of a 2.6 percent gain.
"It was not a great year," Mr. Coen said, "but it was a lot better than the 6.5 percent decline in 2001" compared with 2000. That decline was the first since 1991 and the largest since 1938.
Mr. Coen's refiguring of his numbers for 2003 came soon after several Wall Street analysts slightly rejiggered their forecasts, some adjusting a bit upward and others adjusting a bit downward.
For instance, Lauren Rich Fine of Merrill Lynch lowered her estimate of ad spending growth this year to 3.3 percent from 3.7 percent, while David Doft of CIBC World Markets increased his estimate to 3.3 percent from 3.1 percent. And the entertainment and media practice of PricewaterhouseCoopers decided to stand pat, reaffirming this week a forecast made last year for 3 percent growth in 2003.
While Mr. Coen's predictions have tended to be a bit more optimistic than those of other forecasters and Wall Street analysts, his forecasts during the boom years 1998-2000 were a little less rosy than the actual results. Also, Mr. Coen was one of a handful of forecasters to predict that ad spending last year would increase from 2001.
The consensus among forecasters, including Mr. Coen, for 2003 calls for a gradual improvement in ad spending, which is closely watched as a harbinger of how the overall economy is faring. As a result, the news from Mr. Coen was not all gloom and doom, so perhaps half a bowl of cherries might have been more appropriate.
The total amount of ad spending in the United States expected this year by Mr. Coen, $247.7 billion, would exceed the previous record of $247.5 billion, set in 2000, even if the rate of growth is slower than had been hoped.
Also, Mr. Coen said he saw better results coming in the second half of the year, with the last six months on track for a gathering recovery that will accelerate in 2004 because "much better things for the economy seem to be ahead."
Mr. Coen attributed the downward adjustment to his previous estimates to somewhat weaker results than expected for the first half, caused by the sputtering economy.
"The trends were not quite as robust as they looked in December," Mr. Coen said, "so we're a little more cautious."
"There will be a little less growth in the first half," he added, "but a return to strong growth in the second half."
One reason for the drag on growth, Mr. Coen said, was the war in Iraq, and the buildup to it.
"It had more effect before it happened than probably while it was on," he said, referring to the decisions by many advertisers to postpone or cancel campaigns before the initial attack.
Alan J. Gottesman, an analyst at West End Communications/Consulting in New York who attended the presentation, summarized Mr. Coen's point succinctly.
"It was, 'We interrupt this recovery to bring you this war,' " Mr. Gottesman said, "and once the war was over, the recovery was back on track."
Another reason for the slower growth, Mr. Coen said, is a disparity between demand for commercial time and ad space on the local and national levels.
For example, newspaper classified advertising is still down, he said, adding, "It's a tough year." Demand for ad space in local media outlets from retailers is down because of a slowdown in sales.
As a result, Mr. Coen has knocked a full percentage point off his estimate from December of growth in spending in local media outlets, lowering it to 3.5 percent from 4.5 percent. He called the trimming "a fairly significant reduction."
The variance between the local and national media can be seen in other categories. For instance, Mr. Coen is predicting that ad spending this year will increase on local television by 2.5 percent, in local newspapers by 3.5 percent and on local radio by 4 percent.
By comparison, his forecasts for the national counterparts of those media outlets are more robust: up 4.7 percent for television, 5.5 percent for newspapers and 4.2 percent for radio.
Mr. Coen also predicted better results for other national media, including magazines, up 7 percent; direct mail, up 6.5 percent; and the Internet, up 5 percent.
Analysts, including several who attended Mr. Coen's presentation, echoed his revamped outlook.
"The economy in the first half has not been what people thought," said Mr. Doft of CIBC, "but the second-half strength is still expected."
"There are definitely some good spending categories out there," he said. What investors will be "looking at is the auto category," he said, "which will be a big determinant of where the year is." Automakers, which typically spend more each year than any other advertising group, may be rethinking their ad plans as consumers send mixed signals about their intent to buy more cars, trucks and minivans.
Leland Westerfield, a managing director at Jefferies & Company, said: "We're making up for lost time if 2003 recaptures the height reached in the 2000 peak. But this time, we'd be on firmer ground because it would be built on steadier marketing categories than last time, when so much of the spending came from the dot-coms."
Fueling the gains in the second half, Mr. Coen said, will be national spending by major marketers like the automakers, movie studios, restaurant chains and sellers of cosmetics, drugs, food and toiletries. Those increases will, he predicted, offset spending cutbacks in categories like airlines, brokerage firms and mutual funds, insurance, resorts, telecommunications and tours.
For 2004, Mr. Coen offered an initial forecast for a gain of 5.6 percent from 2003. If that happens, it will be the largest percentage gain since 2000, a year when ad spending was stimulated by a summer Olympics and a presidential election.
By comparison, Ms. Fine at Merrill Lynch has revised upward her estimate of ad spending growth in 2004 to 6.2 percent from 6 percent, while PricewaterhouseCoopers cut its estimate to 6.3 percent from 7.3 percent. In his first forecast for 2004, Mr. Doft of CIBC is predicting a gain of 5.8 percent.
Turning to ad spending overseas, Mr. Coen predicted 2003 would end with a total of $222.1 billion, up 4 percent from his revised final figure of $213.6 billion in 2002. His initial forecast for 2004 is for an increase of 4.5 percent from 2003 to $232.1 billion.
Among countries expected to outpace others in ad spending growth this year, Mr. Coen listed China, India, Indonesia, Mexico, the Philippines and South Korea, which would compensate for smaller gains in larger markets like Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Japan.
Thus, the Coen estimated total for worldwide ad spending this year is now $469.8 billion, an increase of 4.3 percent from $450.5 billion in 2002. His estimate for 2004 is $495.9 billion, up 5.6 percent from 2003.
The bowl of cherries was placed on the table in front of the conference room in which Mr. Coen made his presentation, at the headquarters of the Universal McCann parent, the McCann-Erickson World Group. It was the first time in many years that Mr. Coen's midyear presentation had not taken place at the University Club.
Some attendees joked that McCann-Erickson, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, the struggling agency company, had changed sites to save the rent. Mr. Coen joked that the real savings would be derived from not having to take taxicabs between the University Club and his office.

HEADLINE: Consumer Prices Rose in May, Easing Worries on Deflation 

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Consumer prices, excluding food and energy, had their biggest increase in nine months in May, the government reported yesterday, easing concern that deflation might sap the economic recovery.
 The core Consumer Price Index rose 0.3 percent, three times the median forecast, after holding steady in each of the previous two months. The Labor Department said the overall index was unchanged in May, tempered by a drop in energy prices, after falling 0.3 percent in April. 
 Industrial production increased in May for the first time since February, and housing starts rose, separate reports showed, supporting forecasts of faster growth in the second half of the year.
The figures may reduce pressure on the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed Reserve policy panel, to cut its benchmark interest rate by a half-point next week to help avoid a broad decline in prices.
"The economy is not rushing headlong toward a deflationary environment that would push the F.O.M.C. to become extremely aggressive," said Joel Naroff, the president of Naroff Economic Advisors, in Holland, Pa. 
Production at factories, mines and utilities rose 0.1 percent last month after falling 0.6 percent in April, the Federal Reserve said in Washington. The proportion of industrial capacity in use held at 74.3 percent, the lowest since June 1983.
Economists had expected a 0.1 percent decrease in the Consumer Price Index. Core prices had been forecast to rise 0.1 percent.
Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, said this month that central bankers were concerned about "corrosive deflation," a general decline in prices that feeds on itself.
Jade Zelnik, the chief economist at RBS Greenwich Capital in Connecticut, said: "This should prove somewhat reassuring to Fed officials, helping to reinforce the view that outright deflation remains a remote possibility. However, the May C.P.I. results are unlikely to affect Fed officials' determination to cut rates at their upcoming meeting in order to prevent additional economic slack from developing."
Since November, Fed policy makers have held the benchmark rate on overnight loans between banks at 1.25 percent, the lowest since 1961.
Core prices were up 1.6 percent over the last 12 months, compared with a 1.5 percent increase in the year ended in April, the lowest since March 1966. Core prices so far this year have risen at a 1.1 percent annual pace, down from 2.1 percent in the first five months of last year.
Demand for housing remained strong in May, the Commerce Department report showed, aided by the lowest mortgage rates on record. Builders broke ground on 1.7 million homes at an annual pace last month, up 6.1 percent from April, the Commerce Department said. Construction was completed on 1.8 million housing units at an annual rate, the most since January 1987.

HEADLINE: Hints of Upturn Begin to Ease Gloom at Ban ks And Businesses 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN 

 BODY:
To economists, the message from the last two years of economic weakness has been clear: It's the business sector, stupid.
 Consumershave kept up their spending, thanks to low interest rates on credit cards and mortgages. But the nation's job losses are unlikely to be reversed, economists say, until companies have the confidence to grow. 
 By one indicator -- changes in banks' commercial lending -- that is said to be a favorite of Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, confidence may be starting to take hold. The overall trend in net lending -- new loans minus repayments -- has been dipping for more than two years. Yet, a change of direction in the demand for loans seems to be under way. 
"There's a cautious optimism," said Todd C. Moules, executive vice president for corporate banking at the National City Corporation. "There are people who have a vision of when they expect things to come back. They're seeing signs of improvement."
Six months ago, Mr. Moules said, his clients had no such hopes. Yet some recent data on the economy has suggested that better times are on the way for businesses.
Yesterday, the Fed reported that industrial production edged up 0.1 percent in May, exceeding analysts' expectations. The utilization of industrial capacity was unchanged from a revised April figure of 74.3 percent. 
The Commerce Department reported that housing starts rose by 6.1 percent in May on a seasonally adjusted basis, with permits for future construction increasing 3.7 percent. 
Together, the promising news, based on market interest rates, seems to have led investors to expect just a quarter-point cut in interest rates, rather than a half-point, by the Federal Reserve next week.
In commercial banking, hopeful signs could not come soon enough. Even as businesses have cut back in the face of higher spending by consumers, commercial lending has wilted while mortgages and credit card debt have bloomed.
Commercial and industrial loans held by the biggest banks, those classified by the Federal Reserve as those with $300 million or more in assets, have dropped steadily since March 2001 -- the month the most recent recession began, according to the National Bureau of Economic Research. The previous recession began in July 1990 -- about a month after the big banks' commercial and industrial loans started a downward slide.
A combination of factors has contributed to the drop over the last two years, said Richard A. Higginbotham, executive vice president and managing director of national commercial financial services at FleetBoston Financial.
"Spending for capital equipment and software has really been in a decline," he said. "That has been very marked, especially in the last year and a half. One of the other drivers has been less vibrant merger and acquisition activity in the U.S." Many fewer companies, he added, "are being bought and sold."
"Working capital has, in many companies, shrunk over the last couple of years," Mr. Higginbotham said, "to very low levels. Companies have become very efficient."
Large businesses have also taken advantage of low interest rates to pursue long-term financing outside banks, said John W. Clay Jr., vice chairman of SunTrust Banks in Atlanta. "The large public companies have all, to the extent that they have the ability to do so, taken advantage of the public debt markets," he said. "They've built liquidity, and they just don't need a lot of short-term bank access right now."
Mr. Higginbotham said that some banks had become more selective about their clients, trying to aim lending at those who might buy several types of financial services. 
"All of these have really added together to provide not only a sluggish demand in bank lending but a shrinking market in terms of actual usage," he said.
Though plunges in commercial and industrial loans may coincide with the beginning of recessions, the economy has typically resumed strong growth before loan activity picks up, said Ian C. Shepherdson, chief United States economist at High Frequency Economics. Increases in growth, he said, could speed repayment of old loans as well as new lending, so a recovery in net loans -- the figures kept by the Federal Reserve -- would lag behind an upturn in the economic cycle.
Indeed, loans did not start to recover from their last decline until early 1994, well after the economy had returned to a reasonable pace of growth. But Mr. Shepherdson said that banks' pronouncements about demand for new loans could hint at a turnaround soon in the economy.
"I normally ignore anecdotes," he said. But in this case, "the banks might actually be saying something interesting." Because the biggest banks hold such a large share of the total loan market, he said, their new loans could signal an acceleration in economic growth. According to Fed listings, the top 10 banks have more than 40 percent of the domestic assets of the next 1,300 banks combined.
SunTrust has recently had modest growth in loans, Mr. Clay said, largely from small and medium-size businesses. Because they cannot avail themselves of the securities markets for financing, they have continued to rely on banks for moderate capital spending, working capital and financing of inventories.
"The market is very bifurcated," Mr. Clay said. "In the middle market and the smaller end of the market, business conditions are very good, and our loan demand is strong." But he warned that employment would not pick up until companies began to invest more in new equipment and plants.
Mr. Higginbotham said he had already seen some strengthening in loans intended to finance equipment, an area, he said, where there was considerable pent-up demand.
"We finance a lot of equipment through our leasing company," he said, "either by directly calling on users or purchasers of equipment, or by providing financing to the manufacturer's sales force. That business has had two good months now."
In addition, he said, more companies are being bought and sold. "People are coming to grips with what the market thinks valuations are," Mr. Higginbotham said. "A number of investment shops are putting up for sale companies they own, to rebalance their portfolio or to give a return to investors."
Over all, Mr. Moules said, the demand for loans is increasing as businesses go ahead with projects delayed by the Iraq war, as well as more recent plans.
That change in fortunes may be showing up in the big banks' share prices. From March 12 -- about a week before the start of attacks on Iraq -- and yesterday's close, the Philadelphia Stock Exchange's index of 24 leading banks rose 36 percent, compared with 28 percent for the Standard & Poor's 500.
Mr. Shepherdson said that increased spending on equipment would be one of the first steps back toward new hiring by businesses. For the economy to maintain momentum, though, there can be no strong economic shocks.
"In the second half of last year, capital spending by businesses rose reasonably quickly," he said. "The only reason they stopped in the first quarter of this year was the war."
If economic prospects brighten considerably in the second half of the year, long-term interest rates would probably rise as investors anticipated an increase in short-term rates. Large companies might then return to banks to finance their capital spending, Mr. Clay said.
"Once interest rates turn up, that will effectively signal the end of the rush to the public debt markets," he said. "We really could get a very nice lift when some of this excess liquidity burns off."
Mr. Shepherdson sees the economy poised at sunrise. "If I draw a piece of paper with the numbers I've been looking for to signal a recovery," he said, "most of them have been falling into place. This is it. This is the turning point."

HEADLINE: Calpers to Vote on New Health Care Rates 

BYLINE:  By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
The California Public Employees' Retirement System is expected to approve a big increase today in premiums for its 900,000 members insured by health maintenance organizations.
 The increase, of just over 18 percent for most, will be shared between employers and members; it is well below the 25.1 percent increase for 2003. 
 Rates at the California system, which plans to spend $3.3 billion this year on medical coverage, are widely viewed as an early indicator of national inflation rates in health care. But Wall Street analysts said industrywide increases for large private employers would be lower, 12 percent, on average, in 2004, compared with 14 percent in 2003. 
Of the 1.3 million state and school employees covered by the system, known as Calpers, 70 percent are members of H.M.O.'s. Two nonprofit H.M.O.'s, Blue Shield of California and Kaiser Permanente, are the system's main insurers. Calpers dropped H.M.O.'s operated by Health Net and PacifiCare last year, after they held out for 30 percent increases. Blue Cross of California, a unit of WellPoint Health Networks, administers a preferred provider network for the system.
Clark McKinley, a Calpers spokesman, said it had pared the increase by $385 million in negotiations. He said the H.M.O.'s initially sought increases averaging 31 percent. About a third of the reduction resulted from a multiyear contract with Blue Shield, reducing the number of H.M.O. companies to three from five, and delaying negotiations until the system could obtain recent information on actual spending, Mr. McKinley said. 
The Calpers staff recommended the 18.4 percent increase for Blue Shield, with 460,000 members, and 18.2 percent for the 422,000 members covered by Kaiser, Mr. McKinley said. Western Health Advantage, a small nonprofit health plan based in Sacramento, would raise rates 34.5 percent.
The system's rates "tend to be higher than those of other employee-based purchasers because our members are older, have a greater proportion of chronic health conditions, with higher utilization of hospitals, doctors and prescription drugs," Mr. McKinley said. 
"Calpers continues to offer a richer benefit than most private sector employees," said Matthew Borsch, a health care securities analyst at Goldman, Sachs. Charles Boorady, an analyst at Smith Barney, noted that many Calpers members were in unions that had resisted reductions in employer-paid benefits.
Calpers says it is the nation's third-largest purchaser of employee health benefits, after the Federal Employees Health Benefit Program and General Motors.

HEADLINE: Camera Verite; 
A Peek Through Blue-Collar Lenses

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY DePALMA 

 BODY:
In the vast convoy of vehicles that rumble through New York every day, Zu Rong Li's delivery truck is indistinguishable from the rest until he pulls to a curb and leaves the engine running and the driver's seat empty while he takes a photograph.
 Mr. Li stops his truck where others rarely stop, to shoot pictures of things others rarely see: beneath a bridge he saw a long row of columns that he considered an image of continuity and friendship; he stopped by the old Brooklyn Army Terminal one day to photograph a single railroad tanker car that suggested the history of power and war; and the American flag reflecting on a shiny wall made him stop because it seemed such a glorious symbol of freedom. 
 Mr. Li is the first to say he is no professional photographer. He insists he is a truck driver, nothing more. But over the last three months, he and a handful of other workers have been learning how to document their daily working lives, which by and large unfold invisibly against the backdrop of corporate New York. 
They are part of a project called Unseen America, which lends cameras to people society often overlooks, coaches them in the art of taking pictures that tell stories and then professionally exhibits their photographs in a gallery.
Esther Cohen, executive director of Bread and Roses, the cultural arm of 1199 of the Service Employees International Union, started Unseen America in 2000 to shed light on problems in health care, housing, education and employment.
"By making the issues of the lives of the working class visible, we can come close to resolving some of those issues," Ms. Cohen said.
Through the lenses of about 100 donated point-and-shoot 35-millimeter cameras, people can fill in the blank spots of their lives. Ms. Cohen said that when cameras were given to a group of homeless people, some of them shot houses and apartment buildings "because that is what they never had." And a Chinese garment worker recently explained that taking photographs of her life made her feel "like a frog that jumped out of a well."
These photographs can remind the rest of the city, and the nation, that the majority of Americans still belong to the working class.
"We have images of the working class trudging off to the factory carrying their lunch pails, or sitting on I-beams dangling in the sky," said Michael Zweig, a professor of economics at the State University of New York at Stony Brook and director of the Center for Study of Working Class Life. "Because that's not the way working-class people look now, people tend to think that workers have disappeared, but they have not."
In previous Unseen America projects, including one on Long Island that Professor Zweig's center supported, Mexican migrant workers and Polish asbestos-removal workers took photos of their lives. A Mexican woman photographed ordinary chairs because she spends most of her working day on her feet and sitting is only a dream.
"The whole idea of these images and this process is to really allow and to encourage the humanity and creative impulse of working people to come out," said Professor Zweig, who in his recent book, "The Working Class Majority" calculated that 62 percent of the American labor force belongs to the working class, a group defined not by how much its members make but by their lack of independence on the job. In the New York metropolitan region, Professor Zweig found that 63 percent of the labor force can be classified as working class.
While working-class people are still a majority, they do not have the political influence their predecessors had after World War II, when unions built their own housing projects, like East River Houses, and ran their own health clinics. Today's working class is far less likely to be unionized, Professor Zweig said, and organized labor has lost much of its political power.
Ms. Cohen recently organized a series of Unseen America photography classes that brought together about a dozen Chinese garment workers and a dozen elderly Jewish men and women, including some whose parents had worked in the garment industry years ago.
"Each culture had different ideas about what is an appropriate image to photograph," Ms. Cohen said. The Chinese workers were reluctant to take pictures of anything but happy moments, she said, and the Jewish seniors were more accustomed to expressing themselves in words than in images. Two professional photographers, Matthew Septimus and Teddy Fung, taught the class on the Lower East Side, and Mr. Fung translated.
While most of the students had owned cameras, the idea of shooting photographs of their day-to-day lives was foreign.
"You have to go out, be bold," Mr. Septimus encouraged his students.
Mr. Fung told them, "When you take a picture, don't close your mind."
Ping Lam, a cutter in a garment factory, said he was reluctant to take pictures at work because he didn't know whether his supervisors would object, a common concern in the group. So he quietly photographed only people working near him, taking black-and-white snapshots of women cutting bolts of cloth and a master stitcher attaching trim pieces by hand.
"When I work hard I want to remember it," said Mr. Lam, 40, who went to work at the factory soon after arriving in New York from Hong Kong 13 years ago. Mr. Lam said he also thought that if others saw what it was really like in the factory, they would better understand how Chinese workers lived.
As the classes went on through the spring, many Jewish students stopped coming, but those who continued were focused on their work. Adriana Paulian, who said she was "39 plus 39," came to the United States from Romania about 12 years ago. She took a picture of a vest-pocket park on Delancey Street that made it look like a rain forest. "It was a little piece of paradise in the middle of a very busy, very noisy area," she said. 
Then there was Mr. Li, 52, the truck driver, who came to New York from China seven years ago. He photographed the entire process of making clothing, starting with cutters, then seamstresses and pressers and finally packers.
Mr. Li said he was especially impressed by the fact that his company makes military uniforms. When his truck is filled with the uniforms, all pressed and wrapped in plastic, their creases sharp and their buttons gleaming, he said, he no longer feels invisible. 
"When I carry them in my truck," he said, "I think I am doing something important for this country, and I feel good."
A selection of the photographs will be exhibited at the Bread and Roses Gallery at 310 West 43rd Street in Midtown Manhattan starting on Labor Day.

Ping Lam, a cutter in a garment factory, took a picture of a woman working on clothing.; Matthew Septimus, center left, flanked by Adriana Paulian and Zu Rong Li. Mr. Septimus is teaching a class of workers to document their working lives for the Unseen America project. (Dith Pran/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Coke Confirms Product Test Was Rigged 

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DAY 

 BODY:
Coca-Cola acknowledged yesterday that employees manipulated the results of a market test of Frozen Coke at Burger King restaurants, confirming one of the accusations raised by a former executive who has sued the company.
 Burger King, a major Coke customer, said it was disappointed by Coke's conduct and was conducting its own review. Coke, meanwhile, disclosed that the Securities and Exchange Commission had issued an informal request for documents regarding the executive's assertions. 
 Coke's audit committee, which began investigating the complaints by the former executive, Matthew Whitley, in May, also found that the company's fountain division had improperly valued some equipment. Coke said it would take a $9 million pretax write-down to correct the error, resulting in a reduction in second-quarter earnings of 0.25 cent a share, which it called insignificant. 
But the committee, whose members include the financier Warren E. Buffett and the Home Depot chief executive Robert L. Nardelli, said it had found no evidence to support Mr. Whitley's accusations that Coke had discriminated against minorities or women and said there was no evidence that the fountain division had improperly shifted revenue to a project to develop a new beverage dispensing system last year.
Mr. Whitley, a former finance director in the fountain division, sued Coke in May for $44.4 million in damages. His lawsuit says that the unit engaged in $2 billion in accounting fraud, created slush funds and manipulated its inventories.
Coke did not respond to all of Mr. Whitley's assertions yesterday. In a memo to employees, Douglas N. Daft, the chairman and chief executive, said that Coke took accusations of inappropriate conduct seriously and would take corrective action when employees' conduct was inappropriate. He also said it would vigorously defend itself in court.
Investors knocked $1, or 2 percent, off the price of Coca-Cola shares yesterday; the stock closed at $47.20 on the New York Stock Exchange.
Coke officials have described Mr. Whitley as a disgruntled former employee who threatened to take his charges to the news media if he was not paid. Mr. Whitley, an 11-year employee of Coke, was laid off earlier this year when the company imposed 1,000 job cuts in its North American units.
In his lawsuit, filed in Fulton County Superior Court in Atlanta, where Coke is based, Mr. Whitley says that members of the Burger King account team at Coca-Cola persuaded Burger King to run a three-week test of Coke's frozen carbonated beverages in restaurants in Richmond, Va., in 2000. Coke's marketing plan was to offer customers a coupon for a free frozen drink with the purchase of a value meal, in hopes of increasing traffic at Burger King and persuading the fast-food company to invest more heavily in the frozen beverages and extend the promotion nationally. 
When the tests appeared to be going poorly, Coke officials paid $10,000 to a Virginia man to take hundreds of children to Burger King to buy value meals, according to the lawsuit.
Coke officials, who did not dispute the details of the Virginia promotion, said yesterday that the employees involved were disciplined in 2001. But it denied Mr. Whitley's assertion that it used the beverage promotion to try to influence Burger King's thinking about expanding the promotion. Rather, it said, Burger King had already introduced Frozen Coke in 1999 in more than 75 percent of its restaurants, based on market tests in other cities a year earlier.
Steven J. Heyer, Coke's president, sent a letter yesterday apologizing to Bradley D. Blum, the chief executive of Burger King. "These actions were wrong and inconsistent with the values of the Coca-Cola Company," it said.
Marc Garber, Mr. Whitley's lawyer, said yesterday's disclosure proved that his client's accusations were on target. "My client has been vindicated in good measure," said Mr. Garber, adding that Mr. Whitley intended to go forward with the lawsuit. "Coke had this information almost six months ago; it wasn't until they were confronted by the possibility of a lawsuit that they decided to investigate," he said.

HEADLINE: Boston Archdiocese, Hurting Financially, Warns of Layoffs 

BYLINE:  By FOX BUTTERFIELD 

DATELINE: BOSTON, June 17 

 BODY:
Underscoring the financial difficulty facing the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston as a result of the sexual abuse scandal in the clergy and a sagging economy, Bishop Richard G. Lennon warned his parish priests today that because almost 100 churches were withholding money from the archdiocese, he would order them to start laying off employees or cut their health benefits.
 Bishop Lennon, who took over as the interim administrator of the archdiocese after Cardinal Bernard F. Law resigned in December, told the priests that "this may well be painful for some," but that the archdiocese had to bring its costs and resources into balance. 
 The shortfall averages about $15,000 a parish, the Rev. Christopher Coyne, a spokesman for the archdiocese, said. It now amounts to a $9.4 million budget gap. 
The money is supposed to be paid by Boston's 360 parishes into a central trust fund and then returned by the archdiocese to help individual churches pay for the pension benefits and health insurance of its lay employees and the insurance costs for its buildings, Father Coyne said.
"We just don't have the available funds to make these payments," he said.
If the 100 parishes do not start making payments by July 1, Father Coyne said, Bishop Lennon will send out a "letter of termination," meaning the lay employees could lose their health insurance, their jobs or both.
The 360 parishes employ about 9,000 laypeople, including teachers.
About 300 representatives of the parishes attended the meeting today with Bishop Lennon. The warning about terminating lay employees is only the latest sign of financial and morale problems in the archdiocese. 
Father Coyne said the archdiocese had raised only $4.5 million of a projected $9 million annual giving campaign that is crucial to operating its schools and charities in Boston. Last year, before the scandal became public, the goal for the annual campaign was $17.4 million.
Moreover, an ambitious capital campaign started by Cardinal Law to raise $300 million is now likely to fall $100 million short, church officials here said.
The archdiocese's budget this year has been cut by 20 percent, following a 30 percent reduction last year. 
In 2002 alone, the number of active priests fell by 10 percent, caused mostly by the removal of those accused of sexually molesting minors. That leaves the Boston archdiocese with 505 priests, according to the archdiocesan directory, down from 1,072 priests two decades ago. 
Even these figures do not fully describe the troubles facing the Boston Archdiocese. For example, each parish is also supposed to contribute 1 percent of its weekly offerings to the Boston headquarters, in what is known as the cathedraticum, an amount that can reach anywhere from $3,000 to $9,000 a year. 
But many priests say they have stopped sending their weekly offerings to protest how the church hierarchy handled the sexual abuse scandals and out of concern that the money will be used to pay legal settlements.
The Rev. Bernard P. McLaughlin, pastor of the St. Gerard Majella parish in Canton, a southern suburb, said he had not sent his share of offerings in two years.
"We're in good shape here," Father McLaughlin said. "The reason, I think, is that people here are happy and they are giving."
If his parishioners thought the money was going to the archdiocese, he said, "they would back off." 
Father McLaughlin was invited to today's meeting with Bishop Lennon but did not attend.

HEADLINE: G.E. Union Cites Deal to Curb Workers' Share of Health Costs 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

 BODY:
With details of a tentative agreement beginning to emerge, the president of General Electric's largest labor union said yesterday that it had achieved its goal of ensuring that workers would not shoulder a higher percentage of company health costs.
 Ed Fire, the union's president, said that at the end of the four-year deal, G.E.'s 17,000 unionized workers would continue to pay, as they pay now, 18 percent of company health costs. "We held the line on a critical issue," said Mr. Fire, president of the International Union of Electronic Workers-Communications Workers of America. 
 Before talks began in May, the company said its goal was to have workers shoulder 30 percent of overall health costs. One G.E. official said yesterday that workers would pay 18 percent of health care costs at the end of the proposed contract, although in the second year that would temporarily climb to 19 percent.
Shortly before a Monday morning strike deadline, G.E. reached agreement with Mr. Fire's union as well as with the United Electrical Radio and Machine Workers of America.
Early in the talks, executives at G.E., based in Fairfield, Conn., argued that it was only fair for workers to absorb more of the health costs because the company's health bill soared to $1.4 billion last year, from $965 million in 1999, a 45 percent increase. The cost of health care per worker will rise to $6,500 this year, from $4,140 in 1999, the company said.
But union officials asserted that the workers should not pay a higher percentage of health costs because General Electric, one of the world's most profitable companies, earned more than $45,000 in profits per employee last year.
"The agreements provide good wages, pensions and benefits to G.E. workers while allowing our business to compete in tough markets," said William J. Conaty, G.E.'s senior vice president for human resources. "We faced difficult issues -- a challenging economy and rising health care costs -- but everyone at the table remained focused on doing the right thing for our employees and G.E."
The agreement calls for a 3 percent raise in the first year, 2.5 percent in years two and three, and 3 percent in year four. With the typical G.E. union member earning $21.70 an hour, a union flier said that at the end of four years, that union member's pay would rise by $3.52 an hour, including cost-of-living adjustments.
Other unions and companies were looking to the General Electric talks to see what pattern it would set because many companies, facing skyrocketing health costs, were pressuring their unions to shoulder a higher percentage of health outlays.
Echoing Mr. Fire, the United Automobile Workers said yesterday that it would oppose any efforts by the Big Three to shift more health care costs to their 292,000 auto workers.
Ron Gettelfinger, the union's president, said at a Detroit news conference that his union would not agree to such cost shifting in contract talks next month with General Motors, Ford and DaimlerChrysler. The companies' four-year contracts expire on Sept. 14. 
G.E. and Mr. Fire said that while the percentage workers contributed to health costs would remain the same, employee payments for health premiums would rise during the contract, with G.E. predicting that its health costs would rise by at least 30 percent over the four-year contract. The union's delegates are to vote on the contract today, with members of individual locals scheduled to vote early next week.
In a flier sent to union members, the International Union of Electronic Workers said that the settlement would cost the company $1.7 billion over four years and that the typical worker would receive $15,272 more in net pay over four years, after accounting for higher health outlays.
"Small premium increases for members and their families will be more than offset by a wage and cost-of-living package that is considerably higher than other recent national contract settlements," the flier said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
HBO to Bring 'Sopranos' Back for a Sixth Season
"The Sopranos," the most successful series in the history of cable television, will not end with its fifth season but will instead have one more season, with 10 episodes, according to an executive producer, Brad Grey.
 "Sopranos" will now end with 75 episodes, enough for a potential sale in syndication, which would likely be the biggest in the history of cable. Page C2. 

Net Loss Narrows at Vivendi
Vivendi Universal announced lower operating profit for its Vivendi Universal Entertainment unit and a decline in both revenue and operating income for the Universal Music Group. It plans to accept formal bids for the American entertainment assets on Monday. Over all, the company, which uses French accounting standards, said that it had narrowed its net loss for the first quarter. Market Place. C12.

F.D.A. Approves New Flu Vaccine
The Food and Drug Administration approved a flu vaccine that is squirted up the nose rather than injected into an arm. MedImmune and Wyeth, the developers of the vaccine, said they would spend $50 million in the coming flu season on advertising and marketing. C4.

Calpers to Raise H.M.O. Premiums
The California Public Employees' Retirement System is expected to approve a big increase today in premiums for its 900,000 members insured by health maintenance organizations. Still, the 18.4 percent raise is well below the 25.1 percent increase for 2003. C2.

A group of large employers announced a campaign to encourage overweight workers to slim down as a way to improve their personal health and the corporate bottom line. C2.

G.E. Union Claims Victory in Pact
With details of a tentative four-year contract agreement beginning to emerge, the president of General Electric's largest labor union said it had achieved its goal of ensuring that G.E. workers would not shoulder a higher percentage of company health costs. A18.

The former chairman of Ullico refused to testify before a Congressional committee investigating accusations that the insurer's board members earned more than $6 million through insider trading. A19.

U.S. Rules on Unfair Competition
The Bush administration ruled that United States computer chip makers and catfish farmers were subjected to unfair foreign competition and ordered stiff tariffs on imports of South Korean computer chips and Vietnamese catfish. C4.

GaugesReach Highs for the Year
Stocks rose slightly, with major market gauges posting their highest closes so far this year. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 4.06 points, to 9,323.02, its highest close in about 11 months. The S.& P. 500 gained 0.92 point, to 1,011.66. The Nasdaq composite index added 1.86 points, or 0.1 percent, to 1,668.44. C12.

Creditors Approve SK Global Bailout
Creditors of SK Global, the troubled trading company in South Korea, approved a $2.5 billion bail out plan. The issue has been burning for months since a criminal investigation into top executives at several SK companies resulted in the arrest of the effective head of the conglomerate, Chey Tae Won, chairman of SK Corporation, above, the flagship unit of the SK Group. World Business, Section W.

$480 Million Deal for Jostens
Credit Suisse First Boston's investment arm said that it would buy Jostens, which sells school yearbooks and class rings, from an investment group for about $480 million. C4.

High-Rise Resurgence in Chicago
Despite the economic doldrums, two new office towers totaling more than 2.8 million square feet of space are now under construction in downtown Chicago. Work on a third is to begin later this year. Commercial Real Estate. C7.

HEADLINE: Venting at Rent Hearing Is Long, Loud and Personal 

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. CHEN

 BODY:
One after another, the landlords and the tenants in New York City's vast and byzantine rent-regulated world marched to the microphone yesterday at Cooper Union and offered their opinions about the largest rent increases since 1989.
 Woefully inadequate: That is what landlords like Christopher Athineos said about the increases of up to 8.5 percent recommended by the city's Rent Guidelines Board for the one million apartments under rent stabilization. Double-digit increases, Mr. Athineos said, would be more equitable for landlords who have shouldered soaring insurance and property taxes. "Anywhere in this country, the free market works," he said. 
 Criminally steep: That is what tenants like Judy Cheng said about the predicament that her retired parents, who have a combined income of $850 a month, would face if they had to pay more than their current rent, $600 a month. A reduction or a freeze, she suggested, would be more appropriate. "Why don't we evict landlords?" she said, to raucous applause.
And so the verbal sparring went, from early morning until late evening, as dozens of speakers tried to sway the nine members of the board in the first, last and only public hearing before a final vote on Thursday.
On May 5, the board tentatively approved rent increases of 5.5 percent for one-year leases and 8.5 percent for two-year leases, citing a surge in property taxes and fuel and insurance costs. The board has sometimes altered its initial recommendations in the final vote, though usually on the order of only a percentage point or two.
But for all the passion and heartache yesterday from people like Mr. Athineos and Ms. Cheng, the consensus was that the hearing was a bit more muted or even somber than in years past for one very big reason: many people were distracted by what was happening in Albany.
There, state leaders passed special legislation yesterday, for the third time in a week, to keep the rent laws from lapsing. The laws, which were last modified in 1997, were to expire at midnight on Sunday, but the Democratic-led Assembly and the Republican-led Senate have been at odds over the issue of vacancy decontrol, which allows landlords to eliminate rent regulations on vacated apartments after the monthly rent reaches $2,000.
The new deadline is today. But many landlords, tenants and legislators believe that Albany may not reach a deal until Thursday, the last day of the session. They are increasingly cynical about whether Albany will have the political will to overhaul the laws. That cynicism has been directed toward the city's rent board, as well.
State Senator Carl Kruger, Democrat of Brooklyn, seemed to tap into a sense of futility when he told the rent board yesterday, "Year after year, this board, with reckless disregard of the facts, has moved forward with an agenda -- an agenda that says that the tenant can drop dead, and the landlord has to survive."
His comments elicited thunderous applause from the tenant-dominated crowd of more than 200 people.
Mr. Kruger continued, "If that is not vaudeville, that's a kangaroo court."
Of the city's three million dwelling units, about two million are occupied by renters, though nationally only about a third of dwellings are rental units. Of the city's two million rental units, about one million are stabilized units subject to the board's decisions. About 350,000 more are rent-controlled apartments, public housing and other government-related residences, while only 650,000 units are not regulated, according to the Rent Guidelines Board.
Every spring, the board wrestles with how much to change rents for the million regulated apartments. For the better part of the last decade, rents have risen by a few percentage points, in keeping with low inflation. Last year, for instance, the board approved increases of 2 percent for one-year leases, and 4 percent for two-year leases, though the price index of operating costs, which summarizes landlords' expenses, showed a decrease for the first time in history.
This year, though, the preliminary vote -- the first by a rent board appointed mainly by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg -- came against a bleak backdrop of budget cuts, pending tax increases, a subway fare increase, the city's struggling economy and the lingering effects of the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attack. Hence the biggest increases in 14 years.
Besides proposing increases for apartments, the board on May 5 proposed increases on lofts of 4 percent for one-year leases and 7 percent for two-year renewals. For residential hotels, the board proposed an annual increase of 4 percent. The increases would apply to leases renewed between Oct. 1, 2003, and Sept. 30, 2004.
Many of the dozens of people who spoke in three-minute intervals yesterday were familiar faces from years past. The testimony got personal at times, as some tenants criticized the board's nine members -- two landlord representatives, two tenant representatives and five public members appointed by the mayor -- as being an elite crowd that did not represent the working class or the poor.
Some landlords offered a detailed accounting of building finances in arguing that they were the true victims of rent regulation.
J. Allison Crockett, a former Wall Street broker, said she bought a building in Brooklyn's Williamsburg section four years ago.
Of the building's 30 units, 16 rent for less than $500, she said. Her building had 70 code violations when she bought it, she said; now, it has none. But because she has been unable to raise rents to market levels, she has been late in paying her taxes.
"Did Bloomberg say everyone has to share the pain except the tenants?" she said, after being booed by the crowd. "It can't be that way. This is my retirement. This is my fixed income."

HEADLINE: World Business Briefing Europe: Belgium: Competition Rankings 

BYLINE:  By Paul Meller (NYT) 

 BODY:
 Europe's competition regulators rank fourth in the world, behind the United States, Germany and Britain, according to a new survey by the British trade journal Global Competition Review. The commission was considered weaker in economics than its American counterparts. 
This weakness was highlighted last year when the European Commission lost three court cases. The commission was also seen as more instinctively interventionist than the American authorities, according to the survey, which covered 500 executives, lawyers and competition officials. Last year the commission levied about 944 million euros ($1.11 billion) in antitrust fines. American officials levied $102 million in fines. American antitrust procedures, however, were regarded as less open than European procedures and more prone to political interference, the survey said. Paul Meller (NYT)
