HEADLINE: House Votes to End Federal Estate Tax as Senate Battle Looms 

BYLINE:  By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 18 

 BODY:
The House voted today to eliminate the federal estate tax, the third time in a month that Republicans have approved a large tax-cut bill over objections from Democrats that the government is being deprived of its lifeblood.
 The permanent elimination of the estate tax is a long-sought goal of the conservative Republicans who lead the House, and many said today that the measure would keep family businesses from dissolving to pay the tax upon an owner's death. Democrats countered that only a few thousand of the very richest estates have to pay the tax every year, and several said it was immoral to add to the nation's record-setting debt to benefit those at the economic pinnacle. 
 The vote was 264 to 163, with 41 Democrats joining the Republican majority in an indication of the intense lobbying by small-business interests in favor of repealing the tax. 
Today's bill will have a hard time in the Senate, where supporters will have to assemble 60 votes for passage under the chamber's budget rules. That barrier prevented a similar bill from passing last year, and barring a compromise that changes the House bill, supporters say they are probably four or five votes short in the Senate.
Nonetheless, the vote today represents a fulfillment of Republican promises to bring a continuing series of tax-cut measures to the House floor, whether or not they have a chance of passage in the Senate. Each vote -- and there will be many more to come -- further divides the two parties and the two chambers over a much larger underlying issue: the size of the national government in the years to come.
Although some Democrats criticized the specifics of the plan to eliminate the estate tax, many reserved unusually sweeping condemnation for what Representative Nancy Pelosi of California, the House Democratic leader, described as a Republican effort to undermine the United States' fundamental social compact by starving government programs of money.
"The Republicans are bringing a continuation of their reckless tax cutting binge that they are on, to undermine the fiscal soundness of the country," Ms. Pelosi said. 
Republican leaders retorted that the estate tax was another example of how families and businesses were being taxed to death, stifling the nation's economic growth.
"This isn't just for rich people, this is for everybody who shares in the American dream," said Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois. "We need to pass this piece of legislation, so we can keep this American heritage of families working, of families creating wealth, of families creating businesses."
The estate tax now collects 49 percent of estates of at least $1 million per individual and $2 million for couples, which under current law declines to 45 percent of estates more than $3.5 million per individual in 2009. In 2010, the tax is scheduled to disappear, but then revert to its old top rate of 60 percent in 2011. Republicans wrote the law that way in 2001 to comply with Senate budget limits, working under the assumption that the tax would be eliminated by Congress before 2011. The measure approved by the House today would end that "sunset provision" and kill the tax permanently in 2011.
Repealing the estate tax would cost the Treasury about $162 billion in the next 10 years, a figure that could grow extensively if the exemption is extended. Opponents had a field day with the Republicans' willingness to raise the deficit for that purpose, but not to provide a full prescription drug benefit for older people or an increased child tax credit to low-income families, issues now also under debate in Congress.
"So you're going to give away $60 billion to 40,000 rich kids every year, and you're going deny 40 million senior citizens the health care they deserve in their old age," said Representative Pete Stark, Democrat of California. 
Supporters cited a study released today by the Republican staff of the Joint Economic Committee, which said the tax was a leading cause of the dissolution of family businesses. It penalizes saving to pass on wealth, they said, and encourages excess consumption.
But opponents said that with the current $1 million exemption, the tax only affected the wealthiest 2 percent of all estates, and by the time the exemption rises in 2009, only about 10,000 estates would be affected, or less than half of 1 percent.
Democrats today offered a substitute bill, sponsored by Representative Earl Pomeroy of North Dakota, which would immediately exempt from taxation all estates of $3 million for an individual and $6 million for a couple. Mr. Pomeroy said his bill would exempt 99.65 percent of all estates from taxation, including all but 400 farms.
But House Republicans rejected the proposal and any other compromise on the tax.
"This amendment tells you don't be successful, don't save your money, don't grow your business," said Representative Jennifer Dunn, Republican of Washington, the sponsor of today's tax cut bill. 
President Bush issued a statement tonight praising the House for its vote, but centrist Republicans and Democrats in the Senate expressed more interest in a proposal similar to the Pomeroy bill, aides said. That proposal would cost less than $30 billion in the next 10 years, an amount that could be covered with various increased fees and elimination of corporate tax shelters.
Senate Republicans agreed today to meet their House counterparts in a conference about another divisive tax issue, increasing the child tax credit for 6.5 million families who did not receive it in the tax law signed by Mr. Bush last month. The White House said that at a breakfast meeting today, Mr. Bush urged leaders of the two chambers to resolve their differences quickly, but Congressional officials said there was still no breakthrough in the positions of the two chambers. The Senate approved a modest tax credit bill that would impose no cost on the Treasury, while the House bill includes other large tax cuts that would cost $82 billion over a decade. 

CORRECTION-DATE: June 21, 2003

 CORRECTION:
An article on Thursday about a House vote to repeal the estate tax referred incorrectly to the current rate for estates of at least $1 million. For 2003, estates of $1 million to $1.25 million are taxed at 41 percent; the rate gradually increases until it reaches 49 percent on estates of $2 million or above. (The 49 percent rate does not begin at $1 million.)

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Oracle's Campaign to Take Over PeopleSoft Heats Up

BYLINE:  By LAURIE FLYNN and ANDREW ROSS SORKIN 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, June 18 

 BODY:
Raising the stakes in Silicon Valley's fierce takeover battle, the Oracle Corporation increased its hostile bid for PeopleSoft by more than $1 billion yesterday in a new effort to pressure PeopleSoft's board to consider its offer.
 In the latest legal tit-for-tat, Oracle also filed suit today against PeopleSoft and J. D. Edwards, the software maker that PeopleSoft recently agreed to acquire. Oracle said the lawsuit was "in response to their collective efforts to eliminate PeopleSoft shareholders' ability to accept Oracle's tender offer." 
 A few hours after Oracle's announcement, the State of Connecticut said it had filed a lawsuit against Oracle, alleging the company's proposed takeover of PeopleSoft violates the state's antitrust laws and would damage its economy. The state is just two weeks from its planned first phase of a $100 million computer system based on PeopleSoft software. 
Oracle, the world's second-largest producer of specialized software for business operations, said it would offer $19.50 a share in cash for all outstanding shares of PeopleSoft, raising the value of its bid to $6.3 billion. Oracle's original offer of $16 a share was valued at $5.1 billion.
After previously insisting he would not go higher, Lawrence J. Ellison, Oracle's chief executive, said the company decided to increase the offer after meeting with some of PeopleSoft's largest shareholders during the last several days.
"Oracle remains committed to acquiring PeopleSoft and will not be deterred by management's maneuvers to maintain control of a company they do not own," Mr. Ellison said. PeopleSoft's shares rose 78 cents today to close at $17.93; Oracle's shares rose 7 cents, to $13.42. 
In response to Oracle's higher bid, PeopleSoft said its board would meet to review the new offer and make a recommendation to shareholders "in due course." PeopleSoft's board rejected Oracle's original unsolicited $16 a share offer; its chief executive, Craig Conway, called the bid "diabolical."
Oracle's revised offer for PeopleSoft comes just two days after PeopleSoft modified its bid for J. D. Edwards, a smaller rival, to include cash as well as stock, thereby eliminating the need for a PeopleSoft shareholder vote. By removing the shareholder vote, PeopleSoft made it harder for Oracle to challenge the J. D. Edwards acquisition and made a PeopleSoft acquisition less attractive.
As part of its latest offer, Oracle is asking for the cancellation of the revised merger agreement between PeopleSoft and J. D. Edwards, and that PeopleSoft's shareholders be allowed to vote on the matter.
Last week, PeopleSoft and J. D. Edwards tried to block the takeover by suing Oracle. In its suit, PeopleSoft said Oracle's takeover offer was a "sham" aimed at hurting sales and destroying the company as a competitor. 
Executives at Oracle said PeopleSoft had left it with few options but to go directly to PeopleSoft's largest shareholders. "Normally, we would rely on the management of the target company representing its shareholders to determine what is a fair price," said Charles Phillips, executive vice president of Oracle. "But since the management wouldn't meet with us, we went directly to the majority of PeopleSoft shareholders and asked them."
Analysts took Oracle's new offer as a sign of the company's determination to acquire PeopleSoft despite management's opposition. But they suggested that Oracle's latest price might not be its last. "It gets them in the red zone, but not in the end zone," said David Hilal, an analyst with Friedman, Billings, Ramsey. "It's going to give Oracle more support among PeopleSoft shareholders but I think they're going to want to see $21 to $22 to consummate the deal," he said, referring to the price per share.
Eric Upin, an analyst at Wells Fargo Securities L.L.C., said he thought Oracle's original offer of $16 a share was a fair starting point, but believed the new bid was a necessary next step and clearly showed that Oracle was serious. "At $19.50 it looks like a good accretive deal," he said. "This dispels the controversy of how committed Ellison is. This clearly shows he's sunk his teeth in."
Connecticut's lawsuit, filed in United States District Court in Hartford, alleges that an Oracle takeover of PeopleSoft would effectively reduce competition because it would turn the market for enterprise software into a two-horse race between German-based SAP and Oracle. "The two remaining companies would have more than 50 percent of the market," said Richard Blumenthal, the state's attorney general. "It's a classic antitrust issue." 
State officials also said Oracle's proposed merger could derail gains the state had achieved as a PeopleSoft customer. A takeover of PeopleSoft by Oracle would likely cost the state much of what it has already spent, state officials said, given that Oracle has said it would not continue developing PeopleSoft's product line.
"The threat is very real and very immediate that we will suffer huge financial loss," Mr. Blumenthal said. "In this industry, ending innovation is the death knell for any product line." Oracle's executives expressed disappointment over the state's lawsuit and said that Connecticut's assumptions about the potential financial impact of an Oracle acquisition of PeopleSoft were based on false information. Mr. Ellison sent Gov. John G. Rowland and Mr. Blumenthal a letter insisting that Oracle did not intend "to force any customers to migrate to Oracle applications."
Mr. Phillips argued that Oracle's strategy to focus on a single line of products was more promising than PeopleSoft's plan to keep developing the J. D. Edwards product line. "They should be more worried about PeopleSoft spending its R&D budget on J. D. Edwards products, because they're all duplicates," Mr. Phillips said.
Mr. Phillips said Oracle was encouraged that PeopleSoft executives appeared to be carefully reviewing Oracle's latest offer. He also suggested that Oracle still had a wide range of possible tactics to pursue no matter what PeopleSoft did next.
"It's early in the game," Mr. Phillips said, "and we still have plenty of innings left."

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Quick to Get Big Donors to Cover Cost of Convention 

BYLINE:  By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD 

 BODY:
Reaching out to some of New York City's highest-profile millionaires and billionaires, including Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, organizers of the Republican National Convention said yesterday that they had raised nearly all the money they expected to need to stage the event next year.
 In contrast to past conventions, in which organizers have often struggled up to the last minute and beyond to raise money, organizers of the New York City convention said they had received financial commitments of about $60 million from several wealthy residents and corporate chiefs, with 15 months left to go before the opening gavel strikes. 
 The convention is scheduled to be held in Madison Square Garden from Aug. 28 to Sept. 2, 2004.
That figure is just $4 million short of what the New York City Host Committee has agreed to raise and is several months ahead of a schedule of fund-raising goals spelled out in the agreement with the Republican National Committee. 
The agreement was released to The New York Times yesterday under a Freedom of Information Act request. The city withheld 46 pages of the 453-page document because of what officials described as security concerns. The total budget for the convention is $91 million. The host committee has promised to raise $64 million to pay such expenses as renting the Garden, building a bridge between the Garden and the post office across Eighth Avenue, transporting delegates around town, building a podium and buying an entrance carpet. The city agreed to pick up the $27 million in costs related to police, fire, emergency services and insurance.
The chief contributors include titans of banking, Wall Street and real estate, including David Rockefeller, Jonathan M. Tisch of Loews Hotels, Sanford I. Weill of Citigroup, Henry M. Paulson Jr. of Goldman Sachs and William C. Rudin, the real estate magnate. 
The contributors pledged several million dollars each from their own personal fortunes or from their companies or associates. Mr. Bloomberg pledged $5 million of his personal fortune.
Lewis M. Eisenberg, the co-chairman of the Host Committee and the chief organizer of fund-raising, said he believed the financial commitments reflected both civic pride and deep support for the first-ever Republican convention in New York, where President Bush and Vice President Cheney will begin their drive to Election Day.
Several of the financiers are Democrats or have given to both Democratic and Republican causes. They said for them any partisanship was trumped by the convention's benefits to the city economy, estimated at $150 million, and to the city's psyche in the aftermath of 9/11.
"It is not about politics," Mr. Rudin said, noting that the Host Committee is a nonpartisan, nonprofit organization. "It is about New York City and creating economic opportunities."
The city, according to the agreement, had promised to use public funds to make up any shortfall in the $64 million fund-raising goal, but it is almost clear of that obligation given the pledges of support. 
Mr. Bloomberg said he was convinced the city, in the same time period, could have raised enough money to play host to both the Republican and Democratic conventions. The city was a finalist for the 2004 Democratic convention but lost to Boston in part because the Democrats did not want to hold a convention in a city that was also wooing the Republicans.
"New Yorkis a place where there is a lot people who have done very well and where there is a spirit of philanthropy, sometimes for museums, hospitals, and sometimes for political stuff," Mr. Bloomberg said. 
He added, "I tried to get both conventions to come to New York, and we could have raised the money for both of them in the same period very easily."
Some groups believe the campaign finance law passed last year that bans large, unregulated donations known as soft money in political campaigns applies to the convention host committees. The Federal Election Commission is expected to issue a ruling this summer, though few people in either party believe the commission will agree and turn off the spigot for 2004.
Fred Wertheimer, president of Democracy 21, a Washington group supporting the campaign finance law, said he believed donations like those New York City is expecting are illegal.
"Anyone who thinks donors putting up huge amounts of money for a convention do not get precisely the kind of influence that the new law is intended to stop are kidding themselves," he said.
Mr. Eisenberg said the donors had not been promised anything in return and had made their commitments out of devotion to the city or the president. But he said as host committee leaders it was "likely" they may be invited to choice convention functions.
Organizers began raising money in April, three months after Republicans officially chose New York. By contrast, it took the organizers of the 2000 Republican convention in Philadelphia more than a year to report raising $40 million. (It ultimately raised $60 million in cash and in-kind donations.) 
The agreement provides details on how the convention budget will be spent, although city officials said costs may be adjusted as the actual bills come in.
About $5 million will be set aside to rent the Garden; $750,000 to build a pedestrian bridge linking the Garden and the Farley Post Office, which will serve as the news media center; $1.5 million to transport delegates and convention staff, some of them in car service sedans; and, for more mundane matters: $36,000 for the delegate entrance carpet and $186,250 for portable restrooms. 
Decor and fabric coverings will cost $808,500; $2.49 million will go to the podium; $7.7 million for host committee events, and $1.2 million for office supplies.
The Host Committee has promised 20,000 first-class hotel or motel rooms, 2,000 of which will be one- or two-bedroom suites. The Waldorf-Astoria, for instance, has offered 1,165 of the 1,297 rooms available at that time, including 24 suites at $529 a night overlooking Park Avenue and with a large foyer, separate living room and one or two bedrooms.
The committee must also provide a lighting, sound engineering and air-conditioning consultant.
The city will provide a shuttle bus system arranged by the committee under a traffic flow pattern the city must draft to ensure everybody can get from their hotels to the convention reasonably quickly.
One provision may pose a challenge under any circumstance.
"Host committee shall use its best efforts to ensure that taxicabs will be available during the convention period to provide taxi service to participants of the convention at rates no higher than the rates in effect at the time of the convention period," the agreement says. It does not spell out how that will be accomplished.
The $91 million budget does not include the approximately $14 million both parties receive in federal funds to put on their conventions. That money typically pays for costs associated with the proceedings in the hall, such as salaries for staff members organizing the actual program, producing the party platform and props such as videos played on stage.

HEADLINE: REPORT BY E.P.A. LEAVES OUT DATA ON CLIMATE CHANGE 

BYLINE:  By ANDREW C. REVKIN with KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

 BODY:
The Environmental Protection Agency is preparing to publish a draft report next week on the state of the environment, but after editing by the White House, a long section describing risks from rising global temperatures has been whittled to a few noncommittal paragraphs.
 The report, commissioned in 2001 by the agency's administrator, Christie Whitman, was intended to provide the first comprehensive review of what is known about various environmental problems, where gaps in understanding exist and how to fill them. 
 Agency officials said it was tentatively scheduled to be released early next week, before Mrs. Whitman steps down on June 27, ending a troubled time in office that often put her at odds with President Bush. 
Drafts of the climate section, with changes sought by the White House, were given to The New York Times yesterday by a former E.P.A. official, along with earlier drafts and an internal memorandum in which some officials protested the changes. Two agency officials, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said the documents were authentic.
The editing eliminated references to many studies concluding that warming is at least partly caused by rising concentrations of smokestack and tail-pipe emissions and could threaten health and ecosystems. 
Among the deletions were conclusions about the likely human contribution to warming from a 2001 report on climate by the National Research Council that the White House had commissioned and that President Bush had endorsed in speeches that year. White House officials also deleted a reference to a 1999 study showing that global temperatures had risen sharply in the previous decade compared with the last 1,000 years. In its place, administration officials added a reference to a new study, partly financed by the American Petroleum Institute, questioning that conclusion.
In the end, E.P.A. staff members, after discussions with administration officials, said they decided to delete the entire discussion to avoid criticism that they were selectively filtering science to suit policy.
Administration officials defended the report and said there was nothing untoward about the process that produced it. Mrs. Whitman said that she was "perfectly comfortable" with the edited version and that the differences over climate change should not hold up the broader assessment of the nation's air, land and water.
"The first draft, as with many first drafts, contained everything," she said in a brief telephone interview from the CBS studios in Manhattan, where she was waiting to tape "The Late Show With David Letterman." 
"As it went through the review, there was less consensus on the science and conclusions on climate change," Ms. Whitman said. "So rather than go out with something half-baked or not put out the whole report, we felt it was important for us to get this out because there is a lot of really good information that people can use to measure our successes."
James L. Connaughton, chairman of the Council on Environmental Quality, a White House advisory group, said, "It would be utterly inaccurate to suggest that this administration has not provided quite an extensive discussion about the state of the climate. Ultimately, E.P.A. made the decision not to include the section on climate change because we had these ample discussions of the subject already."
But private environmental groups sharply criticized the changes when they heard of them.
"Political staff are becoming increasingly bold in forcing agency officials to endorse junk science," said Jeremy Symons, a climate policy expert at the National Wildlife Federation. "This is like the White House directing the secretary of labor to alter unemployment data to paint a rosy economic picture."
Drafts of the report have been circulating for months, but a heavy round of rewriting and cutting by White House officials in late April raised protest among E.P.A. officials working on the report.
An April 29 memorandum circulated among staff members said that after the changes by White House officials, the section on climate "no longer accurately represents scientific consensus on climate change." 
Another memorandum circulated at the same time said that the easiest course would be to accept the White House revisions but that to do so would taint the agency, because "E.P.A. will take responsibility and severe criticism from the science and environmental communities for poorly representing the science."
The changes were mainly made by the Council on Environmental Quality, although the Office of Management and Budget was also involved, several E.P.A. officials said. It is the second time in a year that the White House has sought to play down global warming in official documents. 
Last September, an annual E.P.A. report on air pollution that for six years had contained a section on climate was released without one, and the decision to delete it was made by Bush administration appointees at the agency with White House approval.
Like the September report, the forthcoming report says the issues will be dealt with later by a climate research plan being prepared by the Bush administration. 
Other sections of the coming E.P.A. report -- on water quality, ecological conditions, ozone depletion in the atmosphere and other issues -- all start with a summary statement about the potential impact of changes on human health and the environment, which are the two responsibilities of the agency.
But in the "Global Issues" section of the draft returnedby the White House to E.P.A. in April, an introductory sentence reading, "Climate change has global consequences for human health and the environment" was cut and replaced with a paragraph that starts: "The complexity of the Earth system and the interconnections among its components make it a scientific challenge to document change, diagnose its causes, and develop useful projections of how natural variability and human actions may affect the global environment in the future."
Some E.P.A. staff members defended the document, saying that although pared down it would still help policy makers and the agency address the climate issue.
"This is a positive step by the agency," said an author of the report, who did not want to be named, adding that it would help someone determine "if a facility or pollutant is going to hurt my family or make it bad for the birds, bees and fish out there."

GRAPHIC: Photo: In a coming report by the Environmental Protection Agency, sections on the climate were edited by White House officials to eliminate references to studies on the causes and effects of global warming. (pg. A20)

 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk; Pg. 29

LENGTH: 4605 words

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums children under 12 and museum members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

Museums

* "ART OF THE FIRST CITIES: THE THIRD MILLENNIUM B.C. FROM THE MEDITERRANEAN TO THE INDUS," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Aug. 17). The most timely exhibition in years, as well as diplomatically dexterous and beautiful. It surveys the culture of the third millennium B.C., mainly centered in Mesopotamia, the crucible of Sumerian civilization, where art, architecture, law and writing developed with the rise of the earliest cities. The beginnings of a cosmopolitan art are in tiny cylinder seals and in figurines. The show is full of small objects that are monumental in concept. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $12; $7, students and 65+ (Michael Kimmelman).

FREDERICK J. BROWN, "Portraits in Jazz, Blues and Other Icons," Studio Museum in Harlem, 144 West 125th Street, (212) 864-4500 (through June 29). This three-decade, 30-piece retrospective profiles a painter who has restlessly explored Modernist abstraction, Neo-Expressionist narrative and portraiture. His big, luxuriantly congested, storytelling pictures from the 1980's are the most visually rich and imaginatively expansive. His portraits of great jazz and blues musicians are, at their best, theatrically energetic. But a big double portrait of Willem de Kooning steals the show. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $7; $3, students and 62+ (Ken Johnson).

"DRAWN HOME: FRITZ VOGT'S RURAL AMERICA," American Folk Art Museum, 45 West 53rd Street, (212) 265-1040 (through Sept. 21). During the last decade of the 19th century, Vogt, a German immigrant, supported himself by making portraits of homes in upstate New York. A homeless itinerant who preferred to sleep in his patrons' barns, Vogt made wonderfully lucid, formally ingenious drawings of farms with multiple outbuildings and of elaborately decorated Victorian showpieces with manicured grounds. The 26 drawings here tap into an American ethos that elevated domestic prosperity to something like a national religion. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 7:30 p.m. Admission: $9; $7, students and 62+ (Johnson).

* "DREAMING IN PICTURES: THE PHOTOGRAPHS OF LEWIS CARROLL," International Center of Photography, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43rd Street, (212) 857-0000 (through Aug. 31). A photograph is at least as much a looking glass as it is a window. We see in it our own reflections and obsessions. A post-Freudian world has inevitably come to see C. L. Dodgson's photographs through the looking glass of his alter ego, Lewis Carroll. This provocative show tries to put Dodgson's pictures back in their context, to stress that we have lost touch with Victorian conventions, which Dodgson largely obeyed when he photographed little girls. Childhood to Victorians represented, as the show's curator puts it, an "alternate reality, a metaphysical state of preknowledge." Dodgson could pose his charges in adult roles, give them guns, daggers and exotic costumes, even portray them as odalisques and half-dressed waifs, because he and most of his audience believed so emphatically in their total insulation from the implications of such postures. These presentations do not so much underscore the latent sexuality of the child (as we post-Freudians would have it) as they do an obvious lack of it. Hours and admission: Tuesdays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $10; $7, students and 62+ (Kimmelman).

* "MANET/VELAZQUEZ: THE FRENCH TASTE FOR SPANISH PAINTING," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through June 29). The Met has clearly called in every chip to make this show spectacular. The first rooms are a virtual survey of great Spanish painting of the 17th and 18th centuries; after that comes a virtual Manet retrospective, with some Degas and Courbet thrown in for good measure; then a virtual 19th-century American overview of the most gifted portraitists influenced by Spanish painting via Manet, Degas and Courbet: Eakins, Chase, Sargent and Whistler. The thesis of Spanish influence on French art is hardly new, but it is explored in such precise and fresh detail, discreetly, without pushing comparisons (in that respect it's not like "Matisse Picasso" at the Modern, notwithstanding the coincidental titled pairings) that you would have to be churlish not to leave edified and amazed. Hours and admission: See above (Kimmelman).

"MATERIAL DIFFERENCES: ART AND IDENTITY IN AFRICA," Museum for African Art, 36-01 43rd Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-7700 (through Oct. 6). Part Art Methods 101, part Advanced Connoisseurship, this handsome, thoughtful show examines the potent connection between matter and meaning in diverse African cultures and shows them to be organically connected. The material is spiritual in these cultures, and the show's 130 mostly ceremonial objects, arranged strictly according to materials and techniques, reflect the power of that belief. Hours: Mondays, Thursdays and Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 to 6 p.m. Admission: $6; $3, students and 65+ (Roberta Smith).

"ELIE NADELMAN: SCULPTOR OF MODERN LIFE," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3600 (through July 20). Despite the clarion title, this exhibition is too monotonous, stiffly installed and short on drawings to do full justice to the erudite, polymorphous achievement of the Polish-born American sculptor Elie Nadelman (1882-1946). Still, don't miss this opportunity to see his work in quantity, especially the streamlined wood figures from the 1920's and the small, truculent plaster figurines, which were found in his studio after his death. Their suave economy, ineffable stillness, delicate gestures and seamless blend of historical and popular sources place them among the most complex, fully visual sculptures in Western art. Hours: Wednesdays, Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $12; $9.50, students and 62+ (Smith).

"NOGUCHI -- THE BOLLINGEN JOURNEY: PHOTOGRAPHS AND DRAWINGS, 1949-1956," Isamu Noguchi Garden Museum (temporary space), 36-01 43rd Avenue, Sunnyside, Queens, (718) 204-7088 (through Oct. 13). More than 100 photographs and drawings re-create Noguchi's travels from 1949 to 1956, on a grant from the Bollingen Foundation. The project was for an ambitious book (never completed) on the spaces and structures -- religious, monumental, classical and communal -- of familiar as well as less-documented societies. Besides providing an elegant travelogue, the photographs give some idea of the many sources that Noguchi drew on for his work. Hours: Mondays, Thursdays and Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $2.50 for students and 65+ (Grace Glueck)

"THE PHOTOGRAPHY OF CHARLES SHEELER," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Aug. 17). This majestic progression of 90 vintage prints will cause some ripples in the big familiar pond of American modernism, within which Sheeler is known foremost as one of the chief instigators of Precisionist painting. But his most profound, original response to Cubism came through the camera, in tautly composed photographs of Pennsylvania farmhouses and barns, New York skyscrapers and Ford's River Rouge factory. Their confident fusion of abstraction and fact, reverence and scrutiny, puts them among the most radical art of their time; and they are an important precursor, at least in spirit, to both Pop and Minimalism. Hours and admission: See above (Smith).

"ANDY WARHOL: SCREEN TESTS," Museum of Modern Art, Queens, 45-20 33rd Street, at Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, (212) 708-9400 (through Sept. 1). From 1964 to 1966, Warhol shot 500 short, silent, black-and-white films of artists, musicians, actors, writers, filmmakers, models, curators, celebrities and hangers-on at the Factory. The Modern has restored 277 of these screen tests, representing some 34 hours of watching time, and now 28 are being shown continuously on six screens. The subjects include Baby Jane Holzer, Salvador Dali, James Rosenquist, Dennis Hopper, Cass Elliott and Susan Sontag -- but they are of variable interest. By shooting the films at one speed and playing them more slowly, Warhol exposed the mechanics of discomposure and charisma. Some people are fascinating as they lose charisma; others are not. It has nothing to do with handsomeness, histrionics, coolness, slimness, trying or giving up. The typology of charisma is as elusive as the typology of criminality. Hours: Thursdays through Mondays, from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m; to 7:45 p.m. on Fridays. Admission: $6; $4.25 for students and 65+ (Sarah Boxer).

Galleries: Uptown

* "THE HEART OF THE MATTER: THE STILL LIFES OF MARSDEN HARTLEY," Berry-Hill, 11 East 70th Street, (212) 744-2300 (through June 27). This display of nearly 60 works is said to be the first ever devoted entirely to Hartley's still lifes. Glowingly alive, varying in style from abstraction to realism and in subject from delicate floral arrangements to the depiction of fish, a dead bird and ladies' gloves, they were painted with the same power and elan that went into his intense, vibrant landscapes (Glueck).

"SALLY MICHEL, MILTON AVERY: A PORTRAIT," Knoedler & Company, 19 East 70th Street, (212) 794-0550 (through June 27). Also known as Mrs. Milton Avery, the widow of the artist, Sally Michel used her own name as a painter in her own right. This warm memorial tribute to Michel and Avery mounts a group of informal, private portraits of each artist done by the other. A wall of Avery by Michel, who died in January, shows him painting, napping, smoking, reading, thinking, leaning. A facing wall of portraits by Avery (1885-1965) shows Michel smiling, mothering their daughter, March, wearing a new hat and painting a portrait of her husband. This small show is an engaging celebration of a highly productive relationship (Glueck).

"PUERTO RICAN LIGHT: JENNIFER ALLORA AND GUILLERMO CALZADILLA," Americas Society Gallery, 680 Park Avenue, at 68th Street, (212) 249-8950 (through July 20). Ms. Allora and Mr. Calzadilla are young conceptual artist-collaborators who divide their time between Puerto Rico and New York, and this show brings both places together. The centerpiece is a 1965 fluorescent sculpture by Dan Flavin titled "Puerto Rican Light (to Jeanie Blake)," which in this case derives its illuminating power from solar energy gathered in San Juan and stored in batteries in the gallery (Holland Cotter).

Galleries: 57th Street

ERIC FREEMAN, Mary Boone Gallery, 745 Fifth Avenue, at 58th Street, (212) 752-2929 (through June 28). Painting doesn't get much more retinal than Mr. Freeman's large, sensuous compositions of tubular bands of neon-bright color. Rothkoesque but devoid of cosmic consciousness, they are so aggressively decorative that they verge on decadence (Johnson).

"MARIKO MORI: WAVE U.F.O.," atrium at 590 Madison Avenue, at 56th Street, (212) 980-4575 (through July 31). Of late, this Japanese artist, whose past work blended science fiction, fashion and esoteric Buddhism, has been designing interactive spiritual hardware, and this podlike container is her most ambitious piece so far. It accommodates three electrode-wired participants at a time, who are treated to a son-et-lumiere projection of their brain waves, followed by an eye-rinsing aurora borealis of Ms. Mori's devising. The high-tech work is fun while it lasts and must have cost someone a fortune to produce (Cotter).

* AMY MYERS, Danese, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 223-2227 (through June 27). Ms. Myers, who made her debut at Mary Boone a few years ago, makes an impressive reappearance with this show of large drawings. The single, big, complicated, diagrammatic structures in each are made of countless draftsmanly parts meticulously arranged. They suggest many concrete things -- space ships, ectoplasmic apparitions, sexual organs, mandalas -- but remain emanations of an intensely personal exercise in hard labor and serious play (Cotter).

Galleries: Chelsea

MERLIN CARPENTER, "Children of the Projects," American Fine Arts, 530 West 22nd Street, (212) 727-7366 (through July 19). Like a grunge-generation Philip Evergood, Mr. Carpenter has created a suite of brushy, intentionally clumsy and overbearingly sentimental paintings that allegorize the plight of inner-city children. A boy in huge sneakers resembles an op-ed cartoon about escapist dreams of athletic success. Two boys in hip-hop wear, one aiming a handgun at himself, illustrate suicidal tendencies nurtured by poverty. Something is being mocked here but it's not clear exactly what (Johnson).

LARRY CLARK, "Punk Picasso," Luhring Augustine, 531 West 24th Street, (212) 206-9100 (through June 28). This show is a walk-in tabloid that reduces looking to rubbernecking. An autobiographical collage of photographs, newspaper clippings, confessional monologues and personal memorabilia, it ranges through the artist's bouts of drug addiction, rehab, incarceration and marriage, as well as his books, films and their reviews. The intention to equate the heartlessness and outlaw status of drug addicts with artists is clear. But self-revelation is not self-reflection, and it is hard to admire the searing honesty of someone who is an exhibitionist to begin with (Smith).

BART DOMBURG, Gasser & Grunert, 524 West 19th Street, (212) 807-9494 (through June 28). With a careful but not too fussy touch, this Dutch painter makes pictures of land, sea and architecture that exude a muted mournfulness. With titles alluding to the Holocaust, they are actually Gerhard Richter-style history paintings. "Schuhprufstrecke," a stony plot framed by curbstone, was a track where concentration camp prisoners were forced to test the durability of shoes (Johnson).

ELGER ESSER, Sonnabend, 536 West 22nd Street, (212) 627-1018 (through June 28). A former student of the balefully influential Bernd and Hilla Becher, Mr. Esser is a high-concept photographer, but his large color pictures of spectacular coastal geology are nevertheless visually stunning and romantically affecting. They also look slightly antique, as is appropriate, since they are based on descriptions and sketches of sites in Normandy by Maupassant, whom Flaubert had asked to help in his research for a novel about a pair of failed amateur geologists (Johnson).

DAN FLAVIN, Paula Cooper, 534 West 21st Street, (212) 255-1105 (through June 30). Six of Flavin's most radically simplified fluorescent light sculptures turn this spacious gallery into an oasis of coolly luminous quietude that verges on ecclesiastical. Believers will feel blessed. Skeptics may reason that just about any tastefully spare arrangement of lights in such a space would have a similarly dramatic effect. Either way, the show speaks volumes about the idealism of radically materialist art in the 60's (Johnson).

KAHN & SELESNICK, "City of Salt," Yancey Richardson, 535 West 22nd Street, (646) 230-9610 (through July 3). Nicholas Kahn and Richard Selesnick's latest photographic campaign looks like something produced by Monty Python under the influence of Sufism. Accompanied by long, mythic texts, their panoramic, faux-antique digital prints envision Orientalist scenes of magical adventure, mind-expanding allegory and goofy absurdity. "City of Salt," a work built of salt, sugar and clay in the gallery, is less interesting, but it does evoke the idea of lost mystic wisdom (Johnson).

R. L. KAPLAN, "Paintings From the 80's," Edward Thorp, 210 11th Avenue, at 24th Street, (212) 691-6565 (through June 28). This 63-year-old Brooklyn-born painter is self-taught, but his paintings don't look like Outsider art. Surrealistic, political and painted in a simplifying style, his medium-large pictures of fighting birds, gridded flags, imperial architecture, regal dogs and empty parks allegorize international politics in an enigmatic, mournful mood (Johnson).

"ONLINE," Feigen Contemporary, 535 West 20th Street, (212) 929-0500 (through Aug. 9). Not about Web art but the traditional use of line, this 38-artist show includes too much that is only tangentially linear. But works like Daniel Zeller's intense fields, like a zany topographical map; Hilary Harkness's fantasy of sexy girl sailors, drawn with Ingres-like refinement; and Beth Campbell's branching diagram of her own possible futures suggest that a more focused investigation of the varieties of linear expression in contemporary art would be worth pursuing (Johnson).

"PIERRE ET GILLES," Robert Miller, 524 West 26th Street, (212) 366-4774 (through June 28). The word kitsch takes on a new dimension in this over-the-top Shangri-la depicted by the French photographer-painter team (Pierre photographs their subjects; Gilles punches them up with paint and airbrush). Butch male beauties, kittenish sex bombs, preening athletes, pop celebrities, satanic saints and goddesses, jacks of all genders and raw scatological-erotic material a la Mapplethorpe are their preoccupations, embellished with kinky props and settings. Despite their ingenuity of the pair, and their much-touted impact on the art, news media and fashion scenes, the show, with its stale camp glitter, could top your can't-wait-to-miss list (Glueck).

ROB PRUITT AND JONATHAN HOROWITZ, "Surreal Estate," Gavin Brown's Enterprise, 436 West 15th Street, (212) 627-5258 (through June 28). This amusing and annoying show is intended to sell a big Victorian house that Mr. Pruitt and Mr. Horowitz own in Fleischmanns, a Catskills town. The artists painted the house black and decorated it in campy, Gothic horror style. In the gallery, they created a kind of Halloween party scene with black walls, a rattling glass chandelier and digitally printed banners. A video called "Extreme Houses Visits Peacock Hill" spoofs Martha Stewart (Johnson).

HELEN ROUSAKIS, "My Own Nature," Sandra Gering, 534 West 22nd Street, (646) 336-7183 (through June 28). Ms. Rousakis photographs unidentified objects submerged in water. In her evocative color and black-and-white prints they appear coated in tiny bubbles, blurry in some place and sharply focused in others, eerily glowing like submarine life forms on another planet (Johnson).

JOEL SHAPIRO, PaceWildenstein, 534 West 25th Street, (212) 929-7000 (through July). If the sculptures of Donald Judd and Elie Nadelman had children, they might grow up to look like the best works in Mr. Shapiro's exhibition. They are the ones beautifully fabricated in various woods: airy, floating jumbles of tenuously connected boxes that visually resolve from certain angles into figures jauntily dancing or assuming graceful yoga postures. A pair of giant bronzes, however, look ponderous and overscaled (Johnson).

FRANK STELLA, Paul Kasmin, 293 10th Avenue, at 27th Street, (212) 563-4474 (through June 28). Big, unpainted assemblages of steel pipe bent into curves, spirals and serpentine forms, as well as sheet metal and occasional punctuations of plastic materials, fill the gallery with aggressive energy. Mr. Stella's Cubist blend of biomorphic and geometric forms has a vaguely space-age look, but it is too familiar to make these works as spectacularly surprising as he wants them to be. (Johnson).

* DO-HO SUH, Lehmann Maupin, 540 West 26th Street, (212) 255-2923, (through July 18). Mr. Suh's full-scale recreation of his vacant New York apartment, including outer hallway and stairs leading to a nonexistent second story, is a wonderful blend of the mundane and the miraculous. From a distance, it's ghost house, with translucent walls, stairs, doors, and kitchen and bathroom fixtures all made from sheer, slightly metallic blue, green and purple nylon. Inside you discover that everything from the door hinges to the toilet has been realized with loving attention to detail (Johnson).

Galleries: SoHo

"ARTISTS IN RESIDENCE," Location One, 26 Greene Street, (212) 334-3347 (through June 28). Location One is host to artists from overseas who want to explore new electronic media. Works by the latest guests include Isabelle Jenniches's absorbing video of people reading on the subway; Dominik Lejman's video of a swarming, seemingly imploding crowd of people; Jiun-Tin Lin's electronic play with the illusion and reality of butterflies; Javier Viver's prototypes for portable dwellings based on industrial packaging systems; and Daniel Blaufuks's 243 postcards, alternating with brief messages to unidentified recipients (Johnson).

COREY McCORKLE, Maccarone, 45 Canal Street, (212) 431-4977 (through June 30). The best thing here is an optically captivating circular window made from hundreds of cross-sections of bamboo. See it from the street as well as from inside the darkened gallery. Mr. McCorkle's interest in the New Age cult of houseplants, represented in a two-sided mural of photographs of a gardening community in northern Scotland, is intriguing but not, thus far, fully realized (Johnson).

Other Galleries

"ART AFTER THE AGE OF MECHANICAL REPRODUCTION," Apexart, 291 Church Street, TriBeCa, (212) 431-5270 (through tomorrow). This show, organized by the curator Eugenie Tsai, presents five inventive art recyclers. Marietta Ganapin makes densely patterned mandalas from tiny pieces punched from art reproductions; Devorah Sperber redoes Chuck Close using colored pipe-cleaners; Michael Cloud makes gridded abstractions of old master still-lifes; Anoka Faruqee incrementally replicates her own poured paintings using an asterisk mark; and Suzanne Bocanegra's whole-wall installation inventories "All the Petals From Jan Brughel the Elder's 'Sense of Smell' " (Johnson).

"HOMELAND," Art Gallery of the Graduate Center, City University of New York, 365 Fifth Avenue, at 34th Street, (212) 431-1737 (through June 29). This shrewdly entertaining group show, organized by five young curators in the Whitney Museum of American Art Independent Study Program, addresses the present American political moment. Pieces from the 1980's and 90's acknowledge a history of activist Conceptualism, but most of the work is new and includes a Web project that maps out surveillance-free paths through Manhattan, a commemorative Enron monument and a Muslim call to prayer adapted from an alarm clock (Cotter).

* "THE NEW WORLD'S OLD WORLD: PHOTOGRAPHIC VIEWS OF ANCIENT AMERICA," AXA Gallery, 787 Seventh Avenue, at 51st Street, (212) 554-4818 (through July 19). From the mid-19th century onward, photography played many roles in the frontier territories of North and South America: as a scientific instrument, a surveillance device, a definer of cultural identity and an aesthetic form. This beautiful show documents those uses and offers a sustained meditation on the shadow-play of picture-taking and politics (Cotter).

* DARIO ROBLETO, "Say Goodbye to Substance," Whitney Museum of American Art at Altria, 120 Park Avenue, at 42nd Street, (917) 663-2453 (through July 3). Mr. Robleto, who is 31 and lives in San Antonio, makes his New York solo debut with a show that suggests a Nobel Prize-worthy science fair project. Its small, laboriously handcrafted sculptures are made from, among many other things, plaster, driftwood, homemade crystals, antibiotics, prehistoric whalebone dust, gunpowder and melted vinyl recordings of the Beatles, Black Sabbath and Tammy Wynette. Its themes include utopian thinking, space travel, pop culture and American childhood, all viewed with an attitude of sunny despair (Cotter).

Last Chance

"AFTERSHOCK: THE LEGACY OF THE READY-MADE IN POSTWAR AND CONTEMPORARY AMERICAN ART," Dickinson Roundell, 19 East 66th Street, (212) 772-8083 (through today). The ready-made was the Dada brain child of Marcel Duchamp, who presides over this crowded group show of work by American artists, old and young, he has inspired. Several, like Jasper Johns and Sherrie Levine, are represented by classic pieces that retain their charisma even in an overcrowded installation (Cotter),

RUDY BURCKHARDT, New York Studio School, 8 West Eighth Street, Greenwich Village, (212)673-6466 (through tomorrow). This show of photographs and paintings by the Swiss-born photographer and filmmaker, who immigrated here in 1935, was assembled by the poet Vincent Katz. It focuses on Burckhardt's involvement with the forests, ponds, flowers and individual trees of Deer Isle, Me. His lovely, lyrical compositions range from a pastoral stream meandering through marsh grass to close views of lichen-covered trees. But when he tried to capture in oil what his lens recorded so well, the results are less than salubrious (Glueck).

FRANZ KLINE, C&M Arts, 45 East 78th Street, (212) 861-0020 (through today). Kline was the archetypal Abstract Expressionist, painter of the big, explosive gesture. But his paintings are also exquisitely elegant, as this nicely installed nine-piece show of black-and-white works on paper and canvas shows. While the wide swaths of black that tumble like giant logs across "Harleman" suggest impulsive violence, the composition tells a story of order and chaos captured in a moment of perfect equilibrium (Johnson).

"NOGUCHI: CONTOURS," UBS PaineWebber Art Galleries, 1285 Avenue of the Americas, at 51st Street, (212) 713-2885 (through today). Organized by the Noguchi Foundation's curator, Bonnie Rychlak, this show stresses the role of the body in the sculptor's work. It spans 1926 to 1982, and the pieces range from portrait heads to the paper-on-silk scroll drawings that Noguchi (1904-1988) made during an early visit to China (Glueck).

* TONY OURSLER, Metro Pictures, 519 West 24th Street, Chelsea, (212) 206-7100 (through tomorrow). Mr. Oursler returns to the deceptively simple device that made him famous, and has his best exhibition in years. Mobile human features are video-projected in luridly over-ripe color onto simple, bulbous white sculptures. Giant mismatched eyes, fat lips and big, snaggly teeth (no noses) make up weird, comical and oddly endearing characters. Their angry, anxious, erotic and nonsensical monologues enhance feelings of emotional confusion and vulnerability (Johnson).

* "TRANSMITTING THE FORMS OF DIVINITY: EARLY BUDDHIST ART FROM KOREA AND JAPAN," Japan Society, 333 East 47th Street, (212) 832-1155 (through Sunday). The role of Korea in the development of Buddhist art and thought in Japan and therefore in the formation of Japanese culture itself emerges from decades of habitual marginalization in this beautiful exhibition. Dominated by meditating Buddhas and handsomely attired bodhisattvas dating from the sixth to the ninth centuries, the show, organized with the Korea Society of New York, highlights the forceful stylization and subtle abstraction of the human figure, which, while common in Asian and African art, is rarely equaled in Western sculpture between the medieval and modern periods. Hours: Today, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; tomorrow and Sunday, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; $3, students and 65+ (Smith).

HEADLINE: Spring Street, a Stroll for All Seasons 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD LOURIE; Richard Lourie's latest book is "Sakharov: A Biography."

 BODY:
I grew oblivious to Spring Street. It was bound to happen. It's the street I take to leave my neighborhood at the west end of Canal Street, it's the street I take to get home. Over time it became no more than a stretch of cement between me and where I was going. But this year, after a winter like a recession that wouldn't quit, I decided to stretch my legs and walk the length of the street to where it dead-ends at the Bowery. 
 The first thing I discovered was that Spring Street was eminently strollable -- long enough to be invigorating but not so long as to be wearying. The pace is naturally leisurely because there is so much variety at ground level with nary a dull block en route. Its contrasts are startling. At one end there's the bar-restaurant Ear Inn, in a building dating from 1817; at the other the new rice-pudding-only Rice to Riches, whose design style is 22nd-century Jetsons futurismo -- from "Gangs of New York" to "Close Encounters of the Third Kind" all on a single street. 
 As I walked, I also saw that cross streets make cross sections. Spring Street bisects three neighborhoods -- a still nameless stretch between West Street and the Avenue of the Americas followed by SoHo and an area north of Little Italy often called NoLIta. All three are examples of artists' districts discovered and then commercialized, but all three are in very different stages of the process, SoHo being the most advanced. 
Glanced into from its perimeters, the little anonymous enclave between the Hudson and Hudson -- the river and the street -- can seem forbidding, industrial, bleak: sanitation trucks and three blocks' worth of U.P.S. vans are not the props of many fantasies. But that first impression would be doubly wrong. The neighborhood is unusually chummy and has some of the oldest buildings in the city, dating from the early 1800's. Behind the bar, the Ear Inn displays the detritus of decades past -- whiskey jugs and long clay Dutch pipes, entire vanished generations, outlasted by their trash. 
An art zone in the 70's and 80's when Roy Lichtenstein and Larry Rivers had studios nearby, this area was spared SoHo's commercialized fate because no galleries opened there. Geographically, it was far enough off the beaten track that it didn't even have a name -- not really SoHo, West Village or TriBeCa. The artists called it Limbo. Known as the Upper West Side in the early 19th century when New York was young and small and all downtown, it was later referred to as the Lower West Side. Current attempts like NoCa (North of Canal) or Hudson Square haven't stuck. Udi Behr, a local kibitzer of genius, has suggested UPStown. Who knows? It might fly.
This neighborhood may not have a name but it has a definite character and flavor. Still populated by painters and writers, along with designers, video people and the sort of young Hollywood actors who prefer lofts to bungalows, the neighborhood is marked by wit and offhand eccentricity. Around the corner on Greenwich Street is a window where poetry and agitprop appear, like one sign that has President Bush saying: "Why should I care what the majority of the American people think? They didn't even vote for me."
Next door, at 488 Greenwich, is a rare-cookbook store whose proprietor, Joanne Hendricks, displays in her window offerings like "Sandwich Manual for Professionals." (Add lunchmeat B to bread slice A . . .) A few steps farther toward Spring is Castillo, a little theater that specializes in ethnic and political drama, which will be moving to Theater Row (543 West 42nd Street) in the fall. The southwest corner of Spring and Greenwich is Iberian: Pinxtos, a restaurant gem of authenticity and artistry, is Basque; Pao, Portugese, manages to be cozy and sexy all at once, and Kana, which serves tapas, has the late-night crackle of Spain.
The north side of the street has gone a little ritzy of late. A newrestaurant named Spring Street specializes in truffles; Giorgione, whose part owner is Giorgio DeLuca of Dean & Deluca, guaranteeing exquisite freshness of produce, is already threatening to become the Elaine's of downtown.
Other than the high-end furniture store Wyeth, this part of town is essentially shopless. But there are clubs, bars and lounges like Noca, Sway and the scruffy, semilegendary Don Hill's. What will probably doom this neighborhood to development and overdevelopment is not celebrity like SoHo's but something much simpler: riv vu.

Hip Clubs and Fire Museum
The two blocks of Spring between Hudson and the gates of SoHo at the Avenue of the Americas seem to belong to no part of the city, have no quality of neighborhood, are just pure downtown. At night a few clubs set out their bouncers and velvet ropes to herd their clientele -- young, overdressed, braving obstacles of weather and indignity in the firm belief that something at the other end will make it all worthwhile. 
Yet that block also has the New York City Fire Museum at No. 278, which first attracts the eye with its etched glass image of firefighters in profile and a video display of 9/11. For the country and the world the twin towers have become symbolic, iconic. Their meaning downtown is more down to earth. Sept. 11 was not only an attack on the country and city but on the neighborhood as well. The towers are what's missing when you cross Hudson and look south for oncoming cars.
What is best about the Fire Museum is the Americana -- in one case, a stuffed dog, the heroic companion of firemen who could not bear to part with him, a street mutt all heart. Just as wonderful is the red and gold beauty of the old fire engines, their ornate brass gleaming. A hand-drawn hose reel from the Long Island City Fire Department from 1875 is strikingly elegant.
Before 1865 all fire departments were volunteer and they vied with each other in dash and bravery, in baseball, parades and, aesthetically, in a range of objects used in parades and ceremonies; some, like the presentation shields, are particularly handsome. A red, slender horse-drawn fire sleigh of the 19th century reminds us of days when Lower Manhattan was mostly meadow and springs did indeed gush from the ground -- whence Spring Street derives its name.
The area's history is colorful and rowdy. George Washington was headquartered there; later it was chockablock with saloons and fishmongers, free black oystermen and home to the Boodle Gang -- infamous for garroting. During the Depression the west end of Spring Street was a Hooverville -- a shantytown for the homeless and jobless. There was once an El on Greenwich Street constructed with fanfare and now gone without a trace.

SoHo: The Next Generation
Eccentricity and experimentation may be long gone from SoHo itself, but it lives on at its western border at the Avenue of the Americas. A complex of theaters, an art gallery and a cafe, all existing under the general name Here Arts Center, preserve a bit of the flavor of those bygone days when art was more adventure than career. ACE Gallery on Hudson Street has the same feel of authenticity, but it operates on a larger, more professional scale.
SoHo is in very bad odor with the culturati. Those who still live there try to slip unseen out of their front door as if leaving assignations. The galleries have fled like startled pigeons, mostly to Chelsea, some to 57th Street. The fabled Spring Street Bookstore near West Broadway has now become a clothing emporium. It may still be possible to write a novel in SoHo, but not to buy one. 
Though SoHo has become a district of fashion, furniture and fine dining, traces of its previous incarnations can still be spotted. Vesuvio Playground, at Thompson Street, named for an old renowned Italian bakery on Prince Street one block north, is a little more than half an acre surrounded by chain link, with netless basketball hoops and hard wooden benches painted a deep municipal green. Old-timers from the neighborhood might reminisce here over a slice from Ben's Pizza at No. 177 about what the place was like even before the artists came and went.
And most of the restaurants in this section intersected by Sullivan and Thompson Streets are Italian -- Fiamma, L'Ulivo, Mezzegiorno -- ready to spill out onto the sidewalk at the slightest provocation of a warm breeze. Prince Street boasts the classic cafes Borgia and Tina, but Spring Street does have an establishment that is decidedly offbeat, Mix, half cafe, half shoe store. There's a touch of old SoHo cheekiness in that combo.
Charles Darwin would probably be as surprised to find himself on the British 10-pound note as to learn that Evolution is a store at 120 Spring that sells everything from saber-tooth tiger skulls (reproductions) to freeze-dried mice (real). For some reason, creationism has yet to inspire any boutiques. In any case, Evolution, the store, is a reminder that the ferocious change that marks New York is a law of nature.
In a way SoHo's evolution was fitting. It wasn't high-tech or medical offices that opened after the artists left but restaurants, furniture stores, clothing shops and establishments devoted to makeup -- Mary Boone replaced by Helena Rubenstein, Castelli by Armani. There's a certain continuity there as well, the beauty of art giving way to the beauty of adornment, the distance between triptych and lipstick shorter than suspected.

World of Artsy Commerce
Even in the blocks between West Broadway and Broadway there are some glimmers of the old SoHo, though some may postdate SoHo's demise. The open-air clothing and jewelry market at the corner of Wooster Street has that been-around-forever feel. Flint Butera, an artist who sells his work on the street, has been dodging the cops, critics in blue, for 13 years. And there are some nice contrasts. The classic bistro Balthazar -- vast, mirrored, celebratory -- is across the street from the Open Center, a "spiritual supermarket" where people are more concerned with past lives than today's dinner.
"You know what NoLIta stands for?" asked a woman with whom I'd struck up a conversation on Spring Street east of Broadway.
"Sure," I said, "North of Little Italy."
"Wrong," she said. "No Low-Income Tenants Allowed."
Wistful, bitter, the joke was simultaneously nostalgic and prophetic. Would the neighborhood simply be a rerun of SoHo, high rents squeezing out the creative spirits who gave the place its personality in the first place? But that may not be the right template at all. NoLIta was always a place of artsy commerce, of the "'sensibility store" that showcased its owner's taste and skill while also being a venue for vending its products. New additions to the neighborhood like the glowing futurist Rice to Riches and Cafe Lebowitz, with its Mitteleuropean decor and cuisine, are both examples of high design in the service of attracting customers.
It is a quarter of the young, judging by the clientele packing bars like Sweet and Vicious at No. 5 or easygoing eateries like Bread at No. 20; for the younger generations the conflict between art and commerce was never so pronounced as it was for preceding ones. 
The real clue to the future may be found in Spring Street's second etched-glass figure, that of Bruce Lee in the window of the storehouse of SSUR, whose outlet is at 219A Mulberry. The end of Spring Street north of Little Italy might yet be absorbed into an expanding Chinatown. The present will become another stratum of the past. Future historians will puzzle over the early 21st century when people could buy cigarettes in drugstores but couldn't smoke them in bars.

HEADLINE: Planes Fly Off the Line, But Not Alwaysto the Sky 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WONG 

DATELINE: TOULOUSE, France, June 19 

 BODY:
One day they will carry 150 people 37,000 feet above the earth, but at the moment these hulks are no more glamorous than television sets on an assembly line.
 Dozens of men crawl over the 110-foot fuselages of the Airbus A320 at the company's main plant here, drilling, vacuuming and laying cables. Wings will be attached, computers installed. In 10 weeks, crews will fly them to the far corners of the world. 
 And so it goes, maybe five planes at a time in this cavernous hangar, 20 a month. 
But both Airbus and the Boeing Company, its main rival, are as vulnerable now to the airline slump as at any time in the last two years, with no solid signs that the market for planes will improve soon.
Industry experts say several factors, including a glut of aircraft parked in the desert, could lead customers to defer deliveries. Banks and other financial institutions have shied away from financing purchases of aircraft because of their plummeting values. And some experts say that despite new jet designs from Airbus and Boeing, it is unclear whether the two are investing in the right kinds of planes for future travel needs -- especially as smaller jet makers like Embraer encroach on sales of 100-seat planes.
Debate has emerged over whether there are simply too many planes, and whether the production rate is making matters worse. There are more than 2,100 parked planes, according to most estimates, and aerospace executives and analysts say more than 500 of them could return to service.
"There are some people who believe there is a paradigm shift, that there are too many aircraft, just as there are too many cars, too much telecommunications capacity," said Robert Lamb, a professor of management at the Stern School of Business at New York University, who studies the industry.
Both Airbus and Boeing "will have the tendency to keep the rate up," he added. "They do not believe this is a sort of death-defying point of no return. They do not recognize this is a paradigm shift and they're in trouble. Both of them are going for the gold ring. They may act in ways that may seem irrational."
At the Paris Air Show this week, some Airbus and Boeing executives acknowledged that the industry had problems, though no one suggested that there was overcapacity.
"The three years ahead will be difficult for all industry players and for Airbus, too," Noel Forgeard, chief executive of Airbus, said at a news conference. The recent weakening of the dollar only compounds the difficulty of exporting from Europe, he added. Yet he said he remained confident that Airbus would deliver 300 planes this year and 900 planes between 2003 and 2005.
Alan Mullaly, who heads Boeing's commercial plane division, said his company would deliver 280 planes this year and 275 to 300 next year. Next year's estimate, he said, takes into account any softening in the market or possible deferrals.
Some experts see those numbers as overly optimistic. For one thing, they say, the airline industry will almost certainly not see real recovery until 2005 at the earliest.
Hossein Amir-Aslani, head of the airline and aerospace group at J. P. Morgan Chase, said at a recent talk in Paris that many analysts doubted whether Boeing and Airbus could meet their delivery goals. "I think they have a right to be skeptical," he said. A number of deliveries are set for Asian carriers that have suffered serious drops in passenger traffic caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome, he noted. The return of planes from the desert, he added, could be especially bad news for aircraft makers.
John Leahy, chief commercial officer at Airbus, said that only a "very, very small number" of parked planes belonged to companies with backlog orders at Airbus. Likewise, Randy Baseler, vice president of Boeing's commercial airplane division, said his company did not expect to be much affected by planes coming out of the desert.
Airbus and Boeing executives at the air show did not address the possibility that even more planes could end up in the lots, a distinct possibility given the precarious state of many airlines.
"All eyes are on American," an executive of a large leasing company said. American Airlines, the world's largest carrier, is struggling to avoid a trip to bankruptcy court. American has a long-term storage contract with Avtel Services in Mojave, Calif., and Justin Loucks, Avtel's general manager, estimated that a Chapter 11 filing could add 60 planes to his lot.
In addition, airlines are trying desperately to cut capacity and to simplify their fleet types, strategies that require parking planes. Airline executives estimate that capacity must still come down about 15 percent in the United States before airlines can gain enough leverage over seat supply to charge higher prices.
The more planes it has in the desert, the more options an airline has. It could buy parked planes from their owners, whether leasing companies or other airlines, for less than it would pay for new planes from Boeing or Airbus.
Yet it would be tough for either Airbus or Boeing to decide to cut production, Mr. Leahy said, because doing so could result in a loss of market share.
Airbus has a backlog of about 1,500 orders right now, or five years' production at the current rate. Boeing's backlog is roughly 1,100. There can be long-term advantages to churning out planes quickly: the more planes that are out there, the more money a manufacturer can make on plane servicing and spare parts, Professor Lamb said.
Michael Allen, chief operating officer of Back Aviation Solutions, an industry consulting firm in Connecticut, said European labor laws made it tough for Airbus to slow production. Boeing is laying off 5,000 people this year, on top of 30,000 jobs cut since the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. Airbus has not laid off any of its 46,000 workers.
Outside of questions on the rate of plane production, people in the industry are asking whether the two big manufacturers are reacting quickly enough to the growing challenge from Embraer, the Brazilian jet maker, which now has a product that can compete with the smallest planes made by Airbus and Boeing.
This month, JetBlue surprised the industry by ordering 100 Embraer 190's, valued at $3 billion, rather than the similar-size A318 from Airbus. JetBlue's fleet consists entirely of Airbus A320's, and low-cost airlines have traditionally remained profitable by sticking to one plane type, saving on labor and maintenance. But David Neeleman, the chief executive of JetBlue, obviously saw better economies in buying Embraer jets.
In May, US Airways ordered 170 regional jets, evenly split between Embraer and Bombardier. The airline's executives had managed to loosen clauses in the pilots' contract that limited the size of such jets. Other major airlines in the United States have recently negotiated similar concessions from pilots, so regional jet makers can now offer planes to those airlines to compete against Airbus A318's and Boeing 717's, both 100-seaters.
"You're not talking about a typical regional aircraft that the industry grew up with; you're talking about a mainline-look-and-feel aircraft," Robert W. Mann, an industry consultant in Port Washington, N.Y., said of the Embraer 190. "It's generally what business travelers want. There's some operating cost penalties that come with that, but you can't lose as much money with a small airplane as with large ones."
When asked whether Airbus considered the Embraer a threat, Gerard Blanc, vice president for programs, said Airbus' priorities were in developing planes in the 400-seat range.
Mr. Mullaly, the Boeing executive, was not aware that Embraer 190's had 100 seats. "You should check on that," he said when a reporter told him. He added that Boeing was not focused on the market for planes of that size.
As expected, Airbus and Boeing spent much of the Paris Air Show arguing over the competing philosophies behind their new jet designs: the gigantic A380 from Airbus, which will seat 550 or more passengers and has already received 129 orders, and the midsize 7E7 from Boeing, created to be more fuel-efficient than similar-size planes.
But it is doubtful that low-cost airlines -- and they are the only consistently profitable ones these days -- will buy those planes. If JetBlue makes money off the Embraers, that could mean big shifts in the kinds of jets that are in demand. And that could change the very planes that workers at the Airbus factory here churn out month after month in the hope that the machines will spend more time in the sky than in the desert.

HEADLINE: U.S. Tariff on Hynix Chips Draws South Korean Protest 

BYLINE:  By DON KIRK 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, June 19 

 BODY:
The South Korean government said today that it would file a complaint with the World Trade Organization next week against the Bush administration's decision to impose a tariff of nearly 45 percent on chips made by Hynix Semiconductor. 
 The Finance Ministry said it would also challenge a preliminary decision by the European Union in April to impose 33 percent tariffs on Hynix's chips. 
 In each case, the imposed tariffs were based on allegations that the South Korean government had unfairly subsidized Hynix. The company, which has lost more than $7.5 billion over the last four years, is controlled by its creditors, including several banks that are largely state-owned. 
Competitors like Micron Technologies, an American company that at one point came close to buying Hynix's main assets, and Infineon Technologies of Germany have complained that the bailouts, loans and loan guarantees provided or arranged by the state-owned banks amounted to subsidies that violated trade treaties. 
South Korean officials fear that the tariffs imposed on Hynix will set a precedent for complaints against other South Korean exporters, many of which do business with the state-owned banks and benefited from the government's efforts to right the economy after the financial crisis of 1997-98. The finance minister, Kim Jin Pyo, said today that the government needed to demonstrate that it was not subsidizing exporters.
The United States Commerce Department said Tuesday that it would impose final tariffs of 44.71 percent on Hynix dynamic random access memory chips made in South Korea, somewhat less than the preliminary 57.37 percent tariff announced in April. The duties do not affect chips made at Hynix's plant in Eugene, Ore. 
The Commerce Department said that Samsung Electronics, the leading producer of memory chips, had also benefited from subsidies, but, at 0.04 percent of the value of its exports, the benefit was well below the 1-percent threshold for imposing tariffs. Micron, Hynix and Infineon rank second, third and fourth respectively in market share after Samsung.
South Korean officials said the United States had not presented enough evidence to show that the loans and loan guarantees were illegal subsidies.
South Korean officials said that though the government took over a number of banks during the economic crisis, they have had a free hand in making loans and have not acted at the state's behest in bailing out Hynix.
South Korean semiconductor exports have declined sharply, falling to $5.97 billion last year from $10.4 billion in 2000.
The dispute comes at a time when semiconductor sales appear to be improving after several years of deep slump. While Samsung has remained profitable because of its strengths in consumer electronics and other fields, Infineon, Micron and Hynix all posted losses in 2002.
