HEADLINE: Dayton Claims Its Airspace 

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN KINZER; STEPHEN KINZER is a cultural correspondent for The Times, based in Chicago.

 BODY:
LIGHT floods through large windows into the corner store in Dayton, Ohio, where two brothers began designing a machine that would revolutionize human life. They were Wilbur and Orville Wright, and their storefront bicycle workshop is a focal point of this year's celebration marking the 100th anniversary of their invention of the airplane.
 This workshop is one of those places that provoke reflection about life's mysteries. How, in this unremarkable room, did two seemingly ordinary men set out to solve a problem that had tantalized humanity since before the days of Icarus? Why did thousands of years of history and dreams culminate here? 
 This year's anniversary raises not only cosmic questions but also one that is quite prosaic: where was the airplane born? Many Americans would reflexively answer "Kitty Hawk," because it was there, above a North Carolina sandbar, that Wilbur and Orville Wright's contraption took to the air for the first time on Dec. 17, 1903. That grates on some people in Dayton, who take pains to point out that their city nurtured the Wrights, was the only home they ever had as adults, and was the place where they made their most important technical breakthroughs. 
Given those facts, it is perhaps appropriate that this year's celebration, Inventing Flight, will be centered in Dayton. It has been five years in the planning, and organizers have raised $27 million, most of it from private donors, to stage a 17-day party in downtown Deeds Park from July 3 to 20. There will be events connected to the Wrights, like a simulator that will give visitors a chance to feel the sensations of early flight, and more modern attractions like a prototype of a new Air Force jet fighter and a replica of the international space station, plus sound-and-light shows every night.
The North Carolina observances, scheduled to include the opening of new exhibitions and culminate with a re-enactment of the epochal flight on Dec. 17, will be on a much smaller scale. Those in Dayton are expected to be the biggest event in the city's history and draw more than half a million people; about one-tenth that number are expected at Kitty Hawk.
The Dayton celebration is doubling as a coming-out party for the city, which some local civic leaders say has been too reluctant to flaunt its history and rich inventive tradition. Over the last few years, as plans for this big show have advanced, the city has blossomed. Public grants have helped pay for several neighborhood renewal projects, and a new riverside park, a performing arts center and a lovely minor-league baseball stadium have been built. 
"Dayton's coming of age," said Mary Mathews, executive director of the Carillon Historical Park, a campus-style museum where Wright Brothers artifacts hold pride of place. "We're not just second to Cincinnati or Cleveland. We have a lot to offer of our own."
In recent years the Wright Brothers have passed out of most living memory and become distant figures. Visiting Dayton, especially this year, is a way to shake some of the historical dust off them. They were sons of a clergyman who was often away from home. Their mother, whose own father had been a carriage maker in his native Germany, was mechanically inclined. She and her children played with unusual toys, including a rubber-band-powered propeller on a stick that could rise into the air.
When they were still teenagers, the brothers built a printing press from scrap material and opened a print shop. Later they became bicycle mechanics, and then began manufacturing their own bikes. By the turn of the century, fired by the example of the German glider pioneer Otto Lilienthal, they were transfixed by the idea of powered flight. They built their first airplane on the same workbenches where they repaired bicycles.
To test their plane, the brothers searched for a place that was flat, breezy and far from prying eyes. They chose Kitty Hawk, took their various flying machines there by rail and boat four times between 1900 and 1903, and inscribed that isolated town's name in history. Today visitors can walk between markers that show the length of each of the four flights achieved on Dec. 17, 1903. The first, the great breakthrough, covered 120 feet. Orville Wright was at the controls. He flew for 12 seconds, at an altitude that never exceeded 12 feet.
By 1904, the Wrights had decided that they needed a testing ground closer to home, and arranged to use a prairie clearing near Dayton. It was here in 1905, at what is now known as the Huffman Prairie Flying Field, that they flew what they called the world's first practical airplane. The one they had at Kitty Hawk could only take off, stay airborne for a few seconds and then belly-flop onto the sand. Their 1905 model could be maneuvered in flight, kept airborne for as long as the fuel held out, and landed easily and repeatedly.
Today, license plates in North Carolina carry the motto "First in Flight." Those in Ohio say "Birthplace of Aviation." Both are correct, just as both states are justified in depicting Wright airplanes on their quarters: the 1903 model for North Carolina and the 1905 one for Ohio.
Visitors to Dayton during July will throng to the little workshop at 22 South Williams Street, where the spark of genius once flashed so brilliantly. This is the only one of the Wrights' five bicycle shops that still stands on its original site, and was their base of operations from 1895 to 1897. Here they first decided to embrace the challenge that would make them immortal, as they later recalled in a magazine article: "It was not until the news of the sad death of Lilienthal reached America in the summer of 1896 that we again gave more than passing attention to the subject of flying." The workbenches, the drafting table and the building's floor are original. Some of the tools on display were actually used by the Wrights.
On the walls hang copies of several cartoons that were published in Dayton newspapers during the years when the Wright Brothers were active. One, drawn soon after they became world famous, has a panel set in 1904 in which scowling locals watch an early flying test and one scoffs "Look at 'em -- the durned loonies!" The second panel, dated 1908, shows the brothers being decked with honors in Europe while the same local man proudly claims, "I always said the boys were wonderful inventors."
Orville and Wilbur Wright displayed flamboyant imaginations as they reached a triumph that many people believed was beyond humanity's reach. There was nothing else flamboyant about them, however. Both were painfully shy and ill at ease in social situations. Neither ever married. Wilbur (he was the older by four years, the one without the mustache) died of typhoid in 1912 at the age of 45. Four years later, Orville sold the family's aircraft company and took his last flight as a pilot. He lived until 1948, long enough to see his invention change the world, but never again sought a central role in the industry he helped found.
The Wrights' childhood home is no longer in Dayton; Henry Ford bought it and moved it to Dearborn, Mich., in 1936 as part of his plan to bring together the homes of great inventors. But Hawthorn Hill, where Orville lived the last 34 years of his life, still stands, and although it is normally closed to the public, organizers of the July celebration have arranged to open it for a limited number of tours during this summer. 
The house is stately and white-columned outside, and Orville's study has been preserved as he left it, dim and Victorian in style. His bookshelves hold works by Kipling and Ibsen, a biography of Oscar Wilde and a 61-year set of the Ohio Archaeological and Historical Quarterly. The house also has several gadgets Orville designed, including a shower that sprayed water on his body from three sides to help soothe pain he suffered after a plane crash in 1908.
Some of Dayton's Wright-related sites were being renovated and expanded when I visited in May, but all are expected to be ready for the big July bash. Principal among them are the inventors' bicycle workshop and adjacent print shop, where blobs of ink apparently spilled by the Wrights still soil the floor; the Huffman Prairie Flying Field, which can legitimately be called the world's first airport; Hawthorn Hill, where Orville Wright received a steady flow of admirers during his later years; and Carillon Historical Park, where the prize exhibit is the plane the Wrights flew in 1905 (the 1903 model is at the Air and Space Museum in Washington). 
Although Dayton and Kitty Hawk will be the centers of this year's festivities, other communities are also participating. At Rockefeller Center in New York, for example, a display of planes and rocketry will be on view from July 29 to Aug. 18. One of its centerpieces will be a replica of the 1903 plane that will be flown at Kitty Hawk in December.
"For some years," Wilbur Wright wrote as he and his brother began their historic work in Dayton, "I have been afflicted with the belief that flight is possible for man." This year's anniversary is a chance to recognize how completely that affliction reshaped transportation and warfare, altered humanity's concept of distance, and shattered ancient ideas about the limits of the possible. 

One giant leap for mankind

LENGTH: 1519 words

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island; 
A Model Program to Rehabiliate Homes in Freeport

BYLINE:  By CAROLE PAQUETTE

 BODY:
IN looking for a rundown property last winter to highlight a new federal program that would rehabilitate houses in lower income neighborhoods, the Community Development Corporation of Long Island turned to officials of the South Shore village of Freeport, where the corporation has its Nassau County office. 
 "Four local residents recommended by the mayor went out on a Saturday knocking on doors in one of the oldest sections of Freeport asking to rehabilitate them," said Marianne Garvin, executive vice president of the nonprofit corporation. "There was a lot of skepticism, but then they found Carrie Mays, and she said yes." 
 A certified nursing assistant making $400 a week, Mrs. Mays has lived in her 80-year-old four-bedroom house since 1975. Mrs. Mays's daughter -- a secretary who makes about $300 a week -- also lives in the house, with her three children, and shares the $1,500-a-month mortgage payments. 
Mrs. Mays said she welcomed having her two-story house fixed up. Once it was evaluated by the Community Development Corporation, the house turned out to need almost $50,000 worth of work to make it safe and energy-efficient, which is the goal of the new program. This included new ceilings, doors, insulation, kitchen floor and carpeting. The entire house also needed to be painted and the sun porch rescreened.
Mrs. Mays passed all the requirements for eligibility in the program, and within four months the house had new vinyl siding, the porch screens were on and rehabilitation was well on its way and is expected to be completed this month. 
On June 7, a team of volunteers painted the interior during a special celebration that formally announced the Weatherization, Rehabilitation and Asset Preservation program. It is the first nationwide program of this kind, although it is modeled after a similar Long Island program. 
Mrs. Mays's home is one of 195 in the village of Freeport that are to be worked on under the WRAP program, which combines federal, state and local home rehabilitation and energy-saving grants. The program is expected to lower electric bills by 25 to 35 percent, increase property values in the neighborhood and help low-income homeowners preserve their home assets. 
The program was initiated in December 2002 by the 50-year-old Ford Foundation, the giant philanthropic organization. The nationwide WRAP program is being modeled after the Community Development Corporation's two-year-old Loss Prevention Program, which receives grants from the New York State Affordable Housing Corporation and the federal Department of Energy. The program has spent $2,372,266 to rehabilitate 496 houses throughout Long Island with an average household income of $14,694.
George McCarthy, the foundation's program officer in development, finance and economic security, said he approached the Community Development Corporation to set up a three-year pilot program in a concentrated area of Freeport. While the approach is similar, the rehabilitation money comes from the federal government, instead of the state.
"The Community Development Corporation has one of the most innovative and comprehensive programs in the country; they do a lot of post-purchase assistance," Mr. McCarthy said. "My goal is to use their program as a model and create a national program. 
"We were looking for innovative responses to the lack of an adequate home improvement industry for the lower-income communities," he said. "That kind of service seems to have disappeared from low-income housing about 30 years ago. That is because the houses were older, the jobs more difficult and the owners had less money to fix them up. 
"As a result many of these people were getting bad services, which introduced them to predatory loans. We are trying to help those with low income protect their assets and keep their houses."
The foundation has selected 12 nationwide sites to participate in the WRAP program; each will receive $100,000 a year for three years to cover administration and education costs.
Freeport is the first of six projects to begin this year. The others are in Hartford; Chattanooga, Tenn.; Rio Grande City, Tex.; and two in Boston. Next year, projects will begin in Staten Island and New Orleans, according to Mark Wolfe, executive director of the nonprofit Energy Programs Consortium, which awards the Ford Foundation grants. 
Two major federal grants were received from the Fannie Mae Foundation, which gave Freeport $50,000 for the first year, and the Neighborhood Reinvestment Corporation, which gave $30,000.
In Freeport, the energy-saving projects will be financed through a $60,000 three-year grant from the Freeport Electric Company, the village's municipally owned power company; $180,000 from the State Energy Research Development Association; and $600,000 from the federal Department of Energy. 
The money for rehabilitation work includes $150,000 from Nassau County for the first year. An application for $500,000 from the state is pending.
Freeport's three-year goal is to weatherize and rehabilitate 195 of the 1,520 houses in the northeast region of the village, said Ms. Garvin. "That is more than 10 percent of that region, the number that a research team from the University of North Carolina feels is necessary to encourage others in the neighborhood to invest in their homes," she said.
According to William F. Glacken, Freeport's mayor, the targeted area had been neglected for 30 years until six years ago, when some rehabilitation began. "These are sturdy houses, but the stock needs a facelift and the WRAP program is perfect to bring the housing back," he said. "These are not tenements or dilapidated houses; they are just tired."
THE average Freeport house sells for $200,000, he said, adding that the median income in the village is $60,000, except in the northeast quadrant, where the median is $40,000. (Currently, the median household income on Long Island for a family of four is $83,700.)
Since Freeport's WRAP program began in December, four houses have been rehabilitated, 14 are in progress, 16 have been put out to bid and there are 60 homeowners on the waiting list, Ms. Garvin said. 
There are strict regulations for eligibility in the program. Applicants' incomes must fall below 80 percent of the median household income for Long Island. They must have their names on the house's deed, have homeowner's insurance and be current on their taxes.
Once the work is completed, a lien is placed on the house for the total cost of the project. If the homeowner remains in the house for five years, the lien is forgiven, but if the homeowner or dies within five years, the cost must be repaid.
"We try to stay within $4,000 and $6,000 per house for the energy work and below $15,000 for rehabilitation," Ms. Garvin said. If a house needs more than $21,000 in grant money, the homeowner is referred to Freeport's residential rehabilitation program.
In the case of Mrs. Mays, $20,866 was spent in grant money to cover the project, and another $28,000 came in donated labor from four different local contractors.
Recently, Freeport hosted a gathering of officials who will be setting up WRAP programs in other states. Included was a visit to three homes, including Mrs. Mays's, which have been approved for projects.
One of the houses is a 83-year-old brick and stone four-bedroom Dutch colonial owned by Delores Rivas, who lives in the house with her daughter and four grandchildren.Her two mortgages, which total $702.02 a month, are paid predominantly with child support and Social Security money. The Community Development Corporation is currently helping Mrs. Rivas, who has lived in the house for 20 years, to get her name on the deed since her husband, who was listed alone on the deed, died without a will. Until then, rehabilitation work cannot proceed, but in the meantime the $11,280 energy portion of the project, including a new roof and weatherstripping, has been completed. 
A short distance away, a 75-year-old three-bedroom white house with pink trim, owned by Caprice Bateman, will receive a $20,950 renovation that includes a $2,600 lead-abatement project. Ms. Bateman, a corrections officer at Rikers Island, makes $59,000 a year and has a monthly mortgage payment of $1,700. She has lived in the house for five years with her three children. The WRAP project includes replacing a rear stoop, the roof, interior stairways and the front door and insulating the attic.
In observing the Freeport neighborhood, Kevin Washington, the loss prevention coordinator for Staten Island's WRAP program, said it was "similar to Staten Island, only our houses are a little older."
The Staten Island program manager, Richard Trouth, said about 15 houses would be involved in the northern part of the borough, in a section where the annual median income is $35,000 to $42,000.
Katherine Bequary, senior research analyst for Hartford's Community Renewal Team, will be operating the WRAP program in the north-end Blue Hills neighborhood, where the home ownership rate is 55 percent, the highest of any Hartford neighborhoods, she said. Approximately 70 homes are to be rehabilitated.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Owen Peterkin, a volunteer, paints the home of Carrie Mays as part of the Weatherization, Rehabilitation and Asset Preservation program. (Kirk Condyles for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/New Jersey; 
An Industry-Government Team Lures Backup Sites

BYLINE:  By ANTOINETTE MARTIN

 BODY:
NEW rules that say financial companies doing business crucial to the national economy must be able to resume operations within 24 hours of a major emergency have led to formation of a New Jersey group that seeks to work with companies that might put backup offices in the state.
 The new consortium includes two large real estate companies, the Gale Company and Cushman & Wakefield; Verizon; the Public Service Electric and Gas Company; and state authorities, including the Commission on Commerce, the Economic Development Authority, the Commission on Science and Technology and the Urban Enterprise Zone Authority. 
 Gil Medina, a former state commerce commissioner who now directs Cushman & Wakefield's technology enterprise group, said his company and Gale were recently working to establish a backup office for New York Life in Westchester County when the idea of setting up the consortium occurred to them.
"We felt it was important to bring together public and private bodies in New Jersey to provide a service to those impacted by the new requirements," Mr. Medina said. "Not to take away from New York, because everyone in the region has an interest in New York City prospering. It is the economic engine. But many top-tier financial institutions have been affected by the new regulations -- and New Jersey, like many areas of New York outside Manhattan, is fertile ground for the stakeholders." 
A promotional letter for the new consortium describes New Jersey's potential as a backup site like this: "Imagine a secure, reliable and economical network of satellite centers in the New York metro area that are all linked together -- and to the core -- by a modern transit system and highway system, with an ample supply of specialized workers, expertise, communication infrastructure, water and power, all integrated with central operations in New York but functioning independently of the New York-based operations."
A year after the attack on the World Trade Center buildings, federal securities industry regulators released a report emphasizing the need for financial institutions to have out-of-town backup facilities. In its initial form, the report, the Interagency White Paper on Sound Practices to Strengthen the Resilience of the United States Financial System, required backup sites to be 100 to 250 miles from Manhattan.
According to the final version of the report released this spring, however, companies may choose their own locations as long as they can assure the authorities that they have arranged for a secondary office ensuringthe speedy restart of business after a disaster.
"The New Jersey White Paper Consortium was formed to provide firms the support and flexibility they need to create backup sites," Mr. Medina said, "taking advantage of New Jersey's strengths, while minimizing the impact on New York City's economy."
Mark Yaeger, Gale's president, said that changes in technology permitted companies to put their backup offices farther away. "It used to be that with information traveling through cable and wiring beyond about 25 miles, speed and quality and security of transmission became potentially jeopardized," he said.
"Now, that's not so much true, but the quality of fiber optics available is still crucial. And the human travel distance is still very important. In order to have a completely redundant facility, there is the need to be able to get people there quickly." 
Mr. Yaeger said that Gale executives had analyzed which financial service firms would be affected by the report's regulations, which would have the greatest concerns in the event of an "outage of critical facilities" and which would be most likely to find a good fit in New Jersey for a backup facility. 
The consortium is now setting up meetings with companies on that list, he and Mr. Medina said.
The Westchester County transaction that Gale and Cushman have already completed involved securing a 385,000-square-foot backup office for New York Life Insurance at the Mount Pleasant Executive Center. The partners have also recently completed two similar deals for emergency backup facilities in New Jersey: Deutsche Bank's lease of 200,000 square feet at 2 Gatehall Drive in Parsippany and First Fidelity Investments' lease of 87,000 square feet at 125 Chubb Avenue in Florham Park.
COMPANIES are permitted options under the new regulations in the type of contingency operation they plan, Mr. Medina said. "There are actually a ton of options," Mr. Yaeger added, "from creating a completely built-out dark site, ready to put the lights on when necessary, to, at the other extreme, just having a system for knowing what space is out there that your company could implement and not really having it in place."
For those firms performing critical financial roles that need space available in crisis situations, Mr. Yaeger said, vacant space is available in some buildings that Gale owns. "If the Gale options do not satisfy a company's requirement," he said, "then the full support of Cushman & Wakefield will be implemented to find a suitable building or site"
Cushman & Wakefield brokers and manages commercial properties but does not own any.
At this point, Mr. Yaeger noted, the federal regulations require every financial institution to have an emergency strategy in place, but not necessarily a building. He said that one allowable strategy was for financial institutions to rotate workers from their Manhattan offices regularly to secondary offices they have elsewhere so that the employees were able to function in both places.
Regulations require, however, that the secondary office be at least large enough to accommodate the basic number of staff members needed to keep all crucial business functions going in the event of disaster, he noted.
"Ideally," Mr. Medina said, "the secondary office is a mirror image of the primary office. But that may not be economical."
He said that New Jersey and other areas near major financial centers in New York City and Philadelphia, offered more economical sites for backup office plans because the cost of transporting employees would be lower. 
Also, these areas each offer state-sponsored business incentive programs that could help cut the cost of contingency space, Mr. Medina said.
"In addition, if companies cluster their back-office operations in this region, they can take advantage of a common pool of labor, expertise, specialized suppliers and infrastructure," he said. "To the extent that companies disaggregate, they lose economies."
When considering the overall picture for financial institutions needing backup, Mr. Medina said, a balance must be found between "some level of concentration, and some level of disaggregation."
That balance is expected to evolve, he said, based on individual companies' determinations about what is best for them.
THE report also requires firms that play significant roles in critical markets to have emergency backup plans that include sufficient equipment and data sources. That is why P.S.E.&G., which serves nearly three-quarters of the state's energy customers, and Verizon, which focused on "disaster survivability" in developing its current telecommunications systems, are part of the consortium, Mr. Medina said. 
"The ideal backup building has independent power, water and telecommunications capability," he said. "It is on a power grid fed by multiple substations, with a backup generator and, of course, excellent security.
"The consortium is designed to provide companies with the closest thing to ideal, based on the best information we have from those with the most expertise."

CORRECTION-DATE: June 29, 2003

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about an industry and government group that is marketing commercial space in New Jersey for use as emergency backup offices misspelled the surname of the president of the Gale Company, which is part of the consortium. (The error also occurred on April 26 and on Jan. 23, 2000.) He is Mark Yeager, not Yaeger. 
The article and the picture caption also misidentified the town in which space has been leased for a backup facility. The building is at 125 Chubb Avenue in Lyndhurst, not Florham Park.

HEADLINE: As Graduates Look for Work, The Engineer Is Standing Tall 

BYLINE:  By MELINDA LIGOS

 BODY:
As Susan Brewton prepared to graduate this spring with a degree in mechanical engineering from Virginia Polytechnic Institute, she lay awake at night fretting about the tough job market she was about to enter.
 She needn't have worried. Before she was even able to don her cap and gown, she had four job offers. Even after she accepted a position as an engineer for the Naval Surface Warfare Center in West Bethesda, Md., the calls from eager military contractors hoping to employ her kept rolling in. 
 "It was very flattering," said the 36-year-old Ms. Brewton, who worked as a journalist for 10 years before going back to school to pursue engineering. "My professors had told us all of these horror stories about getting a job in the down economy, but I didn't seem to have any trouble."
Ms. Brewton is undoubtedly among the cream of the crop of entry-level engineers. She graduated summa cum laude from a top engineering school and has three internships under her belt, not to mention 10 years of experience in the working world. And she had a keen interest in fluids and turbomachinery, something that impressed her new employer, a government research group that studies ships.
Even so, career experts in the engineering field say that Ms. Brewton's job-hunting experience is not so unusual.
In the weakest overall employment market in many years, the engineering field may be one of the few bright spots. According to a recent survey conducted by the National Association of Colleges and Employers, employers predicted that members of the class of 2003 with backgrounds in computer engineering, electrical engineering and mechanical engineering would be in high demand upon graduation. All three of those degrees were listed in the association's top 10 list of degrees that are considered most desirable by employers.
Experts predict the need for engineers in many sectors will only increase. Yet, the number of high school students interested in studying engineering in college has been on a steady decline. Among the more than 1.1 million seniors in the class of 2002 who took the ACT Assessment college entrance exam, less than 6 percent indicated they were planning on studying engineering in college, down from 9 percent in 1992.
One area that has heated up significantly is the military sector, where engineers are being heavily recruited to work for the newly created Department of Homeland Security, and for private companies that do contract work for the agency. With a proposed budget of $36.2 billion for 2004, the new department has more openings than qualified professionals to fill them, says Ken Selzer, president of Defense Placements, a Washington subsidiary of Management Recruiters International.
Mr. Selzer's team has recently been asked to find candidates with electrical engineering backgrounds to do classified communications work in the areas of border and transportation security. He has also been recruiting mechanical engineers with experience in installing air handling systems to help detect and prevent chemical and biological attacks.
Before the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, "there was always a demand for these kinds of people," Mr. Selzer said, but the need has "skyrocketed" in the last year. Complicating the search, many positions require government security clearances that can take a year to 18 months to complete.
As a result, Mr. Selzer typically limits his recruiting to candidates who already have them. Salaries average about $70,000 for people with three or four years experience, he said, with some engineers making upward of $120,000.
Some are even seeing a resurgence of demand for engineers at high-technology companies. Clint Staley, a professor of computer science at California Polytechnic State University in San Luis Obispo, says he has been pleasantly surprised this spring to be getting calls once again from employers looking for recent computer engineering graduates for jobs in software development. "It's been pretty quiet the last couple of years," Mr. Staley said.
AirPrism, a software start-up in Redwood Shores, Calif., has hired 18 engineers in the last several months to design and support hand-held devices. It plans to hire at least eight more by the close of the year, according to the president and chief executive, Steve Sommer.
Marc D. Lewis, North America president of Morgan Howard, a global executive-search firm for the technology industry, has been busy placing those with computer engineering backgrounds into high-level positions like chief security officer and chief information officer. "The market for technical talent has warmed up significantly in the last three months," he said. 
All of this is not to say that landing a job has suddenly become easy. Generalists are probably less desirable than engineers with niche specialties, for example, said Wayne Voris, a vice president for the Cincinnati office of Spherion Professional Recruiting. "Conventional wisdom says you should round yourself out, but that's not the case in engineering," Mr. Voris said.
Recent college graduates, in particular, need to be aggressive in their job hunting, recruiters say. Jamie Fox, who graduated this month with a degree in electrical engineering from California Polytechnic, says it took nearly nine months to secure a job offer from Mazzetti & Associates, an architectural engineering and consulting firm in San Francisco. 
He began looking for full-time work last fall, attending career fairs sponsored by his university. At such events, he said, you usually "give your resume to a bunch of people and no one ever calls you back." But at a fair in January, he took a more forceful approach, handing the people at the Mazzetti booth a list of reasons he wanted to work there, directing them to his personal Web site, and showing off his familiarity with the company by spouting information he had gleaned from its Web site.
He left the meeting all but securing the $50,000 position on the spot. "The C.E.O. joked with me and said, 'When can you start?' " Mr. Fox said. The lesson he drew from the experience: "You've got to search pretty hard, and be pretty determined."
Even Ms. Brewton, the Virginia Polytechnic graduate who was in such high demand while still in school, had to exert herself to be noticed. She spent her entire senior year going on interviews, some of them pretty grueling. For her final interview with the Naval Surface Warfare Center, her current employer, she was grilled from 7:30 a.m. through the late afternoon. Like Mr. Fox, she came armed with information about her employer that she had gathered not only from the Web but from employees she had contacted. "I already had a good feel for the job and what kinds of things I would be doing," she said. "By no means did I go in blind."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Susan Brewton, a journalist who went back to school to study engineering, had four job offers even before she graduated. (Evan Vucci for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE RIGHT THING; 
Wanted:Whistle-Blower Managers

BYLINE:  By JEFFREY L. SEGLIN; Jeffrey L. Seglin teaches at Emerson College in Boston and is the author of "The Right Thing: Conscience, Profit and Personal Responsibility in Today's Business" (Spiro Press). His column usually appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: righthng@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
SENIOR managers need to wake up. Rather than wallowing in the wreckage of corporate scandals and blaming a few overzealous chief executives or overeager young workers who might do anything to get ahead, managers need to step up, take responsibility for how business is done in their companies and, well, start managing.
 In most businesses, people know when bad behavior is going on. They know who's cutting corners. They know about suspect expense reports. They know when promises to customers are consistently unfulfilled. They especially know when their own work is undermined by a colleague. 
 Of course, not everyone is aware of every bit of misconduct, but rest assured that some workers see the various infractions as they occur. To paraphrase Edmund Burke, all that's necessary for evil workers to triumph is for good managers to do nothing.
Joseph L. Badaracco Jr., a professor of business ethics at Harvard Business School, said the solution is simple. "Managers need to make stronger efforts to let people know what the rules of the game are in their companies, what the bright lines are that shouldn't be crossed," he said. "If people are held accountable, it sends a very clear message."
If you accept the results of a survey released last month by the Ethics Resource Center, a nonprofit ethics training organization in Washington, a significant number of employees are speaking up. Of the 22 percent of the American workers who said they had witnessed misconduct in the workplace, almost two-thirds said they had reported the misconduct to management. But only 43 percent of younger workers -- those under 30 and with their companies less than three years -- said they had reported misconduct they had witnessed.
IT would be too easy to condemn callow youth entering the workplace as being solely responsible for letting unethical behavior go unchecked. Management may talk about the importance of ethics, but workers are likely to get their ethical cues from what they witness at work every day.
In the Ethics Resource Center survey, half of younger workers agreed with the statement, "My co-workers show respect for employees who get good results even if they use questionable ethics practices." Just 26 percent of other workers concurred. 
"It's a huge difference," said Joshua Joseph, a senior researcher at the center who designed the survey. "That's very troubling."
Again, the easy response would be to cast stones at young workers. Instead, if managers truly care about fostering an ethical workplace, it falls to them to stem this tide.
To expect that a younger worker will go against the norms of a workplace isn't just expecting ethical behavior, said Sharon Daloz Parks, the author of "Big Questions, Worthy Dreams: Mentoring Young Adults in Their Search for Meaning, Purpose and Faith" (Jossey-Bass, 2000). "It's expecting ethical heroism."
It is not heroic, however, for veteran managers to only do their jobs and let their employees know that questionable ethics will get them nowhere. If managers know that a rising star is using questionable tactics, they must also stand up to their own bosses who are rewarding the results.
Indeed, there is some evidence that younger workers would welcome a workplace where ethical behavior is more than just talk. A survey by the Aspen Institute asked students at 12 international M.B.A. programs what they would do if they found that their values conflicted with those of the company that employed them. The results, released last month, showed that 35 percent said they would very likely look for other jobs, while 44 percent said they would try to have others at the company join them in addressing their concerns. The response could be read as a positive indicator of willingness among younger workers to stay with a company and try to effect change, rather than ignoring it and moving on.
If managers take seriously the importance of ethical behavior in the workplace, they need to do a better job of letting all workers know what behavior will not be tolerated, that they will receive full support if they report misconduct, and that those guilty of misconduct will not catapult their way to the top but instead be held accountable for their actions. Such management behavior would send a clear signal to workers that being ethical in the workplace is career-enhancing -- and that any alternative is unacceptable.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS/CELEBRATIONS; 
Kristi Lazar, David Mazziotti

 BODY:
Kristi Lee Lazar, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daryl R. Lazar of Visalia, Calif., is to be married today to Dr. 
David Arthur Mazziotti, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Alexander R. Mazziotti of Hawthorne, N.J. The Rev. Thomas J. Mullelly, a Roman Catholic priest, will perform the ceremony at the Princeton University Chapel in Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Thomas E. Breidenthal, an Episcopal priest, will take part in the service.
 Mr. and Mrs. Mazziotti met at Princeton, from which he graduated summa cum laude and she received a master's degree in chemistry. She is a doctoral candidate in chemistry there. 
 The bride, 24, graduated summa cum laude from Westmont College in Santa Barbara, Calif. Her father manages a sulfur-refining plant in Earlimart, Calif., that belongs to the Wilbur-Ellis Company, an agricultural manufacturer. Her mother, Deborah Lazar, is a special-education teacher at Crestwood Elementary School in Visalia.
The bridegroom, 30, is an assistant professor of chemistry at the University of Chicago. He received a Ph.D. in chemical physics from Harvard. His mother, Janet E. Mazziotti, is the home-economics teacher at the Lincoln Middle School in Hawthorne. His father, an internist, practices in Hawthorne.

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
Reading, Writing and Now Checkbook Balancing

BYLINE:  By SUSAN B. GARLAND

 BODY:
BEFORE the end of the summer, scores of newly minted high school graduates will head off to college, on their own for the first time. How prepared are they to balance a checkbook, handle a credit card or budget an allowance? 
 Many new college freshmen will have to learn the hard way, by trial and error, but there is hope for those coming up behind them. Financial institutions and educators, as well as the federal government, are putting together courses, advice sheets for parents, interactive Web sites and other materials aimed at improving the personal finance skills of children, from preschoolers to teenagers. (You can even send your child to special summer camps to learn money management skills.) And though still in a minority, some school systems have added personal finance to their curriculums, teaching the fundamentals of saving, spending, investing and earning. 
 But part of the material, including some online offerings, may not be particularlyhelpful. Some information from banks or brokerage firms, for example, may seem more promotional than educational. And some Web sites have so much material that it requires patience, and maneuvering from page to page, to get through it all. 
Consumer groups and economic leaders, including the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, say that it is important for young people to learn money management skills, especially as more kinds of financial products become available. The increase in self-directed retirement accounts also means that workers need to become wiser savers and investors. 
Several recent studies suggest that young people have a long way to go in grasping personal finance skills. In one study, which was released in March by Teenage Research Unlimited, a market research group in Northbrook, Ill., teenagers reported that they spent 98 percent of the money they receive from parents, jobs and other sources.
IN another study, released last year by the JumpStart Coalition for Personal Financial Literacy, a nonprofit group in Washington that promotes the teaching of personal finance in schools, 68 percent of the 4,024 participating high school seniors flunked a set of personal finance questions, up from 59 percent in the previous survey, in 2000. 
Forty-two percent of the seniors said they didn't know that sales tax made purchased products more expensive; 92 percent didn't know that credit card holders were responsible for $50 in charges made on a stolen card.
Only four states -- New York, Kentucky, Illinois and Idaho -- require students to take a course that includes a personal finance unit, according to the National Council on Economic Education, a nonprofit group based in New York. 
Pooja Raju, 17, who will graduate from Benjamin N. Cardozo High School in Bayside, Queens, on Wednesday, said a required economics course had taught her how to balance a checkbook, use credit wisely and save early for retirement, among other things. 
In one class exercise, each student was assigned a hypothetical job and salary and had to figure out how to pay various bills. Now that Ms. Raju understands the fundamentals of personal budgeting, she plans to use her money from her summer job at J. P. Morgan Chase to buy a laptop computer for her first year at the State University of New York at Binghamton. "Before, I probably would have asked my parents for the money," she said. "But they're already spending so much on me; I'll put the money aside myself."
The economic education council and other organizations have been trying to persuade schools to include such classes, at least as part of math courses and other required classes. "Our goal is to make economic and personal financial decision-making skills the 'fourth R' -- the real world," said Robert F. Duvall, the council's president.
The steady proliferation of personal finance materials may make it easier for parents to teach financial concepts at home, and perhaps to learn a few things themselves. Resources include interactive Internet and software games, stock market simulations, lesson plans, workbooks and computer-based calculators. The materials are developed for use by parents and teachers or by children, and the topics range from the benefits of compound interest to spotting investment schemes.
One place to start is the JumpStart Coalition's Web site, www.jumpstart.org. Parents can find information about ordering more than 400 publications, including curriculum guides, government brochures, videos and books.
A search on the JumpStart site can be narrowed by age, from kindergarten to adult, and by topic, like credit cards or bankruptcy. Dara Duguay, the executive director of JumpStart, says all written materials are evaluated by an educational consultant for organization, objectivity, ability to capture a student's interest and independence from specific products.
One reason for the push for financial literacy is that some parents are not taking the lead. Less than half of parents with school-aged children stick to a budget or pay off their credit cards in each billing cycle, according to a 2001 survey by the American Savings Education Council, a nonprofit group in Washington that tries to raise public awareness of personal finance issues.
"Parents are often reluctant to talk about money, and perhaps that's related to the concern about practicing what we preach," Mr. Duvall said. "If we talk about handling credit wisely, we have to do that ourselves, and the fact is, we are not."
Some Web sites have been developed by large financial institutions, which regard improved financial literacy as good public relations and a way to attract future customers. "All of the financial services companies are self-promotional to a certain extent because they have products they want people to buy," Ms. Duguay said. "People have to make the judgment themselves whether a line has been crossed."
A Young Investors Network sponsored by the Smith Barney division of Citigroup (www.smithbarney.com/yin/home.htm) provides a tutorial on investments and allows visitors to create a "cyber stock portfolio" of real companies. The visitor learns about a stock by using Smith Barney research and can track the portfolio by logging in with a password. The site also informs teenagers that they can track real, future investments many ways, among them by visiting the Smith Barney Web site. The parents' section says children can learn about "financial responsibility with the prepaid Citi Cash Card," and has a link to that product. The site is used as part of a stock market contest among 150 classrooms in 15 states.
An A. G. Edwards site, accessible through www.agedwards.com by clicking on "Investor Education," includes a "Big Money Adventure." Aimed at 6- to 10-year-olds, it is a long story about two children who find some money in the jungle. The children have two choices: they can spend the money on items like tennis shoes and sunglasses, or they can invest it in Lucy the Bear's necklace business. If they decide to invest, they are told, they can make "a percentage or profit." 
The lesson, according to Max the Bird, is that when they leave the jungle, "you can do the same thing by investing in the stock market." Max does warn them, however, that "there is always" a chance you will lose money. 
Ms. Duguay says that some of the best corporation-backed sites and curriculums are those that have sought the help of organizations with experience in personal finance education or education in general. "Corporations don't understand anything about the educational system," she said. "The smart ones are pairing with nonprofits."
Two years ago, Bank of America provided $3.2 million through its foundation to help create Financial Fitness for Life, a curriculum for kindergarten through high school, with the National Council on Economic Education. About 18,000 teachers in 21 states and the District of Columbia have trained in the curriculum. 
Although the program was created primarily for schools, materials also are designed for home use. Guides for parents, including worksheets and activities for children of various age levels, are available for $11.95at www.fffl.ncee.net. The site also has sample interactive activities that a child can try first.
VISA U.S.A. designed a program with the help of nonprofit organizations, including the National Consumers League and the Women's Institute for Financial Education. Called Practical Money Skills for Life, the program is free and can be found at www.practicalmoneyskills.com. 
The site includes lesson plans for teachers, tips to help parents teach responsible money management, and games and activities. Each area is divided by age. In one section -- called "How Much Does It Really Cost?"-- Visa imparts some sobering lessons on the cost of credit. Visitors learn that a shopper who buys a $650 stereo on credit and makes the minimum payment will take 42 months to pay it off at an annual percentage rate of 19.85 percent, for a total cost of $887.44.
"Our responsibility is make sure students understand that a credit card is not free money and that it is a loan," said Rosetta L. Jones, director of corporate relations at Visa U.S.A.

Playing With Money, on the Web
HERE are a few personal finance Web sites geared toward youngsters.
* The Consumer Jungle, at www.consumerjungle.org. Sponsored by the Young Adult Consumer Education Trust. Teenagers learn about buying a car, credit cards and other financial topics as part of an online "safari." Guides for parents and teachers are included.
* Junior Achievement Personal Finance, at www.japersonalfinance.com. Sponsored by Junior Achievement and the Goldman Sachs Foundation. Teenagers learn about employment and career planning, budgeting and other topics.
* The Stock Market Game Program, at www.smgww.org. Offered by the Securities Industry Foundation for Economic Education. A 10-week simulation for classroom use allows participants to invest a hypothetical $100,000 in the stock market. The game is aimed at grades 4 to 12.
* National Council on Economic Education, at www.ncee.net. It offers programs for children of all ages -- and links to sites appropriate for different age groups. 
* Sense & Dollars, at www.mpt.org/senseanddollars. Sponsored by Maryland Public Television with grants from CitiFinancial, the Citigroup Foundation and the federal Department of Education. The site, aimed at middle school and high school students, includes games and information about spending, saving and earning money.
* Government sites. The federal government has several sites for young children. One, www.treas.gov/kids, has links to the United States Mint, the Bureau of the Public Debt and the Bureau of Printing and Engraving. 
* Practical Money Skills for Life, at www.practicalmoneyskills.com. Sponsored by Visa U.S.A. It includes lesson plans for teachers, tips for parents and games for children.
* JumpStart Coalition for Personal Financial Literacy, at www.jumpstart.org. It includes links to 175 Web sites aimed at children and information on 400 publications and other materials.
* Escape From Knab, at www.escapefromknab.com. A collaboration of U.S. Bank and educational consultants. Middle school and high school students take a virtual ride to Planet Knab, where they play interactive games and take part in activities to learn about taxes and making financial decisions. A guide for teachers is available.

HEADLINE: Business; 
Crate and Barrel Handles Its Offshoot With Care

BYLINE:  By JO NAPOLITANO

DATELINE: CHICAGO 

 BODY:
PEOPLE have been asking Gordon Segal for the last three years when he plans to build the second store of CB2, an eclectic offshoot of the Crate and Barrel chain, which he and his wife, Carole, started four decades ago. The answer is always the same: when he's good and ready.
 In an age when blind ambition causes many companies to expand at a breakneck pace, Mr. Segal, the chief executive of Crate and Barrel, is a perfectionist who would rather develop a chain slowly than allow it to swell beyond his control. After all, it took him six years to open the second Crate and Barrel, in 1968, and he says he will take the same approach in opening the second CB2. 
 "It's a laboratory store," he said during an interview in his office in Northbrook, Ill., a suburb about 25 miles north of here. "It's an experiment. You can do it much faster and better, but we do things carefully and slowly." 
The CB2 store, housed in an industrial-looking building with an angular, mesh metal awning, is between a Trader Joe's market and a noisy elevated-train stop in the trendy Lakeview section of Chicago. Like its more sophisticated predecessor, CB2 is neat, colorful and meticulouslyorganized, and it offers a variety of stylish housewares.
But CB2 strives to be hipper and more urban than Crate and Barrel, to reach younger shoppers who may be bored or intimidated by the original chain. To reach them, CB2 sells some tongue-in-cheek products that would never be found at Crate and Barrel, including a book of 1950's-inspired postcards with smiling housewives in calf-length dresses doting on their husbands and children while scrubbing floors or cooking.
The shelves at CB2 are lined with suede pillows, fake wheat grass "growing" inside rectangular tins, and drinking glasses decorated with recipes for fruity cocktails. Orange-colored gel-filled eye masks, made for people with hangovers, sit alongside a display of books titled "Office Spa: Stress Relief for the Working Week," which offers advice on how to massage the worker in the next cubicle. The store also sells soap for those occasions when "you need to turn up the volume on your inner voice of reason"; this spring, a line of plastic shower caps, printed with a fish design, sold out and had to be restocked.
"It's important to have that whimsical side to our product," said Nate Tanner, 29, a lightly bearded, shaggy-haired store designer for Crate and Barrel. "You could imagine how serious and pretentious this store could be."
Pottery Barn, a main rival of Crate and Barrel, has opened a new line of stores, Pottery Barn Kids, and two niche Web sites and catalogs. But that has not hurried Mr. Segal's plans. Instead, CB2 waits in an incubator with Mr. Segal watching every move and recording every success and misstep.
"It's as if he and his wife's name were on the front door," said Wendy Liebmann, president of WSL Strategic Retail, a marketing and retail consulting company in New York. "They will continue to refine it and refine it and refine it until they get it right."
Crate and Barrel is consistent enough to be reliable, yet it changes just enough to be relevant, Ms. Liebmann said. It has also turned up its nose at the Gap model of a store on every corner, she added.
Mr. Segal sold a majority stake of Crate and Barrel to the private Otto Versand G.m.b.H. of Germany, a large mail-order company, in 1998. But Crate and Barrel is still under Mr. Segal's creative control.
Crate and Barrel has grown steadily, if not spectacularly, even during economic slumps. Its sales have risen every year for a decade, expanding 11 percent last year, for example, to $824 million. It expects sales to top $900 million this year. The chain, which has grown to 119 stores, does not disclose profit figures, but says it has never lost money. Mr. Segal would not break out sales for CB2.
Rob Wilson, president of the Tiburon Research Group in San Francisco, said Crate and Barrel could grow slowly because it is privately held. While many public companies are under constant investor pressure to expand, Mr. Segal can set his own speed. Mr. Wilson said that "it's not as sexy to grow at a snail's pace, but usually it's the guy whose money is directly involved who makes the best decisions." 
Lauren Cooks Levitan, a San Francisco-based managing director and senior research analyst of specialty retailing for SG Cowen Securities, said Crate and Barrel had strong brand-name recognition and strong growth potential. 
Ms. Levitan, who once worked for Crate and Barrel as an assistant store manager, said the company had been able to glamorize domestic items more effectively than the more utilitarian Lechters, now defunct. "Visual presentation is something they take extraordinarily seriously," Ms. Levitansaid. "Crate and Barrel knows how to romanticize a spatula."
Unlike many competitors, Crate and Barrel has both a manager and a designer at each store, and the headquarters gives each location enough creative control for management to stay interested, resulting in low turnover. Hiring and retaining the right people have been crucial elements of the chain's success, Mr. Segal has said.
HE has also said that he wants to build another CB2 store here, possibly near the Crate and Barrel on North Avenue, closer to the city's center, and possibly within a year.
He has also suggested that he might build another CB2 in a northern suburb, then perhaps in New York, Boston or Washington. But he has announced no formal plans, leaving even the current CB2 store manager guessing.
"It's frustrating," said the manager, Debbie Kushnir, 32. "He's very meticulous about his locations. He wants to hammer it out perfectly before he opens it up in new cities. He came into the store about a month ago to do a surprise visit. He knows if the light isn't focused or the music isn't loud enough or the staff isn't smiling."
In January 2000, when CB2 opened, 10 percent of its merchandise could also be found at Crate and Barrel. But over time, CB2 gained a better understanding of its target audience. It is a bit younger than Crate and Barrel's: college students looking to decorate their dorm rooms, recent graduates in their first apartments, newlyweds in their first homes. The store now shares only 2 percent of its products with its parent.
Whitney Peterson, 30, who works for a commercial real estate company, said she had been shopping at CB2 at least once a month for a year and a half. During that time, she has bought a contact lens case, refrigerator magnets, rugs, pillows, sparkling wrapping paper, and cards. "It's got inexpensive, fun home-decorating stuff," she said. "If you needed something at the last minute, you could pop in here and find it."
Hilary Applequist, 24, said she would rather shop at CB2 than at Pottery Barn, which she said was for more established homeowners. "That's not a place you'd shop for your first apartment," said Ms. Applequist, a nursing student.
That would please Mr. Segal, who said he built his company on the notion that everyone should be able to buy affordable, durable and fashionable home goods.
"Making a lot of money was never our goal," he said. "It was to be a world vendor, finding the best products wherever they were: wood chairs from Italy, glass from Poland, cookware from Germany."

HEADLINE: The High Life Is Winding Down for Jaguar Mechanics 

BYLINE:  By CHERYL JENSEN

 BODY:
IF you are an import-car enthusiast of a certain age, you remember the jokes: if you want to drive a Jaguar, buy two -- one of them will always be in the shop.
 After Ford bought Jaguar in 1989, it made reliability a top priority. Joe Ivers, executive director of quality and customer satisfaction for J. D. Power & Associates, the market research firm, noticed the change. "Throughout the 90's Jaguar had what I would characterize as a very athletic, consistent and dramatic improvement in initial quality," Mr. Ivers said. And when the Power survey checked Jaguars as they aged, they became increasingly reliable. 
 The improvements have been noted by owners and those who make a rather busy living working on the cars. "If all we did was try to service new Jaguars, like we did back in the 80's, it would be a pretty dicey proposition," said Earl Gibbs, owner of North Coast Exotics in Cleveland. "I'd be like the Maytag man." There are still enough vintage cars, however, to keep him busy.
When Ron Tencati, a government worker from northern Virginia, considered buying a used XJ6 Vanden Plas two years ago, he was concerned about the quality. "I did some research and learned that after Ford bought them their reliability got much better, and I've had no trouble," said Mr. Tencati, one of several owners who responded to a query posted at Edmunds.com.
Many cars have a few problems, but Mr. Gibbs says he has no qualms recommending that a friend buy an XJ6 from the mid- to late 1990's. "In the past, it would have been reckless to recommend that someone buy an eight-year-old Jaguar," he said.
Improvements in quality have also been noticed by Ed Harrison at Coventry West, an Atlanta company that sells Jaguar parts.
The observations are backed up Power's Vehicle Dependability Index, a survey of 30,000 original owners of vehicles four to five years old.
"To us, it has been sort of surprising to see Jaguar in the real high ranks of V.D.I.," Mr. Ivers said. "It's not the place where we have seen them in the past."
In the 2002 dependability study, which looked at 1998 models, Jaguar ranked ninth with 280 problems per 100 vehicles. Lexus was first with 159 problems, but Toyota (fifth) had 276 and Porsche (sixth) had 278.
Jaguar did even better the year before. In the 2001 study, Lexus was first with 173 problems per 100 vehicles, Infiniti was second with 219 and Jaguar was third with 250.
 That doesn't mean Jaguar owners had a free ride. Some of the durability issues owners mentioned in surveys on the last-generation XJ8 centered on uneven tire wear, brake noise and problems with the engine-control computer. But these were not seen as serious problems, Mr. Ivers said.
"There still is a good distance to cover before it's in the Lexus range, but the underappreciated fact is that Jaguar long-term durability is in the same range as vehicles produced by Toyota," he said.
While life with a Jaguar cannot be expected to be trouble-free, some owners figure other factors compensate. Bill Alderman of Dallas has owned three Lexuses, but finds them sterile. "They are all fantastic cars, but after about six months it becomes a car," he said. His '96 XJR continues to enchant him.
"To me it looks like it's going about 60 when it's sitting in the garage," he said.
Some Jaguar owners, however, have turned their backs on the XJ and gone German; sometimes the reasons had nothing to do with quality. "The first time I walked into the dealer I walked right past the new XJ, because I thought it was the X-Type, the small one," said Barry Fromberg, chief financial officer for Dean Foods in Dallas. He traded in his old XJ for a new BMW 7 Series.
Mr. Ivers said that Jaguar tended to stumble in the quality rankings in the years when it brought out new vehicles. It tends to recover the next year.
In 1999, Jaguar ranked first out of 36 automakers in initial quality. In 2000, the year the S-Type was introduced, it dropped to 10th, Mr. Ivers said. Then in 2001 it rose to second. In 2002, when the X-Type was new, Jaguar dropped to 19th (out of 35). This year, it was 10th.
"That raises the question about the XJ," Mr. Ivers said. "Will they struggle with that launch?"

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2004 Jaguar XJ8; 
A New (Aluminum) Way to Skin a Cat

BYLINE:  By CHERYL JENSEN

DATELINE: PHOENIX 

 BODY:
JAGUARS have always had style, but for too long they lacked substance. They ceased to be driving machines for hard-core enthusiasts, and their reliability --or lack thereof -- was legendary. As the company teetered on the financial precipice in the 1980's, its cars seemed as anachronistic as the British Empire.
 Since the FordMotor Company snatched Jaguar from the brink of collapse in 1989, Ford has poured in the resources required to improve quality and expand the model lineup. After adding the midsize S-Type and compact X-Type, and redesigning the sporty XK series, Jaguar finally turned its attention to its flagship sedan, the XJ. The 2004 model is the first thoroughly re-engineered XJ since 1987, and Jaguar executives are emphatic that the car now has substance to go with its style. 
After a 500-mile trip through Arizona, along the convoluted ridges of the White Mountains and across the scrub lands of the Fort Apache Indian Reservation, I cannot disagree, especially since I was able to drive the '04 and '03 models back to back. 
While the old and new XJ's do not look a lot different -- styling changes seem subtle unless the cars are shoulder to shoulder -- the '04 is radically different under the skin. This runs counter to the common practice of hiding old technology under new sheet metal: the XJ is like a classic armoire stuffed with a Centrino-based computer and HDTV.
Aside from their once-poor reliability, a concern that Jaguar has worked hard to address in recent years, complaints about past XJ's tended to center on two areas: space was surprisingly tight for such a large car, and despite Jaguar's sporty reputation, demanding drivers found the XJ's steering too vague and its ride too floaty.
A lightweight aluminum unit body -- the first on a mass-produced car -- was developed to address both concerns. The body itself is 40 percent lighter despite being 4.3 inches taller and 2.6 inches longer. Over all, the car weighs 200 pounds less despite being more spacious and significantly stiffer.
Partly because of the lighter weight, Jaguar fitted all models with an air suspension to keep the ride height constant whether there is one occupant or five. The car is indeed stable and quiet at high speeds and nimble when the roads are more demanding -- combining the fluid grace that owners call Jaguarness with the lighter feel of a smaller car. The XJ lets you have your crumpets and eat them, too.
Three versions are offered: the XJ8 starting at $59,995, including delivery charge; the better-apppointed Vanden Plas at $68,995; and the higher-performance XJR at $74,995. The standard XJ8, expected to account for 55 percent of the 12,000 to 14,000 expected sales in the United States each year, undercuts the BMW 745i and the newly redesigned Audi A8L by about $9,000 and the Mercedes-Benz S430 by $13,000.
Standard equipment includes a self-leveling air suspension; adaptive damping that optimizes both the ride and handling; traction control with an antiskid stability system; electronic parking brake; power-adjustable foot pedals; parking sensors; and 12-way power front seats. With just a few options, my XJ8 test car came to $64,820.
The engine has been enlarged to 4.2 liters. The XJR comes with a supercharger that raises horsepower to 390, from 294, and cuts the car's 0-to-60 acceleration time to about 5 seconds (from 5.4 in the 2003 XJR). The XJ8 and Vanden Plas dash to 60 m.p.h. in 6.3 seconds, Jaguar says, down from 6.9.
The previous Vanden Plas was a long-wheelbase version, but it now simply has the most elegant trim. Since all XJ's have been stretched, the car no longer comes in two sizes. Inside, there is an inch more headroom and shoulder room and more legroom (2 inches in front and 5 inches in the rear). Burly six-foot Americans can sit in the back without needing a British stiff upper lip.
One of the old XJ's biggest sins was a trunk that couldn't hold the requisite four sets of golf clubs. It can now, with cargo volume increasing to 16.6 cubic feet, from 12.7.
Asked what is the most obvious improvement, David Scholes, the chief program engineer, nominated the steering, which feels much more direct and precise. Another bonus is a new transmission, a six-speed automatic by ZF, a leading European supplier. With a slightly lower first gear and a higher top gear, the six-speed aims to deliver better acceleration and, Jaguar executives say, 15 percent better fuel economy. The supercharged XJR's mileage is now good enough (17 town, 24 highway) to avoid the federal gas-guzzler tax.
With either version of the engine, these are formidable powertrains. Step on the XJ8's accelerator, and significant power is immediately available almost without regard to engine speed. Downshifts are short and quick, but not abrupt. And when you apply the brakes going into a turn, the transmission anticipates your next move with a downshift that sets you up for a burst of speed as the road straightens out.
The interior has the usual leather-and-wood Jaguar ambience, but I had some complaints. The black-plastic buttons for the climate and audio systems were not very elegant. The readouts for the trip odometer, temperature gauge and radio were hard to read in bright sunlight.
Those are small things. The new XJ fixes everything that was seriously wrong with the previous model, yet it has maintained its pedigree. Unlike the S-Type (which shares parts with the Ford Mondeo sold in Europe) or the X-Type (a mechanical twin of the Lincoln LS), the XJ keeps most of its stuff to itself.
Susan Jacobs, an industry analyst who is president of Jacobs & Associates in Rutherford, N.J., says the smaller models have hurt Jaguar's image. "The XJ is coming to the market a time when the cachet of the brand has been severely eroded," she said. "I think the new XJ is going to help Jaguar remain competitive with BMW and Mercedes, and that's fine. But that doesn't revive or send Jaguar on a new course."
Nor does the XJ's evolutionary styling signal a new direction, since the look has not changed appreciably over 35 years. But luxury automakers often find themselves torn between their desire to innovate and the conservative tastes of their customers. BMW found this out by giving its 7 Series a radical, highly polarizing makeover.
George Ayres, vice president for marketing at Jaguar Cars North America, said the designers had chosen to go for a look with staying power. "The XJ came out in 1968," he said. "This is the seventh-generation car. And we have sold 800,000 XJ's worldwide, which is more than half of all Jaguars ever produced. We've proven already that that design can last quite a long time."
Not everyone agrees. Chris Cedergren, an analyst with Iceology, a consulting and research firm in Los Angeles, says the styling, while handsome and true to the Jaguar tradition, may not have the legs to compete for a decade with the sleek new Audi A8L or the next generation of the Mercedes S-Class. And he says it may not attract younger buyers.
While Ms. Jacobs has no problem with the evolutionary styling, she says Jaguar may have missed an opportunity to signal the innovations under the skin. In fact, what lies beneath is not just a new Jag, but a radically improved one -- an XJ that atones for many sins of the past.

INSIDE TRACK: A great body to go with the pretty face.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 29, 2003

An automobile review of the Jaguar XJ8 last Sunday reversed descriptions of two other models. The X-Type, not the S-Type, shares parts with the Ford Mondeo; the S-Type is mechanically similar to the Lincoln LS.

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT; 
Cool On Cars, But Warm On Car Parts

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
THESE days, the Big Three automakers are looking more and more like a bunch of Lilliputians. 
 Helped by generous incentives, sales remain robust. But profits are hard to come by. Detroit's share of the market is ebbing. 
 Despite plump dividend payouts, the stock prices of DaimlerChrysler, Ford Motor and General Motors are all off by 20 percent or more over the last 52 weeks. 
Gary R. Lapidus, an automotive analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Company, talked last week about the industry. Following are excerpts from the conversation:

Q. Auto industry executives argue that profitability will improve when the economy picks up steam. Does that position have merit?

A. To characterize the problem as the economy, which Detroit wants to do, confounds me. This downturn was led by overinvestment and the technology bubble. With interest rates at a 50-year low, consumers have been buying houses and cars.
At best, what you are looking at is a sluggish, modest recovery. For autos, that doesn't paint a very exciting picture. 
The need to buy new cars is not that great, so any recovery is not going to be a disaster, but it won't mean a sales boom, either. We will probably chug along at 16.5 million unit sales and a structural overhang of rising excess supply in an O.K. environment.
The auto industry is operating at about 88 percent of capacity, a rate that is extraordinarily unique in the annals of economic downturns. In the early 1990's, by contrast, capacity utilization in the auto industry went down to about 67 percent. And the profit they are earning today at the current level of capacity is dramatically less than what they have historically earned at that sort of rate.

Q. Is excess capacity the crux of the problem?

A. Currently, we estimate the present excess supply in the North American market at two million vehicles. Over the next five years, we are forecasting that automakers will add 2.6 million units of supply, but that demand will only absorb 1.6 million units. That means one million units will need to be cleared through lower prices.
It is going to be very difficult to create a profitable industry with this much capacity. The pricing environment that is created by trying to sell this many vehicles makes it very hard for me to see how to get a thriving industry without removing costs. 

Q. Are expenses for pension and health care benefits for union retirees Detroit's biggest cost problem?

A. They are a microcosm of the Social Security problem: too few active employees are bringing in revenue for too many retirees. That is why these companies are desperately committed to maintaining market share and revenue. They need to cover those looming retiree benefits.
We estimate that by 2007, the collective benefit expense for the Big Three may increase by as much as $7.3 billion, an 80 percent increase from 2002. And the problem doesn't reach its peak until late in this decade and early in the next, from 2008 through 2012. In terms of cash flows, that is the peak period of pain.

Q. Labor contracts expire in September. What's your forecast on the negotiations?

A. The issues are always the same: job security, retirement benefits and wages, probably in that order of importance. I would say there is unlikely to be any kind of strike. Neither side has the stomach for that, and a strike won't accomplish anything except allow the non-Big Three, nonunionized companies to take market share.

Q. Is there any reason to look at auto stocks as good long-term investments?

A. I don't see a credible argument for investing in the Big Three for anyone with a 12-month to 24-month time horizon. Increasingly, they have become trading vehicles. To a certain degree, they they are liquid options on an economic recovery.
You can look at some non-U.S. manufacturers as long-term investments, particularly some of the Japanese manufacturers. They have an opportunity to expand market share in North America. Toyota and Honda are viable long-term investments.

Q. You don't care for the automakers, but you have a different attitude about the auto supply companies. Why? Which do you like?

A. The suppliers are the flip side of the Big Three.
The industry is going to keep adding new supply and keep cutting prices, which is great for the consumer. If you are a supplier, you get paid on volume. The normal and sustainable level of auto production is a lot higher than we had previously imagined. That is a bad thing for the Big Three, but if you are a company like Lear Corporation, it is a good thing. They make money on volume. Lear and Johnson Controls are two beneficiaries of what we call the Motown Breakdown.
