HEADLINE: New York's Rumpus Room 

BYLINE:  By WITOLD RYBCZYNSKI; Witold Rybczynski is the author of "A Clearing in the Distance: Frederick Law Olmsted and America in the Nineteenth Century."

 BODY:
I CAN'T imagine Manhattan without Central Park. Without the park, meadows and lakes would be miles away, instead of just behind the Metropolitan Museum. Without the park, taxis couldn't take those east-west shortcuts that are like sudden short drives into the country. Columbus Circle would be simply a circle, like Piccadilly Circus, instead of an arc opening onto a generous green wood. I would never see the top of the Dakota sticking up out of the trees like a spooky Transylvanian castle. 
 Without the intervening park, the Upper East Side would blend into the Upper West Side -- unthinkable. Without its enchanted setting, Tavern on the Green would be just another tourist eatery, and the site of the Bethesda Fountain would be simply an ordinary street corner. New York City without Central Park would be like Chicago without the lake, San Francisco without hills or Los Angeles without sunshine. 
 I've always liked Napoleon's description of the Piazza San Marco in Venice as "the finest drawing room in Europe," a somewhat ingratiating remark since he had just conquered the city. A decorous Parisian park could be described as a sort of salon, with nothing more strenuous going on than a game of petanque; a London park is more like a comfortable living room, with people dozing in scattered deck chairs. Central Park is like neither; it's too informal to be a drawing room, and too sweaty and boisterous to be a living room. On any given day, you can see dog walkers and bird watchers, bicyclists and joggers, horseback riders and folk dancers, soccer and baseball teams, and yes, petanque players. Central Park is the city's outdoor rumpus room.
 Most urban parks reflect the style of their cities. Parisian parks and gardens exhibit a Gallic sense of good order and neat urbanity; London parks are casual and elegant, like London buildings and streets. Central Park, which officially got its start 150 years ago yesterday, when the proposal to create the park went to the New York State Senate, is different. The uniform Manhattan grid was laid out for the convenience of real-estate subdivision and traffic flow, just building lots and streets. No frills. Pragmatic, standardized, commercial, artless -- and largely treeless -- the grid represents an urbanism that only a surveyor could love. 
 The creators of Central Park turned their backs on this mercantile diagram. They made the park all loopy curves; even the streets crossing the park lose their straightness. Despite its matter-of-fact name, Central Park is romantic, nonstandardized, uncommercial, artful -- and full of trees. It is all frills.
 It was Edmund Burke who first coined the famous description of parks as "the lungs of the city," but Central Park is also New York's heart. Without Central Park, New York would risk becoming as callow and mercenary as many of its critics maintain it is. The park is part of New York's better nature. 
 Whenever I walk down Fifth Avenue next to the park, and I am not in a hurry, I get drawn in. I can't resist. Maybe it's all those shady trees, or the glimpse of sparkling water, or the sinuously curved path that disappears behind a clump of bushes. Before I know it, I am in another world. 
 It's easy to forget what a distinctly odd world it is. Generally, urban parks are conceived as large public gardens with gravel paths, flower beds and manicured lawns. Central Park is a swath of Adirondack landscape -- woodland, rocky outcroppings, lakes and all. 
 City and park meet at a simple, rugged stone wall. On one side of the wall, a sidewalk, women in frocks, traffic, and the bustle of the city; on the other, a dark, silent primeval forest. Jay Gatsby meets Natty Bumppo. The abruptness of the change -- from man-made to natural, from natural to man-made -- is so absolute, it almost takes my breath away. Even though I know that the park is as much an artifact as the surrounding city, like any work of art, it's what it makes you feel that's important.
 Above all, Central Park is horizontal, in the most vertical city in the world. The contrast is underlined by the looming cliff of skyscrapers that encloses the park like an architectural frame. The experience of any urban park is always the experience of temporary escape, but in Central Park the distant view of tall buildings is a constant reminder of the city. 
 Paradoxically, this heightens the experience of retreat and lends a particular zest to everyday, ordinary occurrences. That's why so many memorable movie scenes have been filmed in the park: romantic carriage rides, park-bench conversations, harrowing chases, echoing steps in a shadowy underpass. There is always that delicious and slightly unsettling sense of dislocation, of being in the city -- and not. A walk in Central Park always makes me feel that I'm playing hooky.
 THE bill that authorized the construction of the park followed three years of cantankerous public debate. It was not a straightforward decision -- this was New York City, after all -- since there were two competing sites. The affair was settled in the courts, and the "central" site prevailed. 
 The southern section of Central Park opened to the public in the winter of 1859, about two years after the competition for the design of the park was held. Can one imagine such speed today? Surely not. New Yorkers immediately took to skating on the frozen lake. In the summers they went boating in rented skiffs, and later cruised silently in electric launches, or lounged in one of several Venetian gondolas, listening to the singing boatmen. 
 The park had an elaborate system of bridle paths and carriage drives, an elm-lined mall for promenading, a ball ground for games, and a parade ground (today, the Sheep Meadow) for military exercises. There were rustic arbors and the Belvedere viewing platform, but the only building was a genteel watering hole, the Ladies' Refreshment Salon. In all, Central Park was a mannerly place, mirroring the high-minded ideals of William Cullen Bryant, an early advocate, who hoped that a park in New York would promote "good morals and good order."
 Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux are often praised for the farsighted vision of their design, but one thing that they did not anticipate was how popular Central Park would become. By 1865, before the park was complete, there were already more than seven million visits a year, at a time when the city's population was about half a million (today there are more than 20 million visits annually). 
 From its opening, and ever since, Central Park played catch-up, trying to adapt itself to the various demands of its voracious clientele. Vaux added a boathouse at the head of the lake, a dairy that served milk to children, and a spa pavilion that served mineral water to adults. The 1880's saw a welter of new outdoor activities in the park: roller-skating, bicycling, baseball. There was a craze for tennis, and more than a hundred grass courts were set up in the South Meadow. 
 Olmsted introduced free concerts to the park as early as 1859, and these proved so popular that an ornate bandstand was built beside the Mall. Nineteenth-century concerts were decorous affairs; people were not allowed to sit on the grass. For many years, parks commissioners, notably Robert Moses, who ruled from 1934 until 1960, had a strict notion of which recreational activities were appropriate, and that did not include large public gatherings. 
 Paradoxically, it was Moses who was responsible for creating the 90-acre Great Lawn on the site of the filled-in Lower Reservoir. The flat open area turned out to be the perfect place for outdoor concerts. In the summer of 1966, 75,000 people gathered on the Great Lawn to hear the New York Philharmonic, led by Leonard Bernstein, and the following year 135,000 people listened to Barbra Streisand. 
 It took sanitation workers three days to clean up the trash, raising the question, not for the last time, of whether the park should be open to mammoth crowds. Nevertheless, more concerts followed, culminating in the reunion of Simon and Garfunkel, who played to nearly half a million people in 1981. 
 Musical concerts have a long tradition in Central Park, so it is easy to forget that the park has also served as a place for mass demonstrations. This is a relatively recent development, for during the 19th century, political meetings were not allowed in the park. 
 That changed on Suffrage Day in 1914, when a group of suffragists marched down the Central Park Mall. "The crowd was as large as that drawn by a municipal band concert," marveled The New York Times. In the early 1930's, during the Depression, a group of unemployed homeless men built a so-called Hooverville on the site of the planned Great Lawn to protest federal policies; the 200 temporary shacks remained in place for two years. 
 What is still the largest recorded public gathering in Central Park's history took place in the Sheep Meadow on Oct. 27 -- Navy Day -- in 1945, when an estimated one million people listened to President Harry S. Truman give a foreign policy address. Photographs show an attentive crowd, seated on orderly rows of wooden folding chairs. 
 The 1960's included a variety of distinctly disorderly public events -- love-ins, be-ins, kite-ins. The park continued to be a magnet for political causes: rallies for and against the Vietnam War, protests against nuclear weapons and apartheid, celebrations of Gay Pride and Earth Day. Such events would have surprised Olmsted and Vaux, who imagined the park as a contemplative retreat, not a public forum. But each generation of New Yorkers has redefined the meaning of Central Park to suit itself: a place to promenade, a place to listen to Sousa, a place to demonstrate, a place to Rollerblade. Whatever.
 Central Park was conceived with a very specific function, but it has not been static. It is a historical place, but it is also a place with a history, a changing history. It took a long time before the park was open at night, for example. A hundred years ago letting automobiles use the carriage drives must have seemed like a good idea; today it feels, and sounds, like an imposition. 
 One day, no doubt, we will further restrict the use of cars, and not only on weekends. (One group, Car-Free Central Park, advocates barring cars permanently from East and West Drives.) But that does not mean that there is a "correct" way to use the park. Uses come and go, users jostle each other, sometimes the odd elbow is thrown. Central Park is often described as a democratic space, but it is really a democratic arena, where there is no fixed consensus, just a constant conversation whose tenor rises and falls with the times. 
 OLMSTED had foreseen that the time would come when Manhattan Island would be covered by "rows of monotonous straight streets, and piles of erect, angular buildings" and there would be "no suggestion left of its present varied surface, with the single exception of the Park." But I'm not sure if even he could imagine just how precious its 843 acres would be to a city grown unimaginably large and dense. 
 Mayor Bloomberg, in a rare burst of eloquence, recently described the park as "our picnic spot, our playground, our nature preserve, our band shell, our field of dreams." Not only dreams, memories. There's something about parks that makes people want to fill them with commemorative statues. It must be the tranquil surroundings -- I always think that if he were able, William Tecumseh Sherman would leap his horse over the yellow cabs that circle Grand Army Plaza, and find himself a quiet spot overlooking the Pond. 
 He would have plenty of company. There are now more than 50 fountains, monuments and sculptures in the park, though there is no memorial to Calvert Vaux, who deserves one, and Olmsted, who disliked flowers, is honored by, of all things, a flower bed. 
 The monuments are a decidedly odd mix. The men on plinths reflect the city's various ethnic groups (Simon Bolivar, Columbus, the Polish king Jagiello), celebrate famous artists (Beethoven), notable New Yorkers (Alexander Hamilton), largely forgotten New Yorkers (the newspaperman Arthur Brisbane) and adopted New Yorkers (John Lennon). There are hallowed authors like Shakespeare and Sir Walter Scott, and literary characters like Mother Goose. My favorite statue is Balto, the heroic Alaska sled dog, whose bronze surface is rubbed bright by the stroking of innumerable tiny hands. Balto is back in the news with the publication of "The Cruelest Miles" by Gay and Laney Salisbury (W.W. Norton), about the 1925 trek to icebound Nome with serum to stop a diphtheria epidemic.
 New York is a city relentlessly driven by change, with one eye always cocked on the future, the latest fashion, the next new thing. Yet Central Park looks obstinately backward. It is a repository of the past; other peoples' pasts (Cleopatra's Needle) as well as our own. Perhaps that's why the park, picnic spot and playground that it is, is also, at times, a sort of shrine. It is where New Yorkers go to remember, tocommemorate and to grieve. When George Harrison died, bouquets piled up in Strawberry Fields, which also serves as the site of an annual memorial for John Lennon. 
 The day after the attacks of Sept. 11, the Great Lawn was one of the important places people gathered spontaneously, simply to feel the warmth of each other's companionship on that mournful day. On the first anniversary of the attacks, the park was a major place where flickering candles marked an evening vigil. 
 No one is buried in Central Park, but those little brass plaques on the park benches that memorialize loved ones -- privately famous people, as opposed to the public variety -- have always seemed to me as moving as gravestones. Here they once sat, the plaques testify, doing not much of anything, taking a break, listening to the birds, reading a book, eating a sandwich, watching the children play, hearing the hum of traffic far away, daydreaming, convivially alone. In the park.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: THE RESERVISTS; 
Balancing Their Duty To Family and Nation

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: ST. PAUL 

 BODY:
Brian Schofield says he had to choose between serving his country and saving his family's dry-cleaning business. His country won.
 Mr. Schofield, a master sergeant in the Minnesota Air National Guard, was called up three days after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. He has been on active duty ever since. His job, helping guard an Air Force base in St. Paul, took him away from home for so long, he said, that he and his wife could no longer run the dry-cleaning store they owned. 
 "It came to the point where the war against terrorism had to take precedence," said Mr. Schofield, who had often worked 12-hour days with his wife at their store in Fairmont, in southwestern Minnesota. Though he tried to help on weekends, the strain was too great. So he and his wife sold the store, and have since seen their income cut by more than half. 
"It's been hard, but I don't regret it in the least," he said. "My nation needed me, and that's the least I could do."
More than 212,000 military reservists and National Guard members have been mobilized for war abroad and the battle against terrorism at home, with many spending more than a year away from their families and livelihoods. The resulting burden has been as much financial as emotional for many families, as onetime weekend warriors see their incomes shrink and businesses dry up.
In some cases, particularly when employers pick up the financial slack, the burden has been relatively minor. But many other families feel squeezed and some feel pushed to the economic breaking point, with reactions running from cutting back on cable television to selling one of the family cars. 
Many reservists with high incomes, like doctors and executives, have taken a 50 percent pay cut while mobilized. The self-employed have been hit especially hard, often having no one to run their businesses for months at a time. 
The squeeze has been felt especially hard in Minnesota because of the troubles that have beset Northwest Airlines and many other companies.
Janine Mickey's husband, Robert, a mechanic in the Air National Guard, was ordered to Kuwait three months ago to service cargo planes for the war in Iraq. It was his second call to active duty in less than a year. Although her overriding concern has been for his safety, Ms. Mickey now finds herself with some other big worries. 
Her husband's income plunged to $3,000 a month from the $6,000 he had been making as a mechanic at Northwest Airlines. Then came an even sharper blow -- while in Kuwait, he learned that Northwest would be laying him off.
At first, Ms. Mickey spent her days caring for their 5-year-old son, Shane, and working on a committee giving solace and support to Minnesota's 400 National Guard families with members overseas. But she recently took a full-time job as a mortgage processor to make ends meet.
"These families have been totally in support of the war effort," Ms. Mickey said, "but some of the employers just haven't been very helpful at all." 
Scott Sheard, a car salesman for a Ford-Mitsubishi dealership in LaCrosse, Wis., was called up in November 2001, two months after the terrorist attacks, to serve as a staff sergeant in the Minnesota Air National Guard. He has been on active duty ever since.
The prolonged call-up has devastated his civilian career, Mr. Sheard said, because his success as a car salesman depends on building loyal customers.
"If I go back now, it would be starting from scratch," he said.
Mr. Sheard, who has taken a $1,500-a-month pay cut while mobilized, said he recently decided to join the Army full time because of his desire to serve his nation and because of the damage the call-up has done to his career.
"In the field we're in -- security -- with the current world situation, we're likely to be called up again for an unknown period of time," he said. "Basically, I saw this was going to control my life. I'm happy to do whatever I can for my country."
One survey found that 41 percent of reservists took a cut in pay while on active duty. At the same time, many reservists' families are experiencing scant financial hardship because some companies, like I.B.M. and J. P. Morgan Chase, make up the difference when their employees' base salary is higher than their military pay.
There are 1.22 million Americans in the Reserves and National Guard. The one-sixth who are now mobilized have myriad responsibilities, among them flying cargo planes in Iraq, doing intelligence work in Afghanistan and guarding air bases and train stations in this country.
A 1994 federal law prohibits employers from discriminating against employees because of their participation in the Reserves or National Guard. The law requires employers to reinstate returning reservists to a comparable position with the same status, pay and seniority. Annualized pay ranges from $15,480 for a mobilized army private to $48,840 for a captain and $78,768 for a colonel.
But that law could not save Mr. Mickey, who was part of a layoff of 4,900 Northwest workers. Not only is he unable to look for work while overseas, but his family already suffered financially last year when he was mobilized for four months.
"Everyone knows you don't go to the military to get rich," Mr. Mickey wrote from Kuwait in an interview by e-mail. "My family has felt a change in the quality of life mainly because this is the second time in a year that I've been called up to serve. No complaints about serving, though."
Dr. James Schlimmer, an anesthesiologist from Mason City, Iowa, saw his income drop by 65 percent after he was called up in March and sent to Bulgaria to serve as an Air Force surgeon in support of American troops in Iraq.
"I had to dip into savings to make payments on the obligations I had -- on my mortgages and a loan on a car," he said.
Some reservists, on the other hand, are feeling no financial pain because their companies go beyond the requirements of the law to compensate them. For its 136 employees on active duty, I.B.M. provides health insurance as well as the difference between military pay and an employee's pay. Target, based in Minneapolis, is also making up the difference in pay for its workers.
Yvette Schue said her family's finances remained in good shape even though her husband, an executive at Target, was sent to Oman in March as a member of the Minnesota Air National Guard. 
"It hasn't been bad for us financially," Ms. Schue said. "Target has made it a lot easier. But there are a lot of other families who have to struggle."
The Pentagon has urged companies to go beyond the requirements of the law. 
"We're asking employers to show support for the troops," said Michael H. Lovitt, marketing director of the National Committee for Employer Support of the Guard and Reserve, an arm of the Defense Department. "There are a number of companies stepping up and doing more than what's required by law because they want to share in the sacrifice and they want to be seen as sharing in the sacrifice. They want to do things that put service members' minds at ease."
West, a publisher of law-related materials, provides health insurance for its eight employees on active duty. The company, based in a Minneapolis suburb, also covers the difference between their base military pay and what they earned as civilians.
"We feel it's the least we can do to help them," said Thomas Moran, West's senior vice president for human resources. "The amount of good will from this is just phenomenal."
In today's sour economy, not all companies can afford such largess. Among those that cannot is Northwest, which, like many airlines, is suffering from a drop in passengers and profits. With Northwest making layoffs according to seniority, as required by union contracts, Mr. Mickey was laid off because he had been employed just six years. 
"I was in a way crushed, but in a way I expected it," he wrote by e-mail. "I don't think I was penalized for being in the National Guard."
Mr. Mickey estimates he lost more than $12,000 last year when he was called up. This year, his wife started cutting costs as soon as he was activated. She cut off premium cable, insurance on their 1989 Buick and swimming lessons for their son. With Ms. Mickey working full time, they now pay $800 a month for day care. 
"I'm trying not to think about not having a job when I get back," Mr. Mickey wrote.

HEADLINE: Small Investors, Once Burned, Lead New Bull 

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON

 BODY:
Internet stocks are racing, even those with more promise than profits. Unsolicited pitches for obscure penny stocks inch out of fax machines, and stockbrokers are prospecting for customers. Mutual fund managers who have been in the doghouse for years are basking once again in the favorable publicity that shines on hot performers. 
 There is no denying it: the bull is back. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index has risen 13 percent this year, while the Nasdaq composite is up 23 percent. Individual investors are leading the charge back into the stock market, according to some brokerage firm executives who look closely at trading behavior. 
 "What we're seeing is the retail investor has been getting back into the market since the last couple weeks of March in a pretty broad manner," said R. Jarrett Lilien, the president and chief operating officer of the E*Trade Group, an online financial services business, who added that he was surprised by the shift. "There was a big question: When will broad-based retail come back to this market? All of us thought it would take years of healing time." 
Instead, investors appear to be returning to equities with their wounds barely healed. Three years of stock market torment seem not to have shaken the long-held view that stocks are best for the long haul.
Lyle E. Greenman, 55, a lawyer in Boston, has recently taken a much more active position in the stock market for the first time since the collapse of 2000. "I was one of those people who got caught up in the bubble -- I lost my shirt, boxers and briefs, all of it," he said in a telephone interview last week. "I've tried to use these last few years to figure out what I did wrong."
Mr. Greenman said he thought that individual investors -- and he includes himself in this group -- had learned a great deal since the stock bubble burst and were alert for hype and for advisers with conflicts of interest. "I think the public is a lot wiser about what the investment banks were up to in the 90's," he said. "The public is much more Internet savvy than they were a few years ago. They know people go on CNBC because they need people to sell their winners to. People are sensitive to what they should look for or not."
But to some Wall Street veterans, the market's recent action has a familiar and troubling feel, one that harks back to heady days of 1999. In their zeal to recover some of the losses in their portfolios, have investors become too willing to forgive and forget the lessons of the torturous bear market?
"The rally makes me nervous," said Jonathan H. Cohen, a portfolio manager at JHC Capital in Greenwich, Conn., and former head of Internet strategy at Merrill Lynch. "The Nasdaq is now up almost 25 percent, which is way ahead of the fundamentals. Sure, the market looks into the future and tries to discern the state of the world next year, but I'm not sure we've seen any meaningful indication that technology companies are doing better than they were six months ago. It's just that they're not doing worse."
Portfolio managers point to several pockets in the market where stocks are behaving a lot as they did in 1999. For example, the most speculative securities -- like biotechnology stocks, Chinese Internet shares and low-priced stocks -- are among the hottest today. Sohu.com Inc., the operator of an Internet portal in China, has risen more than 300 percent in 2003 and has jumped to $27.83 a share from $1.15 in the last 12 months. The Sina Corporation, an Internet company that operates Chinese-language Web sites, is up 160 percent in 2003 and has risen 900 percent in the last 12 months. 
Biotechnology stocks, by their nature another high-risk group, are also up smartly. The American Stock Exchange's biotechnology index has gained 33 percent so far this year. And in the technology sector, semiconductor stocks are soaring, in spite of little change in consumer demand for computers. According to a recent analysis by Fred Hickey, the editor of The High-Tech Strategist, an investment newsletter based in Nashua, N.H., only one of the 17 stocks in the Philadelphia Stock Exchange Semiconductor index had a price-to-earnings ratio below 40.
"I can almost understand why people were dopey about this stuff in the mania," said William Fleckenstein, the president of Fleckenstein Capital in Seattle. "Nothing had gone wrong. Everything was coming up roses. But now we know things can go wrong; we have seen Enron and WorldCom; we know most states and local municipalities are bust; and there are lots of problems. To act the same way you did then?"
The stock market is famous, of course, for spotting economic rebounds before the data confirm it and for shaking off bad news when it is in the mood to rally. But in the last three years, the market has made several leaps that some professional investors saw as evidence of a new bull run. All turned out to have been false starts or so-called suckers' rallies. 
To some professional investors, the return of the individual to the stock market is a warning sign all its own. Traditional market lore states that individual investors are not shrewd enough to know when to buy and that when they swarm into stocks professional investors often sell.
But amateurs are not the only ones who are bullish. The most recent Investors Intelligence survey shows that 60.2 percent of investment newsletter writers are bullish, while 16.1 percent are negative. That is the lowest bearish reading since before the crash of Oct. 19, 1987.
The fact that the S.& P. 500 is trading at about 19 times the earnings that analysts expect from its companies in 2003 represents a decidedly optimistic view by many investors. As stock market veterans have often pointed out, bull markets do not typically begin when the index is trading at such a hopeful level.
In the most recent week, investors put $3.3 billion, net of the money they withdrew, into domestic stock mutual funds, according to data from Banc of America Securities. That was the 14th consecutive week that more money flowed into than out of stock funds, the investment bank said.
With so much bullishness about, companies are finding it easier to raise money in the stock market. On June 11, FormFactor Inc., a semiconductor maker, raised $84 million in an initial public offering of its stock, the first by a technology company this year. It had originally hoped to raise about $60 million. Interest in the deal was strong, and the company increased both its price and the number of shares offered. The stock rose 50 percent during its first day of trading, but settled back for a gain of almost 26 percent from its offering price.
Of course, for a hot new stock to close 26 percent higher on its first day out is nowhere near the delirium during the stock market mania of 1999. Then, according to research done by Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, new stocks rose on average 60 percent the day they started trading. Roughly a third of the Internet companies issuing shares in 1999 paid more in investment banking fees than they booked in revenue during the previous 12 months. 
But FormFactor's first-day move was not shabby, especially when compared with typical first-day moves before the mania. From 1986 through 1994, Bernstein calculated, the average first-day move in an initial offering was about 10 percent. 
While speculative fervor has returned to some areas of the market, certain firms say that the increased interest they are seeing from individual investors is tempered. "From an equity standpoint, we are seeing clients dip their toes into the water. They are not jumping in, not diving in," said Jamie Wanless, the director of retail operations at Strong Investments, a mutual fund company in Milwaukee with $45 billion under management. 
Mr. Wanless said that investor interest had picked up at his firm in the last three to four weeks. One measure is a rebound in client calls; in January, client calls were down 30 percent from January 2002. Now, the calls are down only 5 percent to 10 percent from a year ago. "As we talk to our clients, there are those who know they should have been doing something about their investments but were paralyzed with fear. And they are taking action now." 
Even as investors begin to embrace more risk in their portfolios, almost no one expects a return to the anything-goes mentality that ruled during the bubble. For one thing, securities regulators have put some constraints on Wall Street firms, leading to fewer outlandish analyst recommendations. Another change: as of last Friday no brokerage firm had published a report recommending that investors buy FormFactor. During the mania, such reports would have been ubiquitous by now.
Analysts are much less enthusiastic now over all than they were three years ago. According to Zacks Investment Research, 71 percent of analysts' recommendations were buys or strong buys in 2000; today only 43 percent are. And three years ago, fewer than 1 percent of recommendations were sells or strong sells; now almost 11 percent fall into those categories. The remainder were neutral.
Warily, and a good bit wiser to the way Wall Street works, individual investors seem to be coming back to stocks. Mr. Greenman, the investor, said he has seen more people going into the brokerage office where he trades, and they seem to be asking questions about setting up accounts. 
"I don't think you need to caution the people like me who just got creamed," he said. "But a few people missed the whole bubble and now they think they're getting in on the next one."

HEADLINE: Trying to Stay Put in Florida Mobile Homes 

BYLINE:  By JOHN LELAND

DATELINE: MARATHON, Fla. 

 BODY:
To Karen Melnick, the Gulfstream Trailer Park here is a tidy community of narrow streets and close ties, where she pays less than $500 a month rent and neighbors gather at a tiki hut to watch the sun set over the bay. 
 To developers in this Florida Keys city, where land is scarce, the park is a potential platform for 83 luxury apartments worth $300,000 to $1 million each. 
 So begins the battle for Gulfstream Trailer Park, as do fights for many older mobile home parks on prime real estate throughout the state. 
There are 849,000 mobile homes in Florida, the 2000 census reported, or 12 percent of the state's housing units. As the price of real estate in Florida has shot up, and suburban sprawl has reached its limits in some areas, many developers are looking at the ground beneath trailer parks as an underused resource. 
That trend has Ms. Melnick and her neighbors fighting for their homes. 
In February, she said, the park's owners announced that they had accepted an offer to sell the property. "They're telling us, when the developers take over you have to go away," said Ms. Melnick, 53, who sells advertising space for three local radio stations. "This is where I thought I'd live the rest of my life. Where can you go for $425 plus utilities? We've got nowhere to go."
Trailer parks containing a total of 3,000 homes closed in the last three years, said Don Hazelton, president of the Federation of Manufactured Home Owners of Florida, a tenants' group that has 56,000 members. In Mr. Hazelton's own hometown, Largo, the residents of 12 parks are facing eviction, he said. 
To live in a trailer park like Gulfstream, one of more than 2,600 in Florida, is to occupy a precarious niche in the housing system. Residents at Gulfstream own their homes, which cost $10,000 to $40,000, but rent the land. Most homes are mobile in name only, too old or anchored to survive a move. As the value of real estate skyrocketed through the 1990's, park owners found they could make more redeveloping the land for houses or condominiums or selling to redevelopers.
"I can sympathize with the park owners," said Robert Cintron, a lawyer representing the tenants of Gulfstream. "They're getting below-market rent." 
At the same time, said Joshua Mothner, a commercial loan officer in Marathon, without trailer parks the Keys' essential work force -- the teachers and police officers, hotel workers and bank tellers -- could not afford to live there. The price of houses in the area begins at around $300,000, apartment rentals at about $1,000 a month.
"I grew up on Shelter Island and saw this happen in the Hamptons," Mr. Mothner said, referring to the Long Island communities. "You lose whole strata of the population." Some workers already have two-hour bus rides to the area, often to jobs paying $7 an hour, said Jeff Pinkus, a Marathon councilman. 
Recently, Mr. Cintron stood on an empty lot on Route 1, the highway running the length of the Keys. Until last summer, the lot had been a 45-unit mobile home park called Coral Isle. Now an attractive sign at one end advertises "Key West's Newest Gated Community," with two- and three-bedroom apartments selling for just over $300,000 to $450,000.
When the park owners sold the property to a redeveloper, only two of the homes could be moved; the others were left like litter. 
"We all scattered," said David Ray, 48, a carpenter who left his 14-by-60-foot mobile home behind, and is now renting a trailer nearby. To move his home would have cost $18,000 to $20,000, he said. 
When owners decide to sell or redevelop a mobile home park, tenants have few legal protections. If they have formed a homeowners' association and registered with the state, they have the right to match the highest offer from a prospective buyer. Owners often prefer to sell to a well-financed developer. If tenants cannot buy the property, they may be eligible for a relocation payment of up to $6,000, depending on the size of their trailers and whether they can be moved. After an eviction notice, residents have six months to move.
At Gulfstream, Mr. Cintron said, the owners, Frank and Roseanne Mauro, announced that they had sold the park, not giving residents a chance to match the offer. On behalf of the tenants, Mr. Cintron sued to block the sale before it could be finalized, citing the rights of a homeowners' association. Tenants say they believe the sale price was $4 million to $4.6 million. 
Mr. Mauro refused to be interviewed for this article. His lawyer, William N. DeVane, did not respond to phone calls. The buyers, Southstar of Tampa, said through their lawyer, Douglas M. Halsey, that they would not comment. 
At Gulfstream, residents leave their doors unlocked and spend hot afternoons in a community pool. Recently, Dee Villa-Louis, 47, showed off her home, a single-wide with a sunroom added on, and one of the park's popular curiosities, her whirlpool tub. Ms. Villa-Louis and her husband, Patrick Louis, who are retired, moved to the park from Colorado last year and settled quickly into the swing of Keys life. 
"This is my grape room," she said, passing through a small room painted in a bold purple, "and this is my green room." When she bought her home and another nearby for her parents, she said, she had no warning that the land might be sold. Neither of her trailers can be moved. If the sale goes through, she said, her $30,000 investment will be worthless. 
"We'll be O.K.," she said, "but what's going to happen to our neighbors? A lot of the older people here are on fixed incomes. They don't want to change."
A neighbor, Donna King, said her fortunes had already been affected by the prospect of redevelopment. Miss King, 48, is a flight attendant for US Airways who has lived at Gulfstream for seven years, she said. When US Airways declared bankruptcy last year, Miss King made plans to move to Charlotte, N.C.
Miss King paid $8,000 for her one-bedroom mobile home here and estimates that she put another $4,000 into fixing it up. In a competitive market, she said, she could easily sell it for $15,000. But since word circulated that Gulfstream might be destined for the bulldozer, no one is interested in buying there. 
"I don't see how you can tell someone your house is now worthless," Miss King said. 
Under present law, homeowners and buyers often have no way of knowing whether a park might come up for sale or redevelopment, said Frank Williams, executive director of the Florida Manufactured Housing Association, a trade group that represents park owners, manufacturers and dealers. "How a consumer can deduce these things, I don't know," Mr. Williams said. 
Most of the parks being redeveloped, he said, were built more than 30 years ago. "The economics no longer work" for park owners, he said. If buyers see an old community suddenly being surrounded by supermarkets and upscale developments, Mr. Williams said, "a light bulb should go off," adding, "But if they're moving into a modern retirement community, the chances of change are almost nil."
There are no official statistics on park age. Al Hesselbart, a historian of manufactured housing and recreational vehicles, estimates that about half of Florida's mobile home parks are more than 30 years old. He added that many of them would not be candidates for redevelopment. 
Larry Shaffer, 52, a retired Navy chief warrant officer, moved to Gulfstream in 1997, when his previous trailer park, near Tampa, was closed to make room for a Home Depot. His single-wide trailer is filled with computers, supporting the Internet publishing company that has been his avocation since retirement. After spending most of his adult life in ship staterooms, the trailer seemed spacious, he said. 
When the Mauros announced in February that they were selling the park, Mr. Shaffer and others began meeting in the home of Emil Kuhn, a retired veterinarian who has spent winters in the park since 1986. Though they did not have an active homeowners association, they found documents they say show that a homeowners organization had incorporated in 1982 and never disbanded.
Mr. Shaffer said the residents would have no trouble raising the money to buy the park -- roughly $50,000 per homeowner -- and that mortgage and maintenance payments would not be much more than their current rents. The residents of a nearby trailer park, Lion's Lair, recently brought a successful suit to buy their property. 
Even if the Gulfstream tenants' suit is successful, it will do little to ease the crunch for affordable housing in the Keys, said Debbie Love, president of the Middle Keys Community Land Trust, a nonprofit group formed to create and preserve affordable housing. Changes in state regulations have made it easier and cheaper for owners to evict tenants and redevelop trailer parks. 
But she said public sentiment was starting to shift. Mr. Shaffer, motivated by his experience at Gulfstream, said he was resigning from the homeowners' board to run for city council, saying he wants to protect other parks. "I've been alone in the woods crying about this for years," Ms. Love said. "All of the sudden a light has switched on."

HEADLINE: Jordan's King Urges All Sides In Mideast to Press for Peace 

BYLINE:  By ALAN COWELL

DATELINE: SHUNEH, Jordan, June 21 

 BODY:
With continued violence between Palestinians and Israelis threatening Washington's latest drive for peace, King Abdullah of Jordan appealed today to international negotiators to "stay the course." The alternative, he said, "is that this region will slide back downhill."
 "At no other time has there been so much despair and so much hope, so much misery and yet so much promise, such risk and such opportunity," the king said as he opened an unusual session here of the World Economic Forum. The gathering of business and political leaders from around the globe is normally held in the Swiss Alps. 
 His remarks reflected the concern of many in the region that this newest Middle East peace effort will go the way of many others unless the main players and their backers show new resolve.
"The road map must be implemented, and this will require more than words," the king said in what seemed an appeal for the United States and its "quartet" partners, the European Union, Russia and the United Nations, to maintain the intensity of peace diplomacy. "Friends of peace must stay the course," the king said.
He made his appeal in a symbolic setting on the shores of the Dead Sea -- the world's lowest point -- across from the West Bank and Israel and close to the site where John the Baptist is said to have baptized Jesus. 
"There must be no more missed opportunities," the king said. "It is time to listen to the prayers and dreams of those who live in and love the Holy Land."
King Abdullah spoke after Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, who is staying at one of the resorts where the conference is being held, hopscotched the region on Friday. Mr. Powell continues his travels on Sunday to meet with representatives of the quartet supporting the peace proposals. Since President Bush presented his "road map" proposals to Israelis and Palestinians in Aqaba, Jordan, three weeks ago, the region has been struck again by violence from both sides.
King Abdullah blamed "extremists" who sought to push the diplomacy back to "the old peace" for the killing. But most people in the region, he said, wanted only to do their jobs and send their children to school. "People are crying out for a normal life," he said.
While the gathering here of some 1,200 participants has no formal status, it is providing an unusual platform, not only for discussions of Israeli-Palestinian issues but also for those involving lands from Iraq to Afghanistan now deeply entwined with American plans to reshape the region.
The high profile of the Americans drew barbs today from several Arab figures, including Ibrahim Helal, the editor of Al Jazeera, the satellite television network. At one session he compared the American occupation of Iraq to the Israeli occupation of Palestinian territory.
"What we can see in Baghdad is that 85 percent of Iraqis do not believe in the American administrator," Mr. Helal said. But he added, "Criticizing the Americans does not mean we are in favor of the regime of Saddam Hussein."
Mr. Helal's audience included some Americans involved in the administration of Iraq.
Some critics in the audience accused Washington of seeking to divert Iraqi oil through its occupation without accounting for it.
But John B. Taylor, the undersecretary of the Treasury, said "every drop of oil" would be accounted for.
The gathering here is set to last until Monday, with participants including Hamid Karzai, the Afghan president, and Kofi Annan, the secretary general of the United Nations.
American business and government representatives encountered criticism when the conference opened today, particularly from Arab leaders who said they felt unsettled by Washington's maneuvers in the region. "We feel, all of us in the Middle East, insecure," said Amr Moussa, secretary general of the Arab League.
Sheik Hamad bin Jassim bin Jabr al-Thani, the foreign minister of Qatar, an important ally of Washington, said the Americans "know what they want -- maybe we don't know what they want."

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: PROSPECTS; 
Overseer Says Iraq Economy Is Beginning To Recover

BYLINE:  By STEVEN R. WEISMAN

DATELINE: SHUNEH, Jordan, June 21 

 BODY:
L. Paul Bremer III, who was installed five weeks ago as Washington's chief administrator in Iraq, came to the World Economic Forum this weekend with a message of guarded optimism about the country's prospects. He asserted that Iraq would soon resume oil exports and begin establishing an economy based on private enterprise. 
 Speaking to reporters today ahead of an address he will give to the forum on Sunday, Mr. Bremer sought to counter the image of an Iraq that is sliding into chaos, with rising attacks on American troops and frustration over the inability to find Saddam Hussein or unconventional weapons. 
 Mr. Bremer said Iraq had already "come a long way" in establishing law and order. Instead of fires burning in Baghdad, streets empty of traffic and constant gunfire, he said, 1,200 security patrols occur every 24 hours in the city, accompanied by several hundred Iraqi policemen.
As for the economy, he said his interim administration had begun paying pensions and financing emergency construction projects. "This is at least the beginning," he said.
The priority, Mr. Bremer said, is to shift resources from the state industries to the private sector. But shutting down money-losing state industries -- or keeping ones shut that have stopped functioning because of the war -- poses a problem for the United States.
Iraqis will have to choose, he said, which of the "several score" state enterprises that run the country's economy -- from oil to food to supplying commodities -- could become profitable, and which would be hard to shut because of the hardship for their employees.
Whatever happens, he said, employees cannot suddenly be thrown out of their jobs without some sort of safety net. He is soliciting Iraqi experts to make decisions like these. 
As for the budget for Iraq, Mr. Bremer was circumspect, saying oil revenues, seized assets and aid would help the government meet expenses this year. Most of the revenue will come from a forecast $5.5 billion in oil exports over the next six months.
But he declined to estimate the budget for next year. "How would you actually get that?" he asked. Only this week, he said, Iraq's ministries were asked to submit budget figures for perusal by his staff.
Mr. Bremer also met today with a dozen Senate and House members, and afterward Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., ranking Democrat on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said Mr. Bremer's projections were unrealistic.
"People are telling him, you have to level with us on the numbers," Mr. Biden said, recounting what members of Congress were telling Mr. Bremer. He said the administration had been trying to underestimate the cost of the Iraqi reconstruction so as not to alarm Congress and send the federal budget further into deficit.
Mr. Bremer said work on setting up a political council of Iraqi advisers in coming weeks was proceeding, and he dismissed complaints from some Iraqi exiles that the administration had abandoned its idea for establishing an early interim authority in Iraqi hands.
A sovereign Iraqi government cannot be established until after elections, he said, and elections cannot occur until after a constitution is written and ratified by a constitutional conference. Both processes are under way, he said.
The process of removing Baath Party members from government is proceeding but will have to be carried out with the help of the Iraqis themselves. Still, sweeps of suspected Baathists in recent weeks have resulted in several hundred members being detained.
Mr. Bremer said a special council working with Iraqis would determine which of the several million party members would be disqualified from serving in the government. He estimated that its decisions would involve no more than 30,000 Iraqis.
"A lot of these are questions that I think properly belong with the Iraqi people," he said, adding that the Iraqis might also want to set up "some sort of reconciliation process" in which some supporters of Saddam Hussein were welcomed back into Iraqi society.
Mr. Bremer seemed to have little patience with the exile groups, including the Iraqi National Congress led by Ahmed Chalabi, that have openly complained about American delays in setting up a government made up of Iraqis. Without mentioning any names, he said of those groups, "You are going to have to broaden yourself to bring in a more balanced representation of this country," adding, "They were not able to do that."

HEADLINE: Experts See Initial Impact Of Rent Law As Minimal 

BYLINE:  By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
A day after tenant groups were outmaneuvered in a last-minute battle over rent regulations in Albany, some housing experts predicted yesterday that the new law would have little immediate effect on the apartment market in New York City.
 The significance of the law, the experts said, is its extension of a six-year-old rule that allows landlords to charge market prices for the most expensive regulated units after they are vacated. 
 Tenant groups had lobbied aggressively to weaken the rule, contending that over time it would spell the end of the system of rent regulation, which has lasted for decades. Landlords countered that the threshold was so high, allowing decontrol only of vacated apartments renting for at least $2,000 a month, that the people who could afford such prices did not deserve legal protections. 
In the end, the Republican majority in the State Senate, which has traditionally been allied with landlords, pushed through a measure in the final hours of the legislative session that largely kept the 1997 rule intact, and then adjourned for the summer. Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican, supported the move.
Leaders of the Democratic-controlled Assembly, who had wanted to increase the threshold or do away with it, at the behest of tenant groups, felt they had no choice but to approve the Senate measure because all rent regulations would have otherwise expired.
"This won't have a major impact on tenants, beyond the impact that the 1997 law has already had," said Prof. Michael H. Schill, director of the Furman Center for Real Estate and Urban Policy at New York University. "What you are going to see over time is that more apartments upon vacancy will rent for more than $2,000 and therefore will be deregulated. But that is not a major change."
It is to some extent an indication of how the political landscape has evolved that the outcome was perceived as a victory for landlords even though they did not succeed in getting lawmakers to adopt new provisions that erode rent regulations. In 1997, the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, called for virtually abolishing all rent regulations, touching off a spirited months-long battle in Albany before he capitulated, gaining only the decontrol provisions.
This year, Mr. Bruno, seemingly scarred by the earlier fight, sought only to defend those provisions, with a few small exceptions. He was able to add a clause that seems to limit the power of the City Council, which has been friendly to tenants, to wield influence over the rent regulations.
There are more than one million rent-regulated apartments in New York State, the vast majority of them in the city, and Democratic lawmakers and tenant groups have asserted that the Senate legislation would lead to the deregulation of more than 300,000 apartments over the next decade.
But Professor Schill and other housing analysts questioned that figure, saying it was most likely too high. Still, they acknowledged that given the complexity of the city's housing market, it is extremely difficult to assess the effect of these regulations over time.
The experts also noted that the debate over the future of the system largely affects Manhattan apartments. In the other boroughs, regulated prices on apartments are often at the same level or higher than the market price.
The new law extends the rent regulations for eight years, which is longer than previous ones did. Tenant groups described that as a defeat, saying that it is all but impossible to reopen the debate on the luxury-decontrol provisions in the Legislature if the law is not about to expire.
But some housing experts said they were pleased that there would be a lengthy period without rent squabbles. They said that whenever the law expires, anxiety rises among tenants and Albany cannot focus on other housing issues, including finding ways of building more apartments for the poor.
"I think that this is going to be portrayed as a victory for landlords," said Frank Braconi, executive director of the Citizens Housing and Planning Council, a policy research group in Manhattan. "But it seems to me that eight more years of rent stabilization for the vast majority of tenants, without having to worry about all this last-minute brinkmanship, is a good thing."

HEADLINE: For Europe, Messages Differ on Size and State of the Union 

BYLINE:  By FRANK BRUNI and ANTHEE CARASSAVA

DATELINE: PORTO CARRAS, Greece, June 21 

 BODY:
Maybe the European Union should embrace not only Croatia and Bosnia but also Russia, its reach ever broader, its heft ever greater.
 Maybe it should stop where it is, with a planned membership of 25 nations by next May, leaving a geographic hole in the Balkans and an eastern border well short of Moscow. 
 Maybe the European Union should have its own formidable defense force, a global counterbalance to the military might of the United States.
Maybe it should confine itself to economic matters, because the rest is just too messy. 
As European leaders gathered here over the last two days for a special summit meeting devoted to drafting a first constitution for the union, all of those visions were on display, jostling for attention, along with many more.
The leaders' talks confirmed what months of debates about the constitution had already suggested and what, really, almost all discussions of the expanding and diversifying union make clear.
It is not just a trading bloc, and it is not just a project in the promotion of democracy. It is, increasingly, a Rorschach test, with no two countries and no two European politicians seeing the same contours and nuances when they ponder it.
That was the gist of antithetical comments made here on Friday by Prime Minister Costas Simitis of Greece and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain.
As Mr. Simitis was telling one group of reporters that the evolving draft of the constitution reflected a shared belief among all the union's members in "a federal kind of Europe," Mr. Blair was telling another group of reporters that Britain was adamant about "a Europe of nations, not a federal superstate."
Different countries in the union feel differently, to say the least, about how much control and autonomy to cede to the union -- on matters of taxation, foreign policy or even culture -- and about how important that surrender is for the union to remain coherent and relevant.
"The Germans will say that the union is like a bicycle, and if you don't keep pedaling forward, you fall off," said Jeffrey Gedmin, director of the Aspen Institute in Berlin, a research organization devoted to trans-Atlantic issues. "The British will say that you can stop and park a bicycle from time to time without getting off it."
The motivation for producing a constitution was the recognition that the bicycle itself needed to be sturdier and more easily steered in order to accommodate 25 nations instead of the union's current 15.
But even as the elements of that constitution come under sharp dispute, union leaders and other Europeans talk about expanding their club even further, which could make consensus even more difficult.
As on other matters, they disagree about how much to grow.
Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy, who is set to take over the union's rotating presidency for the second half of this year, said last month that the union should ultimately include Russia, Turkey and even Israel.
"This is my vision of the future Europe," Mr. Berlusconi said in an interview, suggesting that membership should be defined by commitment to democracy, global security and certain values, not traditional continental geography.
"That's absurd," countered a senior French official. "Israel just doesn't make the cut. It's not European, not by geographical, not by historical and cultural terms."
Some European politicians, diplomats and scholars say the union, if it is to retain its core values, must remain a predominantly Christian club, excluding countries like Turkey and Israel.
Others say there simply needs to be a limit, or the union would truly become ungovernable.
That ceiling is not likely to be drawn at 25 countries. Bulgaria and Romania seem to be on a course to gain admission later this decade. Representatives of Balkan countries came to this northern Greek resort today to press their case for membership, which union leaders promised to consider seriously.
"We are talking, by the end of this decade or soon thereafter, of a union with 32 or 35 members," said John Palmer, political director of the European Policy Center, a research organization based in Brussels.
Given that projection, he said, the constitution now being drafted might not last more than five years.
Additionally, he said, the union needed to contemplate "a post-enlargement strategy -- a larger, looser, less ambitious form of association" with countries that wanted to cooperate with the union but would not be given full membership.
Already, with the scheduled addition of 10 countries next year, the union has become more diverse than ever.
The per capita gross domestic product of those countries is about $5,500, according to union statistics from 2001, the most recent year available. For the 15 countries already in the club, that figure is about $23,000.
Even among the 15 current members, there are differences in industrial and economic activity, language and culture that make closer cooperation -- of the kind that the constitution is meant to promote -- a formidable challenge.
"Sometimes we get tangled in the E.U.," said Chris Patten, the union's commissioner in charge of external relations. "Our knickers get twisted on many issues."

HEADLINE: Answers, Not Excuses, From New Chief 

BYLINE:  By EVAN GOODENOW

 BODY:
CRUISING down New Haven's streets on a recent night earlier this month, New Haven's new police chief had every reason to be happy. At just 43, after nearly 25 years as a police officer, Francisco Ortiz has achieved his longtime dream of becoming Connecticut's first Latino police chief after being appointed by Mayor John DeStefano Jr. on June 3.
 Yes, there has been a spate of shootings in the first five months of the year, but Mr. Ortiz is proud of a police effort he oversaw that used computer triangulation and old-fashioned street sources to make several arrests in connection to the shootings. 
 The streets were nearly empty and the city seemed relatively quiet as Chief Ortiz's executive officer, Sgt. Ricardo Rodriguez, turned onto Poplar Street in the city's Fair Haven neighborhood. Displaying the kind of night vision that makes for a good police officer, Mr. Ortiz spotted a demolished car with a red sticker on it. 
The sticker meant that the police had tagged the car, but hadn't moved it because the city's Public Works Department must clean the debris from abandoned cars before they can be towed. 
This mix-up annoyed Chief Ortiz, because to him, when the police give up on moving an abandoned car, they are abandoning the neighborhood. Chief Ortiz, a disciple of the "broken windows" theory of community policing, which states that the same police apathy that allows broken windows to go unattended also leads to more serious crime.
"Abandoned cars are a pet peeve to me in the city," Chief Ortiz said. "They're monuments of failure, they make no sense at all. They remind me of the audacity and the spirit of desperation in this city. I tell my guys, 'I don't care if public works won't get that out of here. Take it out of here. Tow it to the police station!"'
Within seconds, Sergeant Rodriguez is on his cellphone calling to get a tow truck, and Chief Ortiz's first call the next morning was to verify that the car has been towed.
"Community police is about having answers, not making excuses. It's about being responsive and getting results," Chief Ortiz said.
His intensity over the car is typical of Chief Ortiz, who said he often puts in 16-hour days since he replaced the retired Melvin H. Wearing as chief. 
"It doesn't seem like he ever sleeps," said Bonnie Posick Winchester, a police spokeswoman. 
Chief Ortiz became a police officer almost by accident at 18, when he stopped by the department to get a background check and applied for a position after being recommended by a friend. Chief Ortiz said he showed up for agility and writing tests to get into the academy because he had nothing else to do on the dates they were held.
But by 1990, shortly after being named a sergeant, Chief Ortiz was involved in the birth of community policing as police coverage went from patrolling four quadrants to 10 neighborhoods. The philosophy of police as partners with the community rather than an occupying force took root. It was then that Chief Ortiz said he began to believe he could lead and set his sights on becoming chief. 
Handling a force of some 430 officers with a $29 million yearly budget, Chief Ortiz , a self-described micro-manager, will be expected to crunch numbers and delegate authority. He recently named a new head of the detective bureau and family services division and more changes are on the way. 
"It's going to be a whole different position on law enforcement and a whole different perspective on the workload," said Lt. Leo Bombalicki, a member of the police union's executive board who graduated from the New Haven Police Academy with Chief Ortiz in 1978. The two worked undercover narcotics together, the most dangerous work a police officer can do, and Mr. Bombalicki respects Chief Ortiz's hard-charging attitude.
Unlike Mr. Wearing, Chief Ortiz -- known as Cisco to his friends -- enjoys the spotlight. That was evident in the hours after the May 22 bombing of an empty classroom at Yale University's law school. Chief Ortiz, who was named assistant chief on March 3 and acting chief on May 1, fielded questions in two languages appearing on Telemundo, Univision and "Good Morning America." 
Chief Ortiz grew up in public housing in New Haven, the son of Puerto Ricans who came to New Haven in search of work. He is proud to be Connecticut's first Latino chief. It is an appointment he said he believed was long overdue. 
"Think about all the departments that exist and all the men and women who exist in law enforcement in Connecticut. It shouldn't be that I'm the only one," Chief Ortiz said. "It may be more of a sad commentary versus a compliment. We've still got a long way to go."
Not far removed from being a street officer, Chief Ortiz is on a first name basis with many of the pedestrians who walk along Grand Avenue. His fluency in Spanish allows him to duck into a small restaurant and tell the clerk to get the person with the stereo upstairs to turn the music down and joke with pedestrians in their native language. 
"He's always been able to cross ethnic lines and develop relationships," said Scott X. Esdaile, the president of the Greater New Haven N.A.A.C.P. and a golfing partner of Chief Ortiz.
Like several areas of the city, the Fair Haven area remains a high crime neighborhood, but Chief Ortiz said things have improved over the last two years as police targeted drug dealers and the locations where they worked. 
Standing at the intersection of Grand Avenue and Ferry Street, Chief Ortiz motioned to an abandoned convenience store across the street.
Several years ago, two teenage boys who Chief Ortiz had just rousted from a nearby corner were shot to death in a drug-related dispute by youths not much older than their victims. "Those are the times that you spend up at night thinking," Chief Ortiz said as he stood at the intersection after conferring with two bicycle-riding officers. 
"Young kids that had their whole lives ahead of them and the kids who are responsible for that homicide, their whole lives are destroyed as well."
To try to prevent similar crimes before they start, officers are using computer statistics to track chronic offenders and pinpoint hot spots. Chief Ortiz also said that officers will have greater input on where they patrol.
Despite being aggressive, Chief Ortiz realizes police officers must know when to back off. When a young man in dreadlocks showing off for neighbors in the Farnam Court housing complex berated Chief Ortiz and Mr. Rodriguez with profanities, they drove on with Chief Ortiz joking that the man was having a bad hair day.
Chief Ortiz, a husband and father of three, constantly rocks back and forth in his chair as he sits in his office speaking in a rapid fire tone. The police will be aggressive, but he knows that officers cannot arrest their way out of crime problems and that can only be addressed by much needed economic infusion in the depressed inner city, he said.
Chief Ortiz said officers will continue their collaboration with the Yale Child Study Center and maintain a proactive approach to handling domestic violence incidents, including counseling for officers who are involved in domestic violence.
The murder rate in New Haven dipped from a high of 31 in 1990 to a low of 9 in 2002, a 71 percent drop. However, shootings have been up this year with 51 occurring up to June 18. A 17-year-old boy who was shot in his car on Monday, died Tuesday. He became New Haven's third homicide victim of 2003.
At a time when many police departments have either dismantled or cut back on community policing due to shrinking federal funds, Chief Ortiz acknowledges keeping community policing strong won't be easy, but he said it's about more than dollars and resources.
"It's about a commitment and a passion and a drive to make neighborhoods healthy, to work with the residents and the businesses and the youth in the community to get a better understanding of what each other's role can be," Chief Ortiz said. "I'm going to work with every family in every neighborhood in every community to let them know that we're here to work with them and we work for them."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Francisco Ortiz is a disciple of the "broken windows" theory of community policing, which states that the same police apathy that allows broken windows to go unattended also leads to more serious crime. (Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In Connecticut Corruption Testimony, the Names Are Making News 

BYLINE:  By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
It has been almost four years since Paul J. Silvester pleaded guilty to having used his office as Connecticut state treasurer to shake down people seeking state business, setting off the first of many scandals to disgrace a member of Gov. John G. Rowland's inner sanctum.
 But it is only in recent days that many seamier details behind Mr. Silvester's dealings have tumbled into full view as part of a federal trial in New Haven in which he is the star witness. And with each fresh revelation, and new name mentioned, political observers are indulging in a parlor game of trying to assess just how far the fallout might reach. 
 "Everyone in the capital is reading about it," said Andy Sauer, the executive director of Common Cause in Connecticut, a government watchdog group. Mr. Sauer was on a camping trip on Cape Cod on Friday but nonetheless knew of Mr. Silvester's latest name-dropping on the stand. "It's an insider's story because of all the people who are being mentioned in the trial. And for our purposes, it's exposing the dark side of money and politics." 
By law, Connecticut's treasurer has sole authority to decide how to invest state pension money. Mr. Silvester, besides implicating many investment firms, executives and politicians already on trial or awaiting trial, also testified last week about people of all political stripes who benefited from his influence but have not been charged.
On Thursday, he mentioned Wayne E. Berman, once a top Republican fund-raiser in Washington, and William A. DiBella, the former State Senate Democratic majority leader, as having reaped large fees from investment companies that won money-management contracts from the state.
The Associated Press quoted Mr. DiBella's lawyer last week as saying that his client had done nothing wrong. Mr. Berman has said recently that whatever fees he took were proper.
On the stand Friday, Mr. Silvester made glancing references to Mr. Rowland, though lawyers following the case say he stopped short of accusing him of anything a prosecutor would build a case on. Under cross-examination, Mr. Silvester said he had steered business to the Apollo Real Estate Investment Fund after a Hartford lobbyist promised that if he did, an Apollo executive would throw a fund-raiser for Mr. Rowland.
Mr. Silvester also testified that he had been asked by another lobbyist who some say is close to Mr. Rowland to increase the state's investment in Pioneer Capital. The investment was against his better judgment, Mr. Silvester said, and he demurred. Later, Mr. Silvester told the court, he asked Mr. Rowland to appoint his brother George as a judge and to hire 15 to 20 of Mr. Silvester's staffers who were losing their jobs at the end of his term. This time, he said, the governor demurred.
Not until he learned that Mr. Rowland would indeed hire some of his employees, Mr. Silvester said, did he put more state money into Pioneer.
Mr. Rowland appears to be trying to distance himself from the latest courtroom drama. On Friday, The Associated Press quoted him as saying not to expect a comment on his former treasurer's allegations. The governor said he was too busy trying to get a budget passed for the new fiscal year that begins on July 1 "to do a daily commentary on each and every day of the various trials that are going on."
Political scientists said that the governor is correct in acting as if the public cares more about the local economy and taxes than how his underlings abused their positions. "The public in Connecticut is scandaled out," said Christopher Barnes, associate director for the Center for Survey Research and Analysis at the University of Connecticut.
The center's most recent poll, of 500 residents, showed Mr. Rowland's popularity at a near low. Only 33 percent of the public described the job he was doing as good or excellent. The poll, taken from May 28 to June 1, has a margin of error of plus or minus 4 percentage points.
Mr. Barnes said he did not think the scandals in Hartford caused Mr. Rowland's approval rating to drop from the high of 73 percent it reached shortly before he was elected to the second of three terms in 1998. "The public expects politicians to behave like that," Mr. Barnes said. "So when it turns out that politicians are doing each other favors, they're not exactly shocked, maybe disappointed, and that may explain part of the lower ratings, but it's the economy that drove them down."
Connecticut has embraced some reforms aimed at closing loopholes that Mr. Silvester exploited. His successor as state treasurer, Denise L. Nappier, has established criteria that her office must use in choosing investment firms. The legislature also bolstered the power of the outside advisory council that oversees pension-related decisions. And it eliminated the ability of a lame-duck treasurer to make investments in the weeks before leaving office, a period that Mr. Silvester had used to cut deals that padded his own pockets.
Mr. Rowland named Mr. Silvester treasurer in 1997 to fill a vacancy between elections. By Mr. Silvester's own admission, he wasted little time, demanding kickbacks and other favors from people who could benefit from pension fund investments. One witness who testified last week under government immunity said Mr. Silvester went so far as to threaten that his brother Mark would harm the witness if he did not participate in a kickback scheme.
After he narrowly lost his post to Ms. Nappier in November 1998, Mr. Silvester attracted the attention of investigators by negotiating $800 million of long-term contracts with a dozen firms in the few weeks before he left office. Mr. Silvester has admitted that at least five of those companies accepted deals aimed at enriching him and associates including his former aide and mistress, Lisa A. Thiesfield. 
An oddity of the trial is that the big fish in the case, Mr. Silvester, has been caught and is taking the stand only in an effort to lessen his sentence by testifying against firms and individuals who have far less name recognition than he. Triumph Capital Group of Boston and its general counsel, Charles B. Spadoni, are the ones currently on trial. They are accused of pledging campaign contributions and jobs in exchange for Mr. Silvester's business and for tampering with evidence once the government began to investigate.
Three more people -- Ms. Thiesfield; Ben F. Andrews, the Republican candidate for secretary of state in 1998; and Triumph's chairman, Frederick W. McCarthy -- are expected to go on trial in the fall.
But unless the various investigative trails ultimately lead prosecutors to someone with more name recognition than Mr. Silvester -- either the governor or perhaps the people behind the Carlyle Group, a star-studded investment fund in Washington with connections to Mr. Berman -- the Silvester saga may never grip the masses the way other Connecticut soap operas have. In contrast, residents closely followed the two juries that convicted Joseph P. Ganim, Bridgeport's former mayor, of taking bribes, and Philip A. Giordano, the former mayor of Waterbury, of using official powers to sexually abuse two young girls.
If this were the first time that the governor's name had come up as a result of a corruption scandal, voters might be more shocked, political analysts said. But the scandals of the last four years have left many rather jaded. There is Mr. Rowland's former co-chief of staff, Peter N. Ellef, who federal and state officials say is under investigation for improperly steering state business. That came on the heels of a guilty plea by Mr. Rowland's former deputy chief of staff, Lawrence E. Alibozek, to charges of accepting cash and gold coins from a state contractor eager for business. The loot was found buried in Mr. Alibozek's backyard. And the governor himself recently agreed to pay almost $9,000 to resolve accusations that he did not pay full price for using vacation homes supplied by a favored state contractor.
All of which may be too much for the average voter, even as the cognoscenti savor every detail. "Everyone is just plain fed up," Mr. Sauer of Common Cause said. "To them, the Silvester story is nothing new, just one more corrupt politician."
