HEADLINE: IN BUSINESS; 
Personal Bankruptcy Filings Rise

BYLINE:  By YILU ZHAO

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS 

 BODY:
THE rocky economy has meant an increase in business for at least one group of lawyers: those who shepherd bankruptcies through the system. Lawrence Reich, a bankruptcy lawyer in White Plains, said his work was spilling over into the weekends. His services are so much in demand that there are more cases than he and his son, Jeff, who works with him, can handle. He has enlisted the help of his daughter, Robin Reich, a bankruptcy lawyer who has spent most of her time at home with her three young children in recent years. 
 The numbers of people filing for personal bankruptcy under Chapter 13 in Westchester and Rockland Counties are still not large, but they are growing. In the first five months of this year, 197 people declared bankruptcy, a 26 percent jump from the same period last year, according to records of the United States Bankruptcy Court of the Southern District of New York. The number of people filing for personal bankruptcy under Chapter 7 increased by 14 percent to 1,033. 
 Roughly three-quarters of both Chapters 7 and 13 cases processed in the White Plains division of the court have been filed by Westchester residents, said Marlene Guercy, the division's deputy clerk in charge. The number of Americans filing for bankruptcy reached 1.6 million in the 12 months ending March 31 this year, setting a national record, said the American Banking Institute, a nonprofit organization based in Alexandria, Va., that researches bankruptcy-related issues. The number represents a 7.1 percent increase over the previous 12 months. Bankruptcy filings nationwide first broke 1.5 million in the 12-month period ending March 31, 2002. 
The jump has brought more work to Westchester's bankruptcy lawyers, the bankruptcy court and the federally appointed trustee, who guards creditors' interests. It has also provided more job opportunities for graduates from universities in the New York metropolitan area specializing in bankruptcy.
But the process of filing for bankruptcy, which involves tallying all debt, counting possessions and, in some cases, creating a formula to repay the creditors is a painful one for the applicants.
"What we are seeing is a flip side of the booming economy," said Samuel J. Gerdano, executive director of the American Banking Institute. "This is simply paying the bill. It is a hangover of the good times people felt they were in.
"Money was spent everywhere," he added, "on vacations, homes, automobiles, boats. They all add to household debts."
National consumer debt has been more than 14 percent of total personal disposable income since 2000, the highest since 1987, according to the American Banking Institute. 
"A lot of people are laid off," said Sidney Turner, the chairman of the Committee on Creditors' Rights and Bankruptcy, part of the Westchester County Bar Association. "People are stretched out. They do as much as they can to hold onto their homes. They refinance. But when they run out of options to refinance, one of the options is to choose bankruptcy."
Jeffrey Sapir, the sole trustee of Chapter 13 cases in the Southern District of New York, said bankruptcy court days now often run from 9:30 a.m. to 6 p.m. instead of to 3:30 p.m. While Mr. Sapir maintained a private practice a few years ago, he no longer has time to see private clients. As a trustee, Mr. Sapir approves or rejects a repayment plan designed by the debtor and the bankruptcy lawyer before the plan reaches court. 
Kathleen Farrell-Willoughby, the head clerk bankruptcy court of the Southern District of New York, said she was hiring an assistant deputy clerk for the White Plains division, a position created in response to the increasing case volume.
Robert Zinman, the director of the bankruptcy program at St. John's University Law School in Queens, said all 34 of the graduating students in the program last year readily found jobs.
The number of businesses filing for bankruptcy has also grown in Westchester, according to bankruptcy court records. While 39 businesses filed for bankruptcy in the first five months of 2002, 45 did in the same period in 2003, a 15 percent increase.
While lawyers usually advise debtors with few assets to file for bankruptcy under Chapter 7, they suggest homeowners to choose Chapter 13. Under Chapter 7, the applicant can be discharged of all debts but must liquidate all assets beyond a certain limit. Under Chapter 13, the applicant may keep his property but must pay the debtor according to a certain schedule with money from future income. 
Bankruptcy is a family business for the Reiches Mr. Reich's father started the family practice in White Plains in 1933, at the height of the Great Depression.
Mr. Reich, who is 63, often finds himself playing the role of a psychotherapist, an accountant and a lawyer all at once. He hands his clients tissues; he dispenses marital advice; he offers financial suggestions. Often he has to tease out information bit by bit.
"Many come in, distraught and traumatized," Mr. Reich said. "There is a lot of hand-holding going on."
For this service, bankruptcy applicants pay their lawyers up front, and lawyers' fees for a basic personal bankruptcy filing are around $1,500. 
"I find it very gratifying to be a bankruptcy lawyer," said Mr. Reich. "At the beginning of the process, they are depressed, they come crying and many are ill. At the end, they feel much better about themselves and they have a new start. It's one area of the law where you can really help people."
Often, the professions of his clients are a weathervane of the economy at large. In the early 1990's, when interest rate was high, Mr. Reich represented many real estate developers and construction company owners who had lost their businesses. Two years ago, when the Internet bubble burst, it was the Web entrepreneurs who sought out his services. Now it's bond traders, investment bankers, stockbrokers or corporate lawyers. 
Who will be next?
"Restaurant owners, maybe," Mr. Reich ventured. "People in the service industry who need the bankers and lawyers to spend. You throw a pebble in the pond, and there will be ripples."

A bankruptcy filing form, which more residents are using as filings rose in the first five months this year. (George M. Gutierrez for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: U.S. Statistical Shift Is Assailed on Island 

BYLINE:  By JOHN RATHER

 BODY:
NASSAU and Suffolk counties stand to lose tens of millions in government aid under a new system put in place earlier this month by the federal Office of Management and Budget, Long Island officials said last week.
 The officials, including members of the Long Island congressional delegation, said they would appeal to the White House to overrule the agency's action and restore the Island to its former status as a separate statistical area within the New York metropolitan region, a status held for 25 years. 
 "They are going to know that they are in a battle," said Lee E. Koppelman, executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board, who blamed "bureaucrats playing their own games" for causing what he described as a serious problem.
Officials at O.M.B. seemed perplexed by the uproar. "There should be no impact as far as funding is concerned," said Trent Duffy, an O.M.B. spokesman. "They have the same status, only a different name." 
Under the former O.M.B. classification, Nassau and Suffolk were joined as a Primary Metropolitan Statistical Area, giving Long Island what officials said was an undisputed, separate statistical existence from surrounding metropolitan areas and a distinct demographic and economic profile. Crucially, the officials said, federal grants and aid did not penalize the two-county area for being wealthier than New York City and most surrounding areas.
In the new classification, the Long Island counties remain joined but now become the Suffolk-Nassau Division, one of four divisions in a mega-conglomerate of 18 million people called the New York-Newark-Edison, New York-New Jersey-Pennsylvania Metropolitan Statistical Area. It includes the 5 city boroughs; 12 New Jersey counties as far south as Ocean County; Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Putnam and Rockland counties in New York; and Pike County in Pennsylvania.
The Long Island officials said the change would mean drastic reductions in government block grants, housing aid and other types of aid based on income. This would be so, they said, because lower-income areas in New York City and elsewhere in the newly designated statistical area would secure virtually all the funding under income caps in many programs. "We would be viewed as too wealthy," Dr. Koppelman said. "And we could lose tens of millions of dollars."
Long Island would also suffer a sharp decline in government money for affordable housing, the officials said.
"It's a disaster," said Jim Morgo, president of the Long Island Housing Partnership, an affordable housing group that relies on public and private financing. "If we are grouped with the five boroughs our income limits will come down. It will cut thousands and thousands of people from our programs." 
O.M.B. said the revisions, part of a national reconfiguring that the agency was required to undertake every 10 years based on census data, were for statistical purposes only. The agency and the Census Bureau outlined the proposed changes and sought comments as long ago as December 2000.
"This was the result of a multiyear, public process," said Michael Ratcliffe, a geographer for the Census Bureau. "It was a very public proceeding that folks in the New York area were aware of."
Long Island officials and planners said, however, that the agencies provided only partial information, making comment difficult. "It was like commenting on a shot in basketball before the guy takes the shot," said Roy Fedelem, a principal planner for the Long Island Regional Planning Board. 
Representative Steve Israel, Democrat of Huntington, said he and Representative Peter T. King, Republican of Seaford, would build a case against the change. "And we will take that case to the White House," he said. Mr. King is the only Republican in the Long Island delegation. Mitchell H. Pally, the vice president for governmental affairs for the Long Island Association, said the O.M.B. change would undo decades of identity-building on Long Island and make the area more difficult to market to businesses seeking to compare it with other regions that remained separate statistical areas.
"It removes our identity as an economic area of our own," Mr. Pally said. "Long Island is being treated differently than many other areas of lesser population, and that's unfair and we won't stand for it."

GRAPHIC: Map of Long Island highlights Suffolk-Nassau division: Nassau and Suffolk would become part of a 23-county statistical region.

HEADLINE: The Rising Price of Getting Well 

BYLINE:  By SUSAN WARNER

 BODY:
IRA ROSENBLOOM is an accountant, not a doctor, but he sees plenty of pain as his clients -- and his own firm -- struggle to pay health insurance premiums that are rising faster than they have in more than a decade.
 For the 55 employees at his firm, Mintz Rosenfeld & Co. in Fairfield, Mr. Rosenbloom, the managing director, has shopped around for lower rates and cut benefits -- though he can only cut so much. After all, he runs a service company, and contented workers are his most important asset. 
 Nonetheless, like an increasing number of employers throughout New Jersey -- where it costs more to insure a family than any other state -- Mr. Rosenbloom finds his company having to pass along a larger share of health care expenditures to the employees themselves. He does not even know where to place the blame: doctors, hospitals, government, insurance companies, or patients. "There seems to be pain all over for an industry that's supposed to make pain go away," Mr. Rosenbloom. 
 Throughout New Jersey, large employers are looking at increases of more than 10 percent in their premiums again next year. Small companies and people who buy insurance on their own face even steeper increases. After sweeping reforms in 1992 -- requiring insurance companies operating in the state to provide health care policies to all applicants regardless of age or illness -- state officials are now questioning whether those regulations have instead priced residents out of the market.
 At the same time, government health insurance plans for low-income residents are also under a strain. As recently as the late 1990's, the state was a leader in expanding health care coverage to low-income families and singles. But these days New Jersey, like more and more states, is staring at cutbacks in enrollment because of budget constraints. By June 30, New Jersey must overcome a $5 billion shortfall and approve a balanced budget. 
 What this all means is that an estimated 1.1 million New Jersey residents are without any health insurance this year, a number certain to keep rising.
 "When people are uninsured and have a major illness they run the risk of going bankrupt trying to provide health care for their family," Holly Bakke, commissioner of the state Department of Banking and Insurance, said in a recent interview. "We don't think that's acceptable."
 But for now, she said she had no quick solution. Not that the crisis in health care costs is limited to New Jersey. Rebuilding a health care system that many Americans say is in turmoil is likely to be a central issue in next year's presidential campaign, though candidates disagree sharply over how to do it. 
 "We have to be very careful not to solve the wrong problem," Ms. Bakke said of New Jersey's deepening quandary.
 For example, she said the changes enacted in 1992 were effective in requiring companies to carry policies regardless of age or illnesses, but were now prohibitively expensive, creating what insurers call a "death spiral" in enrollment. What happened was this: gradually, older and sicker residents sought individual policies, making insurance companies have to pay put more and, ultimately, charge more. 
 After several years of no increases in premiums, or slight ones, in the early to mid-1990s -- mostly because of the spread of health maintenance organizations -- the cost of providing benefits to workers rose 35 percent in the past three years, according to a survey released in March by the New Jersey Business and Industry Association. 
 Employers surveyed said they paid an average of $6,325 in premiums for each covered employee, an increase of $823, or 15 percent -- the highest annual increase since the survey began in 1993 -- and two-thirds said they expected costs to rise again next year by an average of 13.5 percent.
 Another study conducted by the Rutgers Center for State Health Policy found that New Jersey ranks first among states in the premiums employers pay to insure their workers' families. On average, this study found, the premium is $7,592, compared with $6,772 nationally. For singles, the average premium in is $2,911, compared with $2,655 nationally, making New Jersey the fourth most-expensive state in this category.
 Only 3 percent of the companies surveyed by New Jersey Business and Industry Association said they dropped employee coverage last year, but a majority shifted costs to employees; 48 percent increased employee co-payments, 39 percent increased deductibles and 35 percent increased their employees' share of the premium.

Why Costs Are Rising
 Those premiums are going to pay health care costs that are rising across the board, mainly because of an aging population and advances in expensive new medical technology, said Robert Meehan, vice president of consumer and commercial markets at Horizon Blue Cross Blue Shield of New Jersey, the state's largest insurer, covering 2.8million residents.
 Prescription drug costs and outpatient services are among the fastest-growing costs, Mr. Meehan said. And while soaring malpractice insurance rates for doctors have not been a direct factor in premium increases, he said, they may be adding pressure indirectly as doctors order extra tests as a way of practicing "defensive medicine" against lawsuits.
 Hospital costs are up too. Richard Miller, chief executive of Virtua Health, a four-hospital system in South Jersey, said his costs rose 8 to 10 percent this year alone.
 Adding to problem, charity care at Virtua will reach $16 million this year -- or about 3 percent of the hospitals' total budget -- up 5 percent from last year. Statewide, hospitals are expected to provide $700 million in charity care next year, Mr. Miller said.
 "That's significant," he said. "How do we deal with that issue and how do we deal with the increasing number of uninsured? It is a system in need of reform. You can't keep going at this pace for the next 5 to 10 years."
 At Saint Francis Medical Center in Trenton, charity care consumes 7 to 8 percent of the budget, said Jerry Jablonowski, the hospital's chief operating officer.
 Mr. Jablonowski said the hospital strives to provide a medical safety net for the urban poor, which includes an increasing number of uninsured, making the situation even more troubling than the economic uncertainties of the early 1990's because hospital operating margins are thinner. 
 "We're having much more difficulty," he said. "We are starting to see the aging baby boomers using more services, and the economy is still not recovering. As unemployment goes up, so does the number of uninsured."
 Adding to the problem is the shrinking number of managed care plans available. In New Jersey, the field has thinned out considerably in the past 5 to 10 years, reducing competition and driving up premium prices said Eugene Alexander, senior consultant in the Princeton office of Mercer Human Resource Consulting, a major national benefits consulting firm.
 As a result, Mr. Alexander said, "HMO's are getting more powerful."
 In the 1990's, health maintenance organizations drove down prices by negotiating lower prices with doctors and hospitals and reducing hospital stays. But in those days, HMO's were also concerned with building markets and offered low prices to sign up employers, said Mr. Alexander. Now, he added, many of them are under pressure from shareholders to raise prices and profit.
 Yet in defense of the higher premiums, Mr. Meehan of Horizon said insurance carriers typically spend 80 to 85 cents of each premium dollar directly on health care. After paying 10 to 15 cents for administrative costs, he said, insurers make 2 to 5 cents in profit on each dollar they bring in.
 Mr. Alexander agreed with Mr. Meehan that the largest share of the increase was a result of more people using the health care system more often.
 "Employees have become insulated from the real cost of health care," said Mr. Alexander. "Their $10 co-pay hasn't gone up much in 10 years, and nobody thinks twice about going to the doctor when they get a sore throat."
 Moreover, employers have gradually assumed a greater share of spending on health care, further distancing patients from the pain of rising costs. In the 1970's, employees paid an average of 34 percent of those costs; today, Mr. Alexander said, the average is 13 percent.
 Increasingly, employers are trying to spread the burden of health insurance to employees not only as as a way to reduce costs, but also as way to rein in overuse of the system. "That is the long-term trend," said Gary Cupo, president of Benefit Solutions, a consulting company in Wayne.
 In New Jersey, 74.1 percent of the population receives health care benefits through an employer, compared with 67.4 percent nationally, according to the 2000 Census data compiled by the Rutgers Center for State Health Policy. State and federal government provided health benefits to 6.9 percent of the population and 4.5 percent were privately insured. In New Jersey, 14.5 percent of the population was uninsured, compared with 15.5 percent nationally.
 Verizon Communications, for instance, which employs 17,200 workers in the state and subsidizes about 90 percent of its employees' medical costs, is expecting increases in health care costs of 10 to 15 percent next year.
 Ezra Singer, executive vice president of human resources at Verizon, says the company is struggling in a tough telecommunications market in which revenue is not growing. But for that reason, Mr. Singer said, Verizon needs the best employees it can get, and they expect good benefits.
 To that end, he said, the company is shifting more responsibility in the area of health care to its employees, in much the same was as they already manage their retirement savings through company-sponsored 401k plans.
 "As we move forward we have to change the paradigm in terms of the company's and the employee's responsibility for management of health care benefits," Mr. Singer said.
 Smaller employers and those who must buy their insurance individually out-of-pocket are already familiar with weighing benefits against the price of premiums.

Tough Laws Were Enacted
 In 1992, in response to insurers' failure to even write policies for many people in these two categories, New Jersey enacted some of the toughest laws in the country requiring insurance companies operating in the state to provide policies to everyone who applies at standard rates regardless of age or health problems.
 For a time the programs grew, though they have since dropped off. In 2000, 930,000 people were insured through small group plans -- for companies with fewer than 50 workers -- compared with 880,000 today. In 1995 the individual health program peaked at 180,000, but is now down to 75,000.
 Since the reforms of the early 1990's, the number of insurance carriers has dropped off from 29 to around 12 with full programs, said Wardell Sanders, executive director of the boards that oversee both individual and small employer programs in the state. Those companies still in the game are charging whopping rates.In New Jersey, for example, Aetna charges a single, 25-year-old male $405 a month for basic coverage, the same as a 60-year-old resident. In Pennsylvania, where there are fewer regulations, the same 25-year-old would pay $101 a month and the 60-year-old would pay $475, said Frank McCauley, Aetna's general manager for small group and individual business in the Middle Atlantic states.
 "The difference, obviously, is that New Jersey is an extremely regulated market," he said.
 But companies operating in Pennsylvania -- and other states with less stringent regulations -- can exact their price in other ways. For instance, a 60-year-old policy holder with health problems may well have riders in the policy allowing the carrier to refuse to cover pre-existing health problems, or refuse coverage at all.
 "The older folks with significant health considerations make out better in New Jersey than elsewhere," said Mr. Sanders.
 "The sole issue in New Jersey is affordability," he said.
 For low-income residents, New Jersey has been among the most generous states in expanding health coverage, though many of those programs are facing cuts under Gov. McGreevey's proposed 2004 budget.
 Under the governor's plan, Medicaid, the federal-state program health insurance program for the poor, would cut some dental and long-term benefits and increase co-payments for prescription drugs. And in the state's Pharmaceutical Assistance for the Aged and Disabled (PAAD), recipients will face new eligibility requirements that may require 16,000 aged residents to pay $65 toward each $100 in prescription costs, up from $5 now. 
 In addition, the proposed budget would eliminate 57,000 people from the state's FamilyCare health insurance program for low-income children and families, which has a total enrollment of 76,000 adults and 92,000 children.
 "There is always a concern, especially now with the budget cuts proposed, that the number of uninsured in New Jersey is going to increase," said Bridget Devane, an organizer with New Jersey Citizen Action, a nonprofit advocacy group. "New Jersey was a leading state in expanding coverage. Now it looks like we're rolling back on those expansions. Parents and individuals are being kicked out and they have nowhere to go for coverage. We will see the burden elsewhere. These people won't get preventive care and will wind up in emergency rooms where it is more expensive to treat them."
 Ms. Bakke, the banking and insurance commissioner, said the downturn in the economy and the price of insurance in the state had created pockets of uninsured even in affluent parts of the state.

Insurance or Groceries
 "When you think of the uninsured you think of the minority populations and the low-income people," she said. "But what we are finding is a lot of working-class people and people who have lost their jobs and their health care must choose between paying for insurance and buying groceries."
 Mr. Sanders said many workers who are eligible for employer-sponsored plans decline coverage because they do not want to pay their share of the monthly premiums. "If you're making $25,000 a year," he said, "$270 a month is a lot."
 The uninsured include many young adults willing to gamble that they will stay healthy rather than pay all, or part, of their health care premiums. More than 4 in 10 people between 19 and 29 can expect to be uninsured at some time during a year -- twice the rate of adults ages 30 to 64, according to the Commonwealth Fund, a New York0-based research organization.
 Another pool of newly uninsured are residents who have lost their jobs but are too young for Medicare. Mr. Meehan said people in this group are often able to get benefits through a spouse who is working.
 Going without insurance may save money, but it can be costly in other ways. A study released in April by the University of Pennsylvania found that the death rate for uninsured heart attack patients between 1990 and 1996 dropped from 12 percent to 8 percent in New York, but rose from 7.3 percent to 8.2 percent in New Jersey where funds for charity care were reduced by half. The mortality rate for insured patients remained the same in both states.
 Ms. Bakke said it is too soon to say what shape health insurance reform will take in the state. 
 Insurers have continually complained that New Jersey is among the states with the largest number of healthcare mandates, such as coverage for infertility. State officials estimate the infertility mandate raised premiums across the state by 3 percent.
 "I'm sure that helped a numberof people, but when we help a certain number of people there is an overall cost to the system," said Ms. Bakke.
 Mr. Rosenbloom, the accountant, said the complexity of the state's health care insurance system reminds him of trying to bring peace to the Middle East.
 "There are real issues on all sides," he said. "You need something like the roadmap to peace. You need everybody who has an interest in it to contribute to the solution."

HEADLINE: DINING OUT; 
Southern, With Soul

BYLINE:  By DAVID CORCORAN

DATELINE: NEWARK 

 BODY:
"MEASURING approximately 70 by 165 feet, the building is oriented with the apse facing east and the main entrance facing west. The structure consists of a tall central nave flanked by lower aisles and transepts The long nave has a steep, slate gable roof."
 The building is a restaurant - well, partly. It was built, in the 1870's, as St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church, an imposing Gothic Revival edifice of brownstone and stained glass. (The description is from its entry in the National Register of Historic Places.) By the 1970's, its parishioners - largely Irish-Americans from the hilly precincts now called the Central Ward and University Heights - had left for the suburbs, and the Newark Archdiocese was forced to sell it. 
 Luckily for succeeding generations, including those of us who need a weekly or monthly fix of jazz and Southern cooking, St. Joseph's did not go the way of so much else in the Central Ward. Its new owner, the nonprofit social-service agency and housing developer called the New Community Corporation, had the vision to grasp its possibilities as a church-turned-into-something-else. Among the results is the Priory, one of the most striking eating spaces you'll ever encounter.
 You enter through the old church vestibule, into that central nave with its soaring vaulted ceiling. A glass elevator leads to a graceful second-floor balcony, which gives onto various New Community offices. The dining room and bar are at the far end, in the two-tiered space that once held pulpit and altars.
 The sensation of eating there - of having fried chicken, collard greens, macaroni and cheese, and a glass of beer in a former sanctuary still watched over by stained-glass saints - is hard to describe. To this diner, at any rate, it felt not at all sacrilegious, largely, no doubt, because the restaurant's owner is a church-based agency whose mission of community renewal is both political and spiritual. And while the decor in the dining room itself is a bit dowdy and functional, the overall renovation, designed in the early 1980's by the New York architect Roz Li, is remarkably in keeping with the church's history and its place in the community.
 The Priory has been in business about two decades, its menu remaining fairly constant: Southern with a few continental detours. Past reviewers have complained of unevenness, and it's good to be able to report that like the Central Ward, the kitchen is on the upswing. Greg Gaglione, the 27-year-old executive chef and general manager, formerly cooked at the Old Bay, a Cajun-Creole pub and restaurant in New Brunswick. His cooking is robust and satisfying, unafraid of richness and heat.
 An appetizer of seafood gumbo is simply terrific, and a terrific bargain at $5.95. It incorporates clams, scallops and chunks of mild white fish in a deep-orange broth thick with okra and charged with cayenne. A whole crayfish lords it over the dish. Popcorn shrimp are fresh-tasting fun food enlivened by a sherry remoulade. Caesar salad is helped along by Cajun-spiced croutons and a sour-mellow buttermilk dressing. Fried ravioli in a wild-mushroom sauce, decidedly not of the South, proved wearying after a few bites - too chewy, too rich, to no great purpose.
 Mr. Gaglione gives a good account of that soul-food essential, fried chicken. While the batter crust is too salty for my taste, it's crisp and relatively free of grease, and even the white meat is moist and tender. Cajun crab cakes have a high ratio of crab to filler, and a pleasing jolt of spices, but they too would be better with less salt. Main-course jambalaya isn't as wonderful as the first-course gumbo, but it's abundant and agreeable, a smoky, spicy, paella-like melange of andouille sausage, ham, shellfish (including a lobster tail) in rice studded with tomatoes and peas. A 24-ounce steak called the Brick City beef chop is merely abundant, with an unwelcome mane of greasy onion rings.
 Side dishes here are predictable but well turned out. Collard greens are tender and full of flavor, not boiled into submission; so are red beans and rice. Macaroni and cheese is rich and soothing, with a burnished topping of cheddar. 
 All of the above were served on a weeknight, when the dining room was nearly deserted and faintly depressing. Sunday brunch was another matter. For $15.95 a person (the price includes coffee and a glass of generic Champagne), you serve yourself from buffet tables in the church's nave. Many of the weekday dishes and sides are offered here, and the temptation to gorge is powerful. Be strong, if you must, but do not bypass the waffle and omelet table, where a specialist presides over burners and pans and two of the most fearsome waffle irons I've ever seen - ancient metal implements black with age and grease. They turn out beautiful waffles, thick and nutty and so sweet and buttery they hardly need syrup.
 Sunday brunch offers another attraction: live jazz. The day we visited, the performers were the Greg Federico Trio, a drummer with bass and guitar. Like the fare from the kitchen, their playing was tasty, straightforward and generous. In this context it seems fitting to add that they were white, while the customers (many of them fresh from church) were a comfortable mix of black, white and Asian. The unself-conscious mingling of races is part of New Community's mission, no less essential in the long run than housing and economic development. That it has gained a foothold in this splendid old church on the hill is the most satisfying thing on the Priory's menu.

The Priory
233 West Market Street, Newark
(973) 242-8012

GOOD

ATMOSPHERE -- Low-key and a bit solemn, as befits a former church; brightened by live jazz on Fridays and Sundays.
SERVICE -- Pleasant but inexperienced.
SMOKING -- Allowed in the bar.
WINE LIST -- Generic.
RECOMMENDED DISHES -- Seafood gumbo, popcorn shrimp, catfish fingers, Caesar salad; macaroni and cheese, collard greens, red beans and rice; fried chicken, jambalaya; waffles and omelets at brunch.
PRICE RANGE -- Appetizers: $4.95 to $8.95; side dishes: $4 to $6; entrees: $10.95 to $22.95. Sunday brunch: $15.95 a person.
HOURS -- Lunch: Mondays through Fridays, 11:30 a.m. to 3 p.m. Dinner: Wednesdays through Saturdays, 5 to 10 p.m.; Friday night jazz, 7 to 11 p.m.; Sunday brunch, 10 to 5 p.m., with jazz from noon to 3.
CREDIT CARDS -- All major cards.
RESERVATIONS -- Recommended on weekends, but the staff often fails to pick up the reservations phone.
WHEELCHAIR ACCESS -- Lower level of the dining room (but not the bar) is accessible, as are restrooms via an elevator.
IF YOU GO -- Market Street is a main east-west thoroughfare in Newark. The restaurant is a mile and a half west of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center (via Broad Street, Central Avenue and Martin Luther King Jr. Boulevard to Market Street) and a quarter-mile west of the Essex County Courthouse.

HEADLINE: SOAPBOX; 
Modem, Schmodem. I Blew a Fuse.

BYLINE:  By RICH PLISKIN; Rich Pliskin is a resident of Princeton.

 BODY:
JUST as the joyous events in life help us mark the passage of time, tragedies, too, take their place on our calendars of memory: Being divorced. Losing a kidney. Having a new Internet Service Provider foisted on you just when everything else seemed to be going tolerably well.
 By that rule, I will remember these recent weeks as the Spring of My Customer Service Crisis. 
 In this part of Central Jersey, a company that goes by the flaggy name of Patriot Media recently succeeded RSN as cable Internet Service Provider. If Patriot sees itself as keeper of the national modem, then I regret that I have but one aneurysm to give to harassing it.
 Two important things happen during a forced transition from one I.S.P. to another. The first is a sudden, chronic loss of Internet service. The other is a modest erosion of customer service, which, consistent with cable industry practice, was atrocious to begin with and would hardly be noticed but for the accompanying modest rate increase.
 As a result, victims of I.S.P. transition move through what experts call the Five Stages of Sadness: fulminating rage; sputtering fulmination; humiliating sputtering; abject humiliation; and pitiable, pathetic resignation. It is in this last stage that the modest rate increase arrives.
 These are more than laws of economics. They are conditions of life, akin to the unknowability of God, gender confusion or baldness. You just have to live with it. Trying to fix things just makes them worse.
 To be fair, I acknowledge that I suffer from a personality disorder that inhibits me from behaving maturely toward customer service representatives generally. Many companies, across industries, have the audiotapes of our phone conversations to prove this, so there's no point in dissembling.
 I do not care to examine why this is so or what it says about me. I certainly don't care to overcome the condition. I believe that accepting our flaws can be as liberating as correcting them. This philosophy seems to work well for the cable industry, too.
 From my I.S.P.'s corporate mission statement, as shown on the official Montgomery Township municipal Web site:
 Take care of our customers.
 Do what we say we are going to do.
 Make it fun for our customers and employees.
 From my mission statement, as shown on page after page of journal entries made in an unsteady hand:
 Parade in front of company headquarters draped in a sandwich board declaiming corporate arrogance.
 Sue over the $10 credit given for last month's loss of service, which I believe should have been $13.50 instead.
 The company knows I will never actually parade in front of corporate headquarters with a sandwich board, or that I will sue for the disputed $3.50. It knows that I would not even know where to get a sandwich board. And it knows that someone of my temperament could not hope to find a licensed lawyer willing to work with me, regardless of the potential payoff.
 I don't know how the company knows these things, but I suspect it is related in some way to the buying and selling of customer lists by direct marketers. After I defeat the I.S.P., I intend to prove this.
 I may never prove this.
 Appalling service from the cable company is nothing new. But it is worth noting that in New Jersey, the state in which the electric light, Morse Code and the telegraph were invented, you get more sophisticated service at the gas station than at the modem. At some service stations, you don't even have to sign the credit card receipt. That's high-tech.
 Do I overstate the case? Of course. The truth is, there were only a few days during the transition when I was unable to log on. A few harassing phone calls to the chief executive's secretary, some anonymous, criminally threatening e-mails to the head of corporate operations from untraceable public computers -- and I was back online.
 Yes, I must first power down the PC; unplug every outlet in the neighborhood; reboot; and sing "Tura, Lura Lura (That's an Irish Lullaby)" in a proto-Mandarin dialect. This embarrasses the children when friends are over, but for Internet service, it's worth their humiliation.
 Besides, the sooner they learn that Internet service is not a right but a corporate dispensation, the better customers they'll be.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times; 
Steinbrenner Fears Facing a Good Fight

BYLINE:  By HARVEY ARATON

 BODY:
FOR all of the familiar noise being broadcast recently out of the Bronx and Tampa, the real story as summer begins here in New York is the makings of a pennant race. Far from the contrivance of an interleague series with the Mets, could this be the season the Red Sox and even the Blue Jays hang with the Yankees?
 For a change, maybe September will be about something more than Joe Torre preparing his rotation for the playoffs, should he survive the panic attacks George Steinbrenner is sure to continue having if his roster of riches fails to pull away from the pack. 
 When Thursday's game against Tampa Bay was called on an afternoon that was turning into one without rain, you had to know, all Yankee protests aside, that this was Steinbrenner's way of preparing for the weekend against the Mets, by guaranteeing that the hapless Jeff Weaver would not be part of it. Steinbrenner would call this strategizing. Others might consider it an overreaction to his own uncontrolled fear of being embarrassed by the Mets. 
People say that Steinbrenner hates losing. And somehow, in an economic climate where so many don't have enough of a market or enough money to compete with him, this has become the sign of a great American sportsman. Commitment to excellence is one thing. Fear of a good fight is another. For all his demands that his players perform as if programmed to be a lineup of high-priced I.B.M. ThinkPads, Steinbrenner has demonstrated season after season that he is the first on his side to blow his hard drive.
Isn't the mental discipline the most remarkable aspect about those we watch on the grand stages of sport? They are, to varying degrees, all blessed with size and skills, but there is no creatine for the mind, and how they deal with the stress of competition is what makes them different. It doesn't take courage to throw a 3-2 pitch with two outs and the bases loaded. It does take composure, something Steinbrenner has only in his wildest dreams.
Watching his team calmly march into Shea Stadium and brush off the Mets, 5-0, Friday night, I recalled a quotation from a lengthy story in the New Yorker by John Cassidy; Steinbrenner was going on about his advantages over his more buttoned-down competitors.
"These days," Steinbrenner said, "there are not many sports owners who have ever worn the jockstrap."
The inference was that he had, though to what extent he never reveals, beyond convenient cliches. He ran track and won races. When he lost, his father, Henry, berated him, making him a better man for it.
What we really know is what we see, what we hear, what he expects. If Steinbrenner truly believes the Yankees should win the division by 10 games every season and then the World Series, it is because, far from a jockstrap, his only protection from life's more painful realities has been his wallet.
When he refuses to let Gene Michael become the general manager of the Red Sox, a job he can't have in the Bronx, Steinbrenner demonstrates more of a fear of losing than a love of winning. When he whines about having to play the Cubs while the Red Sox play the Brewers, he demeans the competitive nature of his team. Do you think Jason Giambi and Roger Clemens care about scheduling quirks? Do you think they were up nights worrying about the rotation resulting in Weaver against Tom Glavine, until Thursday's game magically disappeared?
Do you believe they are terrified, as Steinbrenner obviously is, of the Red Sox and the Blue Jays chasing them all the way into September and having to deal with the threat of not making the playoffs at all?
Sitting in the visiting manager's office after yesterday's game was called in the fourth inning, Torre sighed while revealing that the game would be made up Saturday as the nighttime end of a home-and-home doubleheader, like the 2000 spectacle eclipsed by Clemens's beaning of Mike Piazza. Here we go again, more profundity on the quaintness of transferring from the No. 4 line to the No. 7.
"I don't care for it," Torre said of the total concept of interleague play. "It's an inconvenience in that it takes games away against teams you need to beat to win your division."
In other words, bring it on, Toronto and Boston. Bring on the race, for as long as it may last, and the pressure of honest competition, as opposed to the garbage Steinbrenner supplies.
Maybe Torre has finally had it with Steinbrenner's ignorance of the process. I don't know the motivation for his recent Boss-baiting, but I do know that although players would rather win by 10 games, they welcome the kind of challenge that once defined the long baseball season and that made it so different from other team sports. The Derek Jeters and Alfonso Sorianos live for the nights when they can stun a packed stadium of Mets fans with back-to-back home runs, as they did Friday night.
Jeter took one on the left wrist yesterday from the Mets' starter, Jeremy Griffiths, and had a precautionary X-ray.
"Fifty-fifty," Torre said on the chances of Jeter facing Tom Glavine tonight.
"I'll play," Jeter declared. "I enjoy playing in big games."
Contrived or otherwise. Only the owner loses his cool when facing a tough fight and his own fear. He doesn't need a jockstrap to run the other way.

HEADLINE: City Ordered to Pay Owners of Midtown Hotel Millions in Tax Incentives 

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY DePALMA

 BODY:
New York City improperly denied the owners of a Midtown Manhattan hotel tax incentives worth millions of dollars and will now have to pay back those lost benefits with interest -- despite the city's deep fiscal crisis -- an appeals court has ruled.
 The ruling, by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court, could have a wide impact on future development in Manhattan, broadening the possibilities for projects involving the renovation of landmark properties attached to new structures. It also will put additional pressure on a city squeezed for tax revenues. 
 Lawyers for the city had argued that the legislation governing the tax-exemption program did not cover multiple parts of a single project like the hotel in the court case, now called the Millennium Broadway, which now consists of a historic theater and two new wings. 
"We strongly disagree with the court's decision and feel that three separate structures over two tax blocks cannot be treated as one building for tax-exempt purposes," Carl A. Laske, senior counsel, in the tax and bankruptcy division of the city's Law Department, said in a statement issued after the court decision was released last week.
The city is considering an appeal. 
The hotel first generated controversy before it was even built. In 1985, the New York developer Harry Macklowe partly demolished two single-room-occupancy hotels on 44th Street, just off Times Square, in the middle of the night to make way for the new construction.
That action led to a review of city regulations of the S.R.O.'s. Mr. Macklowe went on to build a 46-story, 627-room hotel on the site, then called the Hotel Macklowe. He incorporated the adjacent Hudson Theater, which was converted into a conference center for the hotel.
Mr. Macklowe had applied for and received a property tax abatement for the hotel and theater project under the Industrial and Commercial DevelopmentIncentive program. Started in 1984, the program was intended to stimulate economic development in the city by offering tax exemptions for new construction, modernization, rehabilitation or expansion of existing structures.
The program was adjusted in 1995, 1999 and 2000, and is set to be renewed at the end of this month. At the program's peak, in 1999, the city received 905 preliminary applications for tax relief, according to Finance Department records. In 2001, the program cost the city $1.76 million in tax revenue, but proponents say the projects generated far more than that in sales, salaries and other economic activity. 
Mr. Macklowe ran into financial difficulties and lost the hotel in 1994. It was bought late that year by the current owner, CDL Hotels USA Inc., an arm of the international hotel group. In 1997, CDL applied for a tax exemption on a 22-story addition to the hotel it built on the site of the old three-story building that had been the headquarters of the Newspaper Guild, the union representing reporters, editors and others.
The owners argued that the new structure was an integral part of the existing hotel and theater, to which it was connected on several floors. The new structure lacked its own cooling system, garbage storage space and other facilities, which led the owners to take the position that it was one of three parts that make up the Millennium hotel, at 145 West 44th Street.
The city's Finance Department denied the application because it considered the addition a separate building, which led the owners to go to court. After being denied in State Supreme Court, the owners appealed to the Appellate Division, which ruled in their favor. That opens the way for the owners to receive a partial reimbursement of taxes paid on the addition since 1997, plus interest.
One of the lawyers representing the owners, Charles G. Moerdler, of Stroock & Stroock & Lavan, said that even though the city was in deep financial trouble, fairness required that the owners be granted the tax exemption and the repayment.
He said the city offered the incentives because it felt it had to create additional construction or renovation in Times Square. "That is a policy judgment made by the municipality," said Mr. Moerdler, a former commissioner of Housing and Buildings. If the city no longer wants to provide such economic stimulation, he said, it can repeal the incentive program. But until then, he said builders who comply with the regulations have a right to receive the promised tax exemptions.

HEADLINE: Investing; 
Online Bond Tr ading Is Gaining, Despite the Bumps

BYLINE:  By HOWARD ISENSTEIN

 BODY:
RESEARCHING and trading stocks online became common in the long bull market. During the bond rally of the last three years, a small group of do-it-yourself investors has begun to assemble portfolios of bonds bought online. 
 Online bond trading remains cumbersome, partly because information about bonds is harder to find on the Internet than data about stocks. And unless investors restrict their online purchases to Treasury and Ginnie Mae issues, which are backed by the government, they will need to devote a lot of time to monitoring their portfolios, many advisers caution. 
 Numbers for the entire industry are not available, but Charles Schwab & Company, the big discount broker, says its clients now average 10,000 online bond trades a month, up from 1,000 in August 2000, when it began to offer the service. By contrast, Schwab clients made 143,990 trades of stocks or mutual funds online on an average day in March, the company said. 
Other companies offering bonds online include the E*Trade Group, Fidelity Investments, TD Waterhouse and Vanguard Brokerage Services. Investors can also turn to TreasuryDirect.gov to buy newly issued Treasury bills, notes and savings bonds from the government, and to www.internotes.com, owned by Incapital, and www.direct-notes.com, a unit of LaSalle Funding, to buy newly issued corporate bonds.
Brokerage firms began offering online bond trading as an outgrowth of online trading over the last four years among dealers and large institutional investors.
The shift toward electronic trading platforms has allowed individual investors to see thousands of prices in a more timely way, said Sang Lee, an analyst at Celent Communications, a financial services industry consulting firm based in Boston.
"There is a lot more transparency," he said.
Still, Web pages for bonds are more difficult to navigate than those devoted to stocks, partly because the bond sites are relatively new and not yet fully refined, and partly because of the nature of bonds. Unlike stocks, bonds do not have ticker symbols. To find bonds, search engines use the name of the issuer as well as the bond's maturity, coupon, rating and other criteria. 
At some sites, not all bond trades can be made online. At Vanguard's site, for example, customers can research corporate bonds online but must call to execute an order; Treasury issues, however, may be bought online. 
Investors who buy in bulk can get better yields. For example, at 1:30 p.m. on Friday an investor on Schwab.com seeking to buy just one AAA-rated bond from GE Capital, due on Jan. 19, 2010, with a coupon of 7.375 percent, would receive a yield to maturity of 2.689 percent; someone buying 20 bonds would get a yield to maturity of 3.427 percent. Bond prices move inversely to their yield; a bond generally has a face value of $1,000.
Quoted yields reflect a small markup by the broker. Some firms also charge explicit commissions. In looking for the best deal, investors should calculate the yield after commissions are taken into account.
APRUDENT way to invest in individual bonds is through a strategy called laddering, said John Ladensack, executive vice president for fixed income at Schwab in Jersey City. To start building a laddered portfolio, an investor buys a collection of bonds with different maturities spread over a given time frame. For instance, in a five-year laddered portfolio, an investor buys bonds that mature in one, two, three, four and five years. When the first bond matures in a year, the investor reinvests in one that matures in five years, maintaining the ladder. By doing so, the investor seeks to diversify risk over time while keeping income relatively stable.
To minimize risk, most people who want to assemble bond portfolios on their own should stick to Treasuries or to securities issued by Ginnie Mae, said both Mr. Ladensack and Guy M. Cumbie, a certified financial planner and principal of Cumbie Advisory Services in Fort Worth. Ginnie Mae, the Government National Mortgage Association, offers government backing for its bonds.
Mr. Cumbie suggests that investors need at least $50,000 to buy enough bonds, from different issuers and with different maturities, to achieve enough diversification. Schwab research, however, suggests that an investor can get enough diversification with 8 to 10 bonds, so investors can start with as little as $10,000, Mr. Ladensack said. 
An investor buying Treasury or Ginnie Mae issues can get decent prices even when buying so few bonds, but those interested in municipal bonds should have at least $50,000, because prices of municipal bonds are not as competitive, Mr. Ladensack said.
Still, buying individual bonds may not make sense for all investors, Mr. Cumbie said. Such purchases can be useful if an investor wants to lock in a specific amount of income over a particular period, or is seeking a set amount of money at a certain time for a specific objective, like paying for a child's education, he said. But investors seeking the highest total return -- interest income and capital gains from buying and selling bonds -- should probably invest in a bond mutual fund or a managed portfolio of bonds because monitoring a bond portfolio "certainly requires more competence or a heck of a lot more energy" than many people have, Mr. Cumbie said.
Mark Kiesel, an executive vice president of the Pacific Investment Management Company and a senior member of its investment strategy and portfolio management group, cautioned individual investors to be very careful if they want to buy bonds.
"The benefit of mutual funds is that you're buying a manager's expertise," Mr. Kiesel said. "You need an active manager" to buy and sell different maturities and classes of bonds over time, based on the changing economic environment, he said. 
Mr. Ladensack said people shouldn't trade bonds online in hopes of making a quick killing.
"You don't buy bonds to get rich, you buy bonds to stay rich," he said.

HEADLINE: Into the Politics of Economics 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
FEW people try to get the attention of the president of the United States by tugging on the bottom of his suit jacket until he looks their way. But Peter Mankiw had an important message to deliver, and he was not going to let diplomatic procedure, or the president's personal space, get in the way.
 So, after President Bush had sworn in Peter's father, Gregory, as the new chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers last month, Peter, who is 4 years old, made a run for the presidential coat. 
 "Don't be mean to my daddy," he said, aware that, if nothing else, the man to whom he was speaking seemed like one of the few people who could tell his daddy what to do.
The president, looking downward, quickly spelled out his conditions. "As long as the economy improves," he told Peter, according to Gregory Mankiw. 
In his very first minutes on the job, Mr. Mankiw was hearing one of the two main yardsticks of his success -- the one over which he is likely to have relatively little control. His son was demonstrating the other: getting the president's ear as often as possible. 
A popular professor at Harvard who is quick to smile, and the author of a best-selling economics textbook, Mr. Mankiw has come to Washington to fill a job that was once held by Alan Greenspan and that has had a resurgence of influence in the Bush administration. Mr. Mankiw's predecessor, R. Glenn Hubbard, was a main architect of the three tax cuts passed in the last three years, and his handiwork was particularly obvious in the recent reduction in dividend taxes.
In his first interview in his new job, Mr. Mankiw (pronounced man-CUE) said those tax cuts were a major reason that economic growth was on the verge of improving, effectively tying the Bush administration to the economy as the 2004 campaign begins.
"I have no doubt that tax cuts will lead to higher growth," said Mr. Mankiw, 45, whose tousled dark hair and round, boyish face are set off by square eyeglasses. "Each quarter going forward is going to look better. By the end of the year, we will see growth above potential," causing the unemployment rate to drop.
Nicholas Gregory Mankiw grew up in North Jersey, the son of a teacher and an engineer who was active in the local Republican Party. He made his name in academia by writing about a great range of subjects and won tenure at Harvard before turning 30. Although his academic reputation remains excellent, his peers no longer see him as one of the members of his generation most likely to win a Nobel in economics, probably because his textbook writing has at times drawn him away from research.
His emphasis on the private sector and the forces that shape long-term growth, as opposed to government spending and the business cycle, made him a natural choice to lend intellectual cachet to a Republican White House. This administration is still looking for an economic spokesman with the credibility of Robert E. Rubin, a Treasury secretary under Bill Clinton. 
BEYOND the chance for good timing, Mr. Mankiw brings one clear advantage to the job, in which he oversees a staff of about 35 and serves as one of the president's chief economic advisers. Unlike most academics, he has devoted hundreds of hours to distilling complicated ideas for general audiences -- through writing both the introductory textbook and an intermediate one, and through a column he wrote for Fortune magazine from 1997 to 2000. 
"Greg is broadly in ideological sympathy with the president," said J. Bradford DeLong, an economics professor at the University of California at Berkeley and an ecomonic aide in Clinton administration. "And Greg is absolutely the best at describing economic principles in ways that make them seem necessary truths of nature."
Mr. Mankiw said he considered his new job "similar to textbook writing in a way." His audience is now policy makers, not college freshmen.
A big test for him, many economists say, is whether he will have an influence on what they consider the fiscal excesses of the Bush administration that have led to soaring deficits. In part because he has warned in his writings of the dangers of deficits, he is considered to be somewhat less enamored of tax cuts than Mr. Hubbard was. In 2000, Mr. Mankiw also wrote a column in Fortune that, while full of praise for Mr. Bush, said that his discussion of Social Security exaggerated how easy reform would be.
But whether Mr. Mankiw tries to shape the administration's message or simply amplify its current one, hefaces hurdles that many previous council chairmen did not. He has few previous ties to the administration, which is known for being centralized. 
Success "really depends very much on the relationship between the individual and the president," Mr. Hubbard said. "As I've told Greg privately, he really has to work to build that relationship."
He has also arrived at a time when the economy has surprised almost all forecasters with its persistent sluggishness, having lost 2.4 million jobs since Mr. Bush became president. Although the slowdown began on Mr. Clinton's watch, White House aides remain worried that voters might punish Mr. Bush if he becomes the first president since Herbert Hoover to oversee a decline in employment during an entire term. 
These concerns will almost certainly complicate Mr. Mankiw's job by requiring him to advise Mr. Bush on some issues, like the deficit and trade policy, in which good economics and good politics might argue for different solutions.
Mr. Mankiw got a taste of those tensions in the early 1980's as a junior staff member for Martin Feldstein, another Harvard professor, who was then serving as the council's chairman. By warning of the downsides of big deficits, Mr. Feldstein burnished his academic reputation but became a pariah within the Reagan administration.
Some Republicans worry that Mr. Mankiw has the potential for similar mischief. In the first edition of his textbook, "Principles of Economics" (1998), he dismissed as "charlatans and cranks" the supply-side economists close to Ronald Reagan who argued that tax cuts could pay for themselves by creating enough economic growth. The second edition, in 2001, omitted the section because people misinterpreted it as critical of tax cuts, Mr. Mankiw said., But the book still says that the "most basic lesson about budget deficits" is that they cause interest rates to rise and investment to fall.
The deficit is on pace to reach $410 billion in the current fiscal year, according to J. P. Morgan Chase. Three years ago, the government ran a surplus of $237 billion.
Reclining in one of the cushioned chairs in his office, with his long right arm reaching down to a bottle of water sitting on the floor, Mr. Mankiw said he still believed that lower taxes and a smaller government would lift economic growth by allowing the market to dictate decisions. The deficit is likely to shrink over the next 5 or 10 years because of the higher growth, he added. 
"I've expressed skepticism that tax cuts fully pay for themselves," he said. "But I have no doubt they partly pay for themselves."
WITH major parts of the recent tax cut set to take effect on July 1, interest rates still low and layoffs showing signs of slowing, consumer spending is likely to rise, Mr. Mankiw said. That increase would make companies more profitable and help persuade executives to end the long slump in business investment in the wake of the 1990's boom. 
Mr. Mankiw's forecasting record is hardly perfect. In the late 80's, he wrote a paper suggesting that the aging of the baby boomers could cause housing prices to decline 50 percent, adjusted for inflation, over the next two decades. But he has spotted an economic turning point before. When Mr. Clinton took office in 1993 and began studying how to stimulate the economy, Mr. Mankiw correctly said that it was recovering on its own. 
Over the long term, closing the budget deficit, which he called important, will require changing Medicare or Social Security, he said. Senator Jack Reed, Democrat of Rhode Island, asked Mr. Mankiw during his confirmation hearing whether these changes were the same as cuts, and he essentially avoided the question.
Many economists outside the administration predict that the recent tax cuts will eventually have to be reversed or require big reductions in government programs. 
Mr. Mankiw is clearly making an effort to remain consistent with the administration's message in a way that he did not as a professor. Asked about the recent controversy over a tax credit for poor families that was not included in the tax cut this spring, he started to speak, interrupted himself and looked at a White House spokeswoman, Claire Buchan, who was sitting in on the interview. Ms. Buchan then said that Ari Fleischer, the press secretary, had addressed the issue in his briefing that day.
BECOMING a confidant of Mr. Bush, however, will require more than just avoiding headlines. While Mr. Hubbard, the previous council chairman, worked on the 2000 campaign. Mr. Mankiw first met the president, briefly, at an economic summit in Waco, Tex., last year. The man who recommended him for the job, Mr. Hubbard, is now a professor at Columbia.
Making the task harder, Mr. Mankiw's staff members have recently lost their offices in the Eisenhower Executive Office Building, next door to the White House, and been relocated to the decidedly unprestigious address of 1800 G Street NW. Other groups that have been pushed out of the Eisenhower building -- still commonly known as the Old Executive Office Building, include the White House Travel Office and the Office of Presidential Correspondence. Parts of the National Security Council were allowed to stay.
"The biggest effect will be on the morale of the council," said Martin N. Baily, the last council chairman in the Clinton administration. "I can't help but think that the separation will make it tougher on Greg."
Alone among the council staff, Mr. Mankiw still has an office in the Eisenhower building, as well as one in the nondescript building on G Street, where Mr. Bush swore him in. Mr. Mankiw talked about the relocation of his staff with typical good humor. "I get a lot more exercise," he said, by walking between the two offices a couple of times a day. 
Since it was created by the 1946 Employment Act, the Council of Economic Advisers, or C.E.A., has risen and fallen in status several times. Harry Truman had little use for it. Walter Heller, the chairman for John F. Kennedy, helped design a major tax cut. Mr. Greenspan mattered in part because he and Gerald Ford watched football games together, according to the late Herbert Stein, who also held the job under Mr. Ford. 
Mr. Clinton seemed to diminish the council by creating a separate group, the National Economic Council, that coordinates policy from the West Wing. Mr. Bush kept the group intact, and Stephen J. Friedman, a former Goldman Sachs executive, now runs it. Before sitting down with the president, Mr. Mankiw had to interview with Mr. Friedman. But the fact that Mr. Friedman is not an academic economist makes it less probable that Mr. Mankiw will be overshadowed by him. 
Mr. Mankiw said he envisioned his staff as a "think tank" that allows members of the administration to tap into the vast but often indecipherable world of economic research. 
He left little doubt, for example, that he would argue against trade tariffs and subsidies, saying that economists were nearly unanimous in favoring lower trade barriers. At the urging of some political advisers, but over the objections of Mr. Hubbard, Mr. Bush enacted new protections for American farmers and steel makers last year.
"The job of the C.E.A. is to present good economic analysis in a way that is understandable and persuasive to noneconomists," Mr. Mankiw said. But, he added, "ultimately the world is not run by economists."

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: DISORDER; 
Across Iraq, the Dark Shadow Of Hussein Still Looms Large

BYLINE:  By PATRICK E. TYLER

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, June 21 

 BODY:
Professor Hilal al-Bayyati, the former director of Iraq's National Computer Center, is moving out of the country this fall because he does not want to live in fear of Saddam Hussein.
 "I had thought about entering politics, though I am not a politician, but then I thought I did not want to put my family through the risk that someone would come one day and kill me," Professor Bayyati said in an interview. "So I will leave until it is safe to come back." 
 As Mr. Hussein's rule collapsed, Professor Bayyati came to prominence when he led a revolt at Baghdad University against the administration that was dominated by senior members of Mr. Hussein's Baath Party. 
Motivated by two years of prison and torture under Mr. Hussein, Professor Bayyati was determined to help rid the country -- or at least the university -- of the remnants of the dictator's most ardent supporters.
But now he thinks the effort is failing, or going too slow. What really bothers the professor is that more than two months on, the specter of Saddam Hussein still lays across the land in Iraq.
Despite the presence of 140,000 American troops, Professor Bayyati and many other Iraqis of assorted political outlooks feel no sense of a consolidated victory. They see no power emerging that is capable of stamping out the vestige of the once all-powerful Mr. Hussein.
The attacks on American forces that have left 13 soldiers dead in the past month and the apparent sabotage against electrical and oil installations critical to economic and social recovery are feeding a new psychology of fear in Iraq.
Professor Bayyati, one of thousands of Mr. Hussein's victims, is taking the personal step of leaving because he fears becoming a victim again. "I think it will get worse if there is no real action taken," he said, referring to the so far unsuccessful efforts to disarm thousands of Husseinloyalists.
Many of Mr. Hussein's supporters are believed to have access to hidden funds and hidden weapons. Thousands of people have been denied access to government jobs because of their high rank in the Baath Party, but they remain free to subvert the status quo if they choose.
When crowds form these days in the capital, the loudest voices are often those of Mr. Hussein's supporters. Those who speak against the ousted leader often do so by pulling reporters aside to speak in whispered tones or in English, so that most bystanders cannot understand.
On a recent afternoon at Jassim's, a coffee house on the corner of Safina and Al Hara streets in the Khadamiya district of the city, Mohsen Abdel Hassan, 65, was going on about how much he hated Mr. Hussein.
He pulled out a box cutter and said, "If I were to see him, I would slit his throat," as he lightly pulled the blade across his own neck.
But when a man with close-cropped hair and a military bearing walked up to listen to Mr. Abdel Hassan's conversation with a foreign reporter, the conversation froze.
After the man walked away, Mr. Abdel Hassan arched his brow and explained his momentary silence. "He looked like a Baathist to me," he said. "They are not very easy people and they still exist."
Many Iraqis presume that Mr. Hussein prepared hiding places long in advance of the American and British invasion. They imagine him on a farm along the Euphrates River, in a house in a Baghdad suburb or in a military dugout protected by loyal aides, and those images still radiate a sense of power over Iraqis.
The capture this week of Mr. Hussein's closest aide, Abid Hamid Mahmoud al-Tikriti, sent a shiver of hope through the ranks of Iraqis who fear his ability to threaten their future.
Galab Sadiq Muhammmad has been baking bread since the time of the monarchy in Iraq four decades ago. Nowadays, he sits on a bench under an acacia tree most afternoons and drinks sweetened tea.
The only remedy that would rid the country of Mr. Hussein's shadow, he said, was a new Iraqi government that would project itself clearly and forcefully across an unruly land of ethnic and religious division.
"Whoever comes, we will call him father," he said as he ordered tea for a visitor.
The power of the fallen dictator appears sometimes in surprising places. Sadiq Abdel Amir, a Shiite Muslim and 23-year veteran of the Iraqi Air Force, was drummed out of the service after the Persian Gulf war in 1991 because the loyalty of all Shiites was suspect after hundreds of thousands rebelled against the government across southern Iraq.
Yet he was thinking about Mr. Hussein last week as the antidote for the disorder and chaos that Mr. Amir sees in the country. "We need Saddam Hussein with his iron fist," he said as he stood in the middle of the Jumhuriya Bridge across the Tigris River.
As Mr. Amir spoke, he was distracted by something in the river below. There, moving with the stream, was the body of a man in black trousers, floating face down.
No one was doing anything to retrieve the body. There were no Iraqi police officers in the area, no rescue squad or boat to recover the body making its silent and uninterrupted passage through the center of the city that is still largely lawless because there is no government.
The limits of American and British occupation authority were evident on the bridge that morning. There is an army of 55,000 here more than able to secure the streets with its tanks and mobile howitzers, but it is unable to protect Iraqis in their homes from random crimes, or, perhaps, from the the vengeance of Mr. Hussein.
Mr. Amir was making the bridge crossing as he fled a demonstration of former Iraqi Army officers demanding back pay. An American soldier had fired into the crowd, killing two of the demonstrators.
Mr. Amir gestured toward the body in the river as if it contributed to his point about the search for order. "We need someone with Saddam Hussein's power and his strength to control everything in Iraq," he said before uncertainly making his way across the span toward home.
